glossdef.para: The root directory of the Activation Server installation. When the Activation Server packages are installed, the software creates a BJCWCore subdirectory under the installation directory, and the files are extracted under the BJCWCore directory. Together, the installation and the BJCWCore directories are referred to as the BJROOT or $BJROOT directory.
A software component that retrieves content from third-party knowledge bases.
802.11 refers to a family of standards for WLAN (wireless local area network) communication developed by the IEEE. Commonly referred to as Wi-Fi, 802.11 includes 802.11a, 802.11b, and 802.11g.
Source: JIWIRE and Wikipedia

The Alcatel-Lucent 9900 Wireless Network Guardian (WNG) is a hardware and software system that watches wireless data subscriber traffic and network signaling traffic to identify behaviors that impact and threaten the performance of wireless data networks. A WNG system includes one or more detectors that monitor traffic, and one central server that manages the detectors and collects their data.
The name of a femtocell access point, which identifies the network that is accessible to associated mobile phones.
An organization that owns the cable or DSL infrastructure of the last mile (to the subscriber home). For cable technology, this is the MSO. For DSL technology, this is the telephone company (telco).

A switch that, when combined with an IVR menu, receives all phone calls at a typical call center. The ACD system routes calls according to a specified algorithm (set of rules) to CSRs who are not currently on the phone. In call centers, these rules are used against data provided by the IVR system to route calls to the next available CSR within a certain skill set group or queue. When a CSR becomes available, the CSR services the first caller in this queue.
Content created in Studio that contains a set of programming instructions that run on computers to diagnose or repair problems.
The client/server functionality that initiates subscriber access to and provides enhanced services on IP access networks.

The hardware and software infrastructure dedicated to an activation deployment. This infrastructure includes a firewall, load balancer, and some number of activation-dedicated hosts. Each activation host runs an installation of the Activation Server.
A host that runs the Activation Server software.

An online transaction processing schema that provides for the basic function and operations of an activation deployment. The schema stores all services configuration, state, and operational data as well as the subscriber computer data collected from clients during the activation process.

A schema optimized for bulk activation reporting purposes. The activation data stored in the activation OLTP schema is extracted, transformed, and loaded into the reporting schema. Typically, this transformation, referred to as ETL, occurs on a nightly basis through scheduled batch jobs. In addition to completing data cleansing, the ETL can assign subscriber activations into organizations based on attributes such as postal code, state, account number prefix, and other attributes.
Motive database reports that describe the characteristics of a subscriber computer, such as the OS and amount of RAM present, at the time of service activation.
The server software that supports an activation deployment. The software is installed on each activation host.

A program that performs discrete functions that perform specific tasks to initiate broadband service on a subscriber computer. Activation workflows perform basic access, computer activation, network activation, or a unique combination of these functions.
A Studio document and associated client content with an attached action that automates problem resolution or a hyperlink to a page containing automated actions.
A user interface in which the user must perform an action before the workflow continues. A Workflow Editor-related term.

A component program object that can be reused by many application programs within a computer or among computers in a network. ActiveX controls can be downloaded as small programs or animations for web pages. In addition, they can be used by applications running on the latest Windows operating systems to execute common tasks. In general, ActiveX controls replace the earlier OCX (Object Linking and Embedding custom controls). The technology for building ActiveX controls is part of Microsoft's overall ActiveX set of technologies, chief of which is the Component Object Model (COM).
An interface defined for a subflow including inputs, outputs, and end states. Subflows are configured to implement the activities for different interactive workflow channels.
An enabled subscriber who has used Motive software at least once.
Compare to converted subscriber.
The percentage of subscribers who are actively using Motive solutions to resolve problems and questions.

A technology that enables high-speed data connections in homes and businesses by transmitting digital information over ordinary phone lines. ADSL provides transmission speeds up to 9 Mbps downstream (to the customer) and up to 800 Kbps upstream. ADSL can transmit analog (voice) and data information on the same line simultaneously.
bjinternal A Motive Expert Service that leverages Motive's in-house usability labs and expertise to enhance the subscriber and customer service representative experiences.
A software component that connects to the agent harness and can be reused in other agents. An agent plug-in is a subset of an agent.
For example, Monitor, Test, Repair, and Help are agent plug-ins for CorrectConnect.

A device that acts as a server host for multiple other devices or users and forwards data in a concentrated and economical way. The aggregator can handle up to 100 incoming dial-up calls for an Internet (or other network) point-of-presence. In some cases, the aggregator can support a certain number of ISDN connections, leased-line traffic, and frame relay traffic while also serving as a router.
A web service offered by Amazon.com which allows web-based access to databases that can be created and scaled up or down via API calls. One of the set of Amazon Web Services (AWS).
In Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3), a bucket is a container that can store any number of objects.
A set of web services offered by Amazon.com which allows companies to expand or contract their computer usage dynamically, as needed.

Device or transmission signal with the property of continuously varying in strength or quantity, such as voltage or audio. Traditionally, broadcast and telephone transmission have relied on analog technology.

A device used to transmit data from a computer over a telephone line to connect to the Internet. An analog modem modulates outgoing digital signals to analog signals, and demodulates incoming analog signals to digital signals.
The Motive software server component that manages the services and communications associated with the Insight and CSR Console applications.

Open-source server software that is used by the Activation Server as its web server. Apache functions as the front-end server that responds to all client requests in the segment. Apache serves static files (such as client updates) to clients that request them, and it forwards requests that require a dynamically generated response to Tomcat. Upon receipt, Apache forwards Tomcat responses to clients.
A database that uses column oriented data model. It provides a scalable multi-master database with no single points of failure and the convenience of columns, rows, column families, and keyspace.
The set of methods, classes, and fields written for an operating system or application. Programmers use the API to make requests of the operating system or another application.
Compare with CLI and GUI.
A client or server program that performs specific tasks.
A Motive action that detects specific conditions during content searches to determine the appropriate content to display on an service site web page.
An open incident that is assigned to a CSR.
Type of service in which a CSR assists a subscriber with problem resolution.
An service request that is routed to a CSR for resolution.

Network technology that transmits data, voice, video, and frame relay traffic in real time. ATM organizes digital data into packets of information and transfers this data over a cable or DSL modem that uses digital signal technology.
In Studio, a reference to a file that an action launches on a subscriber computer to perform a specific function. Attachments can include references to nested actions, DLLs, or other system files.
Also, a resource file (such as a graphics or movie file) that is associated with a document.
glossdef.remark: commenting out the following while AnswerWeb is not customer-facing in the product as of Mont Blanc

glossdef.para: The definition for a group or class of users that determines who can view particular content on a Motive service site.
In a multiuser environment, a process that compares user logon information to an authorized list. If a match is found, access and privileges are granted as defined in the role assigned to that user.
A software component that provides the capability to authenticate subscribers against third-party authentication systems.
The rights granted to a person to use the system and data stored there.

The capability that facilitates an automatic transfer of diagnostics from the subscriber system to the server, provided that the system is connected. The telemetry submitted provides valuable information for resolving problems in both self-service and assisted service.
Compare to diagnostic code.
On-net content that is billed from within the access provider network by the content provider rather than by the access provider.
The amount of data transmitted through a digital system in a given amount of time. Generally, bandwidth is measured in bits per second (bps).
A basic diagnostic action that retrieves general information from subscriber computers.

Workflow functionality that configures a subscriber computer for IP dialtone. Sometimes basic access and computer activation make up a single activation workflow that runs on subscriber computers end to end from a CD. Otherwise, basic access is the only functionality on the CD. In this case, basic access establishes limited connectivity and launches a web-based workflow from the Activation Server to perform computer activation and possibly network activation.
A set of reusable utilities that Motive agents and the Motive Client Foundation use.

The software architecture that enables components to be combined into a variety of Motive applications. BJCOM defines a standard for component interoperability that is extensible and provides for robust evolution of component-based applications and systems.

A platform-independent library to implement GUIs (graphical user interfaces) for consumer-oriented agents. BJGUI provides a platform-independent API for the native GUI widget set of each supported platform; a set of widget replacements for native widgets so that the look and feel can be changed by replacing bitmaps; and a GUI description language that allows GUIs to be scripted using text files.

The company name for the second-generation framework that serves as the basis for development of client and server applications. BMW is a library of modular code that applications can access to provide common functions such as security and client update management.
The Motive software server component that functions as the central contact point for management and security services within a Motive environment.
A measure of data speed equal to the number of bits transmitted each second.
The process of replacing the generic names in product packaging with a company's product name and logo.
Compare with configuration.

Communication technology in which the medium of transmission, such as a wire or fiber optic cable, carries several messages at a time, with each message modulated on its own carrier frequency by means of modems. Broadband communication is used on WANs and LANs.

Motive self-management software that automates the residential subscriber service and support experience. Leveraging intelligent self-configuration and self-repair capabilities, Broadband Manager takes the waste out of complex management processes that affect customer satisfaction and drive costs up for service providers.

Broadband Manager software that provides subscribers tools to activate their broadband service. Providers deploy Broadband Manager Activation Edition to lower operational cost, deploy service considerably faster, and decrease subscriber turnover.

Broadband Manager software that provides subscribers self-service tools to resolve connectivity issues and troubleshoot other problems. Providers deploy Broadband Manager Electronic Edition to reduce costs and improve subscriber satisfaction by automating service and support.

Broadband Manager software that automates the connection and configuration of multiple digital devices and applications in a home network. Providers deploy Broadband Manager Home Networking Edition to provide subscribers an intuitive, self-setup process for home networking.

Broadband Manager software that provides subscribers the resources to resolve problems through automated self-service over a phone call. Providers deploy Broadband Manager Phone Edition to optimize support call interactions and reduce support costs by deflecting calls.

The Motive client that subscribers use to run problem diagnostics and repair scripts on their computers and to access provider resources to research problems. Subscribers use the client to conduct self-service and to acquire assisted service, depending on the deployment. The Broadband Technician runs on Windows and Macintosh operating systems.
An organization that provides broadband access to the Internet.

A configuration that defines which action to apply for a target population of endpoints or subscribers. A bulk campaign depends on either a business process workflow or a service operation to perform the action for the specified population.

Motive self-management software that automates the configuration and management of small business broadband services. Business Class Manager makes broadband access and value-added services self-managing for the growing number of small business customers targeted by service providers. Leveraging intelligent self-configuration capabilities, Business Class Manager makes it easier for small businesses to use broadband and increases their adoption of fee-based value-added services.

BSS are the components that a telecommunications service provider uses to run its business operations towards customers. Together with operations support systems (OSS), they are used to support various end-to-end telecommunication services (for example, telephone services).

Customer premises equipment (CPE) device that transmits data through a coaxial cable television network rather than phone lines, as with a conventional modem. Cable modems generally transmit data faster than conventional modems. An advantage of a cable modem is that the user does not have to dial up for network access because the computer is connected continuously.

A television distribution system in which broadcast and nonbroadcast signals, received by elevated antennas, are transmitted by cable ( coaxial or fiber optic or both) to the televisions of subscribers.

A third-party adapter that provides high availability (HA) distributed locking and caching in multi-cluster installations. The Cache Adapter for Redis is a replacement for Hazelcast, which is configured in an SMP installation by default.

A server that saves (or caches) web pages that users request for the first time and then provides them quickly on successive user requests. The main advantages of a caching server are that it enables users to view cached pages quickly, reduces Internet traffic, and may enable users to view cached web pages when the real pages are unavailable. Files transmitted by FTP and other methods also can be cached.
The act of resolving an service request through self-service without intervention from a CSR.
Content and application companies that partner with Motive and broadband service providers ( BSPs) to market their products to subscribers as offers through Motive activation software.
A workflow that runs on the subscriber computer from a CD.
Set of content from different vendors distributed through one vendor.
For example, Encarta, as a CDN, delivers content from a variety of vendors, including Time Warner, MTV, and others.
A set of tools and guidelines for developing Motive ChannelDirect integrations.
An action that gathers information to create a profile of an application or component, but cannot back up or restore operations.

The component of the Broadband Technician for Windows that gathers telemetry information about the subscriber system and what the subscriber is doing to determine the appropriate interface pages to display. Subscribers use Chorus self-service and assisted service pages to diagnose and repair their systems, depending on the deployment. Chorus also handles content synchronization and incident management.
Before SmartCare and before Broadband Technician, Chorus used to mean everything subscriber facing. That meaning has since changed, though previous usage permeates the product.

A company in the United States that competes with an established local telephone business by providing its own network and switching. CLEC is a term that distinguishes new or potential competitors from established local exchange carriers (LECs) and originates from the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which was intended to promote competition among both long distance and local telephone service providers.
Examples of CLECs are North American Telecom and Winstar Communications, which generally are listed simply as local exchange carriers.
Source: Atomica.
A user interface to an operating system or an application in which the user types commands using a special command language.
Compare with API and GUI.
The subscriber computer in a client/server architecture. The piece of the Motive framework that controls the behavior of client services.

Use the term client to refer to the communication between the subscriber computer and the server, in industry-standard references such as client/server architecture, and in external, low-level technical documentation that describes the client (rather than the agent).
A unique registration ID that the Activation Server assigns to each subscriber system.

An assisted service request that was resolved by a CSR and has been acknowledged by the subscriber as resolved. To reach a closed confirmed state, a service request must first go through the closed pending state.
An assisted service request that has been resolved by a CSR and is waiting for the subscriber to acknowledge that it is resolved.
The network device in the central office of a cable MSO to which multiple customer cables send signals. The CMTS converts these signals to data packets and passes the data packets to the Internet.
A type of cable used by cable television companies to transfer signals between the community antenna and televisions in homes and businesses.

A database backup made while the database is down. During a cold backup, users and applications that depend on the database cannot connect to the database. If feasible, companies should make cold backups of the database once a month.
The Insight desktop tool that enables CSRs to provide assistance with incidents assigned to other CSRs in the Motive environment.
General term for a software application responsible for loading, activation, access, and unloading of components.

Workflow functionality that performs a minimum requirements check to qualify a subscriber computer for service and then configures and brands broadband service on the system. Typically, computer activation installs third-party applications such as Internet Explorer onto subscriber computers, configures Outlook Express account settings, and updates web browser settings to define a particular home page and favorites. It is possible to deploy the computer activation functionality through a CD-based workflow or a web-based workflow.
A large hub for connecting cable or DSL inside a central office. Typically, a concentrator functions as a DSLAM in a DSL network.
In general, concentrating (or multiplexing) allows multiple entities to share a single communication medium.
Also known as access concentrator. Use the term concentrator instead.
A process that involves modifying files to change application appearance or behavior.

A Windows-based tool for creating customized activation applications that run on subscriber computers. The customized applications are based on use cases, which are fully configured applications that have been developed and tested by Motive.
A customer-configured and branded workflow that is ready for deployment. A reference workflow and its configured version are associated with a use case that a Motive solution supports.

A string used by Oracle software to establish a session with the database. The value of connect_identifier is in the service entry in the file $ORACLE_HOME/network/admin/tnsnames.ora. Other common references to the connect_identifier string are database_spec and database_instance.
The link between two work nodes. Connections determine the flow of logic through a workflow. A Workflow Editor-related term.
A Studio user who creates documents or actions to help resolve subscriber problems. commenting this out while AnswerWeb is not part of the product as of Mont Blanc

The Motive software server component that processes data associated with requests for content within the Motive software environment and serves the appropriate HTML-formatted web pages. Also, the Content server hosts subscriber-facing applications.

A type of service alert that enables automatic content synchronization on SmartBridge clients. Subscriber systems with SmartBridge installed automatically receive these content updates and can accept or cancel the updates. Content update events are created and configured in the Management Console.

A property associated with a specific location in an application or web page or with other specific data which determines the appropriate problem resolutions for the Motive software to display to subscribers.

The continued use of Motive software by adopted subscribers. Continued use is defined as two or more service requests from the same subscriber. Such a subscriber is referred to as a converted subscriber.
An enabled subscriber who has used Motive software two or more times.
Compare to adopted subscriber.

The company name for the third-generation framework that serves as the basis for Motive client and server applications. Corvette is a library of modular code that Motive applications can access to provide common functions such as security and client update management.

Method for managing traffic that organizes groups of similar network traffic (such as email, streaming video, voice, large document file transfer) and handles them as classes each with its own level of service priority. Unlike Quality of Service (QoS), CoS technology does not guarantee a certain bandwidth and delivery time; instead, a CoS offers a "best-effort." Of course, CoS technology is easier to manage and more scalable as a network increases in size and traffic.
Source: whatis?com.
The primary processor in a personal computer where most calculations take place.
A document that customers use to review configuration options and make selections concerning the delivery of Motive software.

The methodologies, software, and processes related to the management of the interaction of a company with its customers. Activities automated and tracked by CRM systems include pre-sales, sales, and support.
Company or organization that provides the value-added services, content, applications, and other services that an access provider or ISP can offer to subscribers.
Use the term value-added services provider instead.
A person who provides subscribers assisted service. CSRs use Motive software to diagnose and resolve service issues while communicating with subscribers.
CSRs are sometimes referred to as analysts or agents.

Web-based interface that CSRs use to facilitate assisted service while working with a subscriber over the phone. The CSR Console presents a consolidated view of the subscriber system telemetry and backend telemetry from resources such as a diagnostic code if subscriber system is not connected to the provider network or if automatic telemetry submission is not available; automatic telemetry submission if subscriber system is connected; and third-parties such as billing, provisioning, and outage telemetry providers.

The interface was first released with Fuego as the SmartCall CSR Console. It is also known as (and still referred to as in Bugzilla) the PRT (Problem Resolution Tool). There is/was also a PRT in the ASM/EEM area...that's something completely different.
A subscriber phone incident that is routed directly to a CSR. The CSR-direct call bypasses the self-service path.

A simple method for globally formatting (typefaces, colors, and layout) a set of web documents from a single file or small number of CSS files. Comprehensive references for CSS1 (level 1) and CSS2 (level 2) are available.
The combination of computer and voice systems to manage and enhance phone services. For example, CTI can enable caller authentication and call processing following a programmed set of rules.

Rented or purchased equipment that is physically located at the residence or office of a subscriber. Examples include cable or DSL modem, residential gateways, IP set-top boxes, VoIP terminal adapters, and femtocell base stations.

Motive product that helps CSRs (customer support representative) pinpoint the cause of and resolution for service issues on behalf of high-speed data subscribers. The product gathers service data referred to as telemetry from multiple sources to present CSRs with a complete representation of a service as it exists in a subscribers environment. Also, the product presents CSRs the results of a comparison between the subscriber information and managed settings that model the optimal working state. The overall process empowers CSRs to automatically perform root cause analysis and to drive rapid and accurate resolution.

A program that runs continuously to distribute periodic requests to other programs or services as appropriate. For example, web servers use a Hypertext Transfer Protocol daemon (HTTPD) to distribute requests from clients to the appropriate servers and services.
A repository of files that a Deployment Automation Framework (DAF) system's Master Server uses to install components on client machines; contained in a folder on the Master Server.
A web page that provides a quick and accurate measure of certain statistics to help understand how one or more Motive software solutions are being used.
During server installation, the fully-qualified domain name of the database server host computer. Called the Global Database name in the Oracle installation.

A service that provides database interaction services across all Activation Server services and applications. The Activation Server persists configuration and operational data in an external relational database.

A database optimized for reporting and querying rather than for transaction processing. Reporting databases or schemas are sometimes referred to as OLAP (Online Analytical Processing) databases, in contrast to OLTP (Online Transaction Processing) databases. Data marts are designed with fewer tables, more indexes, and de-normalization. Typically data is moved at regular intervals but at off-peak times from the OLTP transaction database to the data mart by means of an ETL tool.

A data mart or OLAP database reduces the load on the transactional database and facilitates faster, more accurate reporting for a subdivision of a larger organization. Data warehouses, in contrast, pull together data from multiple databases and multiple departments. Data warehouses are sometimes made from multiple data marts. Data marts and data warehouses are often designed with a star schema or snowflake schema.
The host in the Motive environment on which the nightly ETL (extract, transform, load) processes run.
The group of entities, their attributes, the relationships among these entities, and integrity rules that make the abstraction from the real world of those properties relevant to a given application.

A database optimized for reporting and querying rather than transaction processing. Reporting databases or schemas are sometimes referred to OLAP (Online Analytical Processing) databases, in contrast to OLTP (Online Transaction Processing) databases. Data warehouses are designed with fewer tables, more indexes, and de-normalization. Typically data is moved at regular intervals but at off-peak times from the OLTP transaction database to the data warehouse by means of an ETL tool.

A data warehouse or OLAP database reduces the load on the transactional database and facilitates faster, more accurate reporting. Data marts are similar to data warehouses, except that they focus on one department of the organization and often only pull data from a single transactional database. Data warehouses are sometimes made from multiple data marts.
The term deployed means set up within a provider network. Also known as packaged. Use deployed instead.
The term hosted means set up offsite from a provider's network and managed by Motive.
The service installed. Motive offers a family of products with a client/server architecture that targets the life cycle of a broadband Internet subscription and other service subscriptions.

This is a TR-064 service that allows the handling of device configuration which includes managing transactions to prevent a device from simultaneously processing configuration changes from multiple Control Points or interfaces. This service is required for devices that support the TR-064 protocol.

This is a TR-064 service that allows the reporting of basic device information, including the current hardware and software versions. This service is required for devices that support the TR-064 protocol.

A TCP/IP protocol that automates the assignment of IP addresses in a network. DHCP lends an IP address to a computer. Using short lease periods, DHCP can dynamically reconfigure networks that have more computers than there are available IP addresses.

A numeric code that defines a discrete set of subscriber system telemetry. For example, after the server decodes the diagnostic code, the results may indicate that the subscriber system includes an installed CD-ROM drive. The diagnostic code is key to problem resolution when the subscriber system is not connected.
Compare to automatic telemetry submission.
A content type with an attached action that provides an automated information-gathering check on a computer to determine if a hardware or software component is functional.

The process of generating a diagnostic code on the subscriber system. Diagnostic encoding provides information about the subscriber environment to identify any non- optimal value. Typically, diagnostic encoding facilitates providing subscribers assisted service when they are not connected to the Internet.

The Java language code interpreter used by Motive actions. Currently, Motive Studio supports the use of diagnostic engines that operate with two runtime environments: Java/JView and J#. To test the code, content developers must have the appropriate runtime environments (Java/JView, J#, or both) installed. To run an action in production, the appropriate runtime environment must be installed on the subscriber system.

Refers to a condition in which a server process stops running. A Tomcat process can die for an unexpected reason. For example, the port Tomcat needs is unavailable because another process is using the port. At this point, the Tomcat process stops running (dies), and PCS restarts it.
Use the term stops running instead.
Compare with fail.

Technology that generates, stores, and processes data in combinations of bits. The states are positive and nonpositive, where positive is represented by the number 1, and where nonpositive is represented by the number 0. As a result, digital data is expressed as a string of 0s and 1s.

An encrypted file and accompanying private key that is provided by a known certifying authority. The digital certificate is used by a subscriber system to authenticate secure communication from a host. The activation service supports certificates from two authorities: Verisign and Thawte.

In a data mart or data warehouse, dimension tables model the attributes that provide the context in which events occur. The events are modeled in fact tables with foreign key references to records in dimension tables. For example, dimensions such as time, customer, and operating system provide part of the context in which some event, such as the creation of a service request, occurs.
Windows 95 software that enables applications direct access to the sound and graphics hardware of a computer.

An area between an internal network, such as a corporate LAN, and an external network, such as the Internet. Typically, the DMZ contains devices accessible to Internet traffic. The term comes from military use, meaning a buffer area between two enemies.
A server that implements the Domain Name System (DNS), which automatically translates the domain name to its numerical IP address that can be used by the packet-routing software.

glossentry.glossterm: DOCSIS (Data Over Cable Service Interface Specification)

glossdef.para: An interface for cable modems that optimizes cable bandwidth use. DOCSIS supports multiple classes of service (CoS), as well as real-time service flows needed for applications such as voice and streaming media.
In Broadband Technician and Narrowband Technician clients, an attachment to a service alert that is expressed as the path to a file.
In Studio, a file that contains HTML-formatted information about computing resources and problems, and is published as a web page for a service site.
The last part of a Web address. The domain identifies the type of organization that owns the address. Common domains are: .com, .edu, and .org.
A meaningful, user-friendly address of a network connection. The domain name identifies the owner of the address in a hierarchical format: server.organization.type.
A point at which access to a resource can be gained. For instance, the RJ11 jack in a hub is an Ethernet drop. Also, a wire pair coming out of a DSLAM is a drop.
A technology that provides high-bandwidth Internet connections to homes and small businesses over ordinary copper telephone lines. DSL can carry both data and voice signals.

The DSL version of CMTS. A DSLAM is a network device in the central office of a telephone company to which customer DSL connections send signals. DSLAMs move the signals received from individual copper pairs onto a single high-speed pipe.
A CPE device that connects a computer to a regular telephone line for network access. Generally, DSL modems transmit data at a much faster rate than a standard telephone modem.
Microsoft technology that enables Windows users to connect to a network using a modem.

A digital video recorder (also known as a PVR or personal video recorder) is a device that records television programs or video from a security camera to a hard disk for later playback. DVRs typically also have features to help you manage your recorded videos and to schedule recordings.

A Workflow Editor-related term.A type of connection that is a line between two work nodes. Dynamic connectors always have an arrow that points in the direction of the logic flow. Normally, dynamic connectors are routed from a work node output to a work node input.
Interactive workflows that authors create based on an adaptive workflow framework to automate the selection of the path with the best statistical chance of resolving a problem.

Virtual channel through which subscribers resolve service issues by using Broadband Technician, Narrowband Technician, Motive Support Portal, or the Escalation page. The electronic channel supports self-service and assisted service, depending on the deployment. This is a 5.x term. Use electronic channel in 6.x contexts.
An individual who has access to the Service Management Client or the Escalation page.

Enterprise Messaging Gateway (EMG) is a very powerful and configurable SMS/MMS gateway, message router and protocol converter. It provides connectivity between applications, SMSC/MMSCs and other messaging entities.
Management system (such as a program, an API, or a SNMP MIB) provided with a network element. An example of an EMS is the interface used to control a Redback SMS.
An individual who has the Service Management Client installed.
Subscriber system state in which Service Management Client is installed.
Rules governing the transmission of multiple protocols within the same network. The frames of one type of protocol are carried within the frames of another.
Source: TechEncyclopedia.
A subscriber machine.

A service request that is routed to a CSR for resolution after a subscriber attempts to resolve the issue through self-service. Escalated self-service requests are a subset of assisted service requests.
The action of submitting or transitioning a request to a CSR for assisted service.
Web page that subscribers access either online or offline to facilitate problem resolution with assisted service. The Escalation page executes automatic telemetry submission from subscriber systems.

A database management programming tool that incorporates three functions. The extract function reads data from a specific database and extracts a subset of data. Next, the transform function converts the extracted data into the intended format. Lastly, the load function writes the extracted and transformed data to a target database.
bjinternal Services provided by Motive at an additional cost to help customers plan and optimize the production and delivery of their SmartSuite applications.
A Workflow Editor-related term.A workflow that loads during the execution of another workflow. For efficiency, the extension workflow does not contain binary files that are in the master workflow.

In a data mart or data warehouse, fact tables model the key events that occur in the domain being modeled, such as an individual sale, a service request, or content being accessed by the subscriber. Fact tables include fields that describe aspects of the fact being modeled and fields that contain foreign key references to relevant dimensions to provide context for the fact being modeled. Data in fact tables is often a candidate for aggregation.
Refers to a condition in which an action is not completed as expected. For example, Tomcat can fail to load the server management servlet, which causes the Activation Server services not to function.
In Studio and associated client content, a content type that contains a set of common questions and answers about an issue.
A computer or storage device on a network that makes files available to other computers on the same network.
To make files and folders available to other computers on a network. File sharing provides multiple users read, write, or read and write access to a set of files configured for sharing.
Unique identifier for a service alert. The filter criteria uses the subscriber context to determine when an alert should be displayed.

para.remark: [**Writer's note: This definition was written with the HomeView/home networking audience in mind. Another glossary term could be added for more technical audiences.**]

glossdef.para: A system that prevents unauthorized access to a computer or network by blocking incoming network traffic. Software firewalls, such as the Windows Firewall, protect individual computers while hardware firewalls, such as those typically included in residential gateways, protect entire home networks.
A column or columns that uniquely identify a record in another database table by referring to its primary key.

An identifier that consists of a host and domain name, including top-level domain. For example, www.motive.com is a fully qualified domain name. www is the host, motive is the second-level domain, and .com is the top-level domain. A FQDN always starts with a host name and continues all the way up to the top-level domain name, so www.inhouse.motive.com is also a FQDN.

The set of APIs and implementations that support Motive applications. The framework consists of core components common to all applications and includes both server and client functionality. Applications are "built on top of" the framework.
The Motive software server component that receives and processes communication from subscriber computers and coordinates communication for incident data.
A network point that serves as an entrance to another network.
A CSR from one workgroup who is enabled by a Management Console feature to work on a service request in another workgroup.
The GUI contains graphical elements such as buttons and menus that users click or execute through keyboard commands to interface with an operating system or application.
Compare with API and CLI.

A Call Request Management (CRM) client that enables CSRs to open and work with service requests. A Help Desk client (such as the Remedy Action Request System client) can be integrated with the Motive environment to provide access to the CSR Console.

A Call Request Management (CRM) system server that handles requests from the Motive Integration server and from a CRM client to negotiate backend services such as subscriber identification and authentication and Motive-CRM system synchronization of CSR accounts with a CRM database. For example, the integration with the Remedy Action Request System (ARS) leverages the Remedy server to provide authentication and synchronization services.
Description of a system or component that is continuously functioning. Planning for high availability usually focuses on backup and failover processing and data storage and access.

A home network (or home LAN) consists of two or more computers or other devices connected to form a local area network (LAN) within a residence. A home network enables connected computers to share files, programs, accessories, and Internet access. In addition to computers, devices like game consoles, IP cameras, personal video recorders, file servers, and other devices can be connected to a home network.

Home networking is the process of connecting two or more computers to enable them to share files, programs, accessories, and Internet access. In addition to computers, devices like game consoles, IP cameras, personal video recorders, file servers, and other devices can be connected to a home network.
One step or segment of the path between routers on a dispersed network. A hop is similar to one leg of a trip that includes several destinations between the starting point and the final destination.
The number of hops a packet took to arrive at its destination.
A computer connected to a network. The subscriber computer is the client host, and the provider system is the server host.

Writeronly. Once activation integration with support occurs, this para could probably go.You can use the term host to mean activation host if the distinction is clear in context. To qualify what kind of host it is, use server host and client host. To refer to the software that runs on a host and provides one or more services (such as Apache or Tomcat), use the term server.

This is a TR-064 service that provides information about each of the hosts on this LAN, including those hosts whose IP addresses were allocated by the CPE using the DHCP as well as hosts with statically allocated IP addresses. It also allows the IP address of a particular host to be re-allocated by removing it from this table.

A database backup made while the database is running. During a hot backup, transactions should proceed mostly as normal. Typically, companies run hot backups during off-peak hours because they have some performance impact.
In Studio, a content type that contains written instructions for performing a task.

The set of tags or codes used for documents on the World Wide Web. HTML is a markup language that uses tags to mark text and graphics to indicate how web browsers should display elements and how to respond to user actions.
The client/server protocol used to access information, such as text, graphics, sound, video, and other multimedia files, on the World Wide Web.
An engineering process that prepares a product to operate without modification in a variety of human languages other than the language in which it was initially developed.

A device that provides other devices access points to a network. The IGD could be a single device (such as a combination device that is DSL and Ethernet-capable), or it may be a composite device that consists of a simple one-port Internet CPE and an Ethernet/Ethernet or Ethernet/wireless device that implements the NAT and router logic. IGDs also are referred to as residential gateways or gateways.
glossdef.glossseealso: IGD DCP (Internet Gateway Device Device Control Protocol)

glossentry.glossterm: IGD DCP (Internet Gateway Device Device Control Protocol)

glossdef.para: Standardized specifications that UPnP-compliant IGDs implement. See the UPnP Forum web site for more information. Marking this content internal because it's verbatim from the source and I don't want to rewrite it. This whole dfn should probably be reworked with input from Heather Kirksley. The DCP supports IP and PPP connections that originate at the IGD or pass through the IGD from a host on the LAN; configuration of cable, DSL, POTS, and Ethernet WAN interfaces; remote configuration of LAN DHCP services; and the delivery of generic and connection-specific status information.
Source: Intel Corporation

Also, the IGD specification includes a solution for NAT (Network Address Translation) traversal. NAT can break many computer and home networking experiences such as multi-player games, real-time communications, and other peer-to-peer services that consumers use in their homes or small businesses. As IP packets from the private LAN traverse the gateway, NAT translates a private IP address and port number to a public IP address and port number, tracking those translations to keep individual sessions intact.
A new and easy way to communicate with friends and colleagues in diverse locations using the concept of a virtual meeting room, a customisable space where you can meet, discuss and share information
In Studio, a content type that contains text and graphics from existing HTML-formatted web pages to re-create the pages within the framework of Studio documents.
Automated. For example, if you order a service using your computer, the service is an in-band service.

In pre-6.x Motive environments, an instance of subscriber information and system telemetry recorded in the database. The issues associated with incidents are resolved through self-service or assisted service.
The Insight desktop tool that searches for and displays a list of incidents on a specific server.
An Insight desktop tool that displays important information and activities associated with each incident, including telemetry, incident history, and messages.
A file that maintains records about events and operations performed on each incident received within Insight.

Windows-based tool that CSRs use to facilitate assisted service while resolving incidents. The incidents in Insight are those created by subscribers using Broadband Technician to submit them over the Web. From Insight, CSRs view incidents and subscriber system telemetry, and they also chat with subscribers. commenting this out while AnswerWeb is not part of the product as of Mont Blanc
Compare to CSR Console.
A Motive software component that translates information and enables data exchange between external third-party applications and Motive software components.
The optional Motive software server component that functions as a gateway to third-party business systems.
IMEI number is a 15 or 17 digit unique number to identify mobile devices.
The protocol within TCP/IP that computers use to send and receive data over the Internet.

A number that uniquely identifies a host that is connected to a TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) network such as a LAN (local area network) or the Internet. An IP address is a 32-bit number with decimal values for its four bytes separated by periods (for example: 156.2.2.3).
An IP camera or network camera is a camera that can send compressed digital images across the Internet or a LAN. IP cameras are typically used as part of a security system.
A Windows NT network utility that provides users access to information about their TCP/IP and network adapter settings.
IPconfig provides a quick way to determine if a computer is connected to the Internet as well as its IP address and DHCP lease information.

Limited Internet connectivity that enables the initiation of the activation process. IP dialtone provides a client system access to a discrete set of external destinations, such as to the Activation Server. After the activation process is complete, the system has full Internet connectivity.
Faxing over an IP-based network. Similar to Internet telephony, in which the Internet can be used to transmit a voice, but optimized for faxing.
A framework for Internet Protocol (IP) multimedia services which uses Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) protocols such as Session Initiation Protocol (SIP).
Hardware lines over which devices can send signals to the microprocessor. When a new device is added to a computer, its IRQ number has to be set to specify which interrupt line the device may use.
An organization that provides Internet access and related Internet services.

A system in a call center that typically is used as a front end to an ACD system to improve call routing. In such a setup, an IVR system prompts the caller for information about the problem, which signals the ACD to route the caller to a CSR whose specialty is handling that type of service request.

An object-oriented programming language that is similar to C++ but easier to use and more portable. Sun Microsystems developed Java as a language that can be used to create complete applications that may run on a single computer or in a distributed network of clients and servers.

An SMP extension consisting of a single Java method that is programmed to execute some type of operation. A JSO provides an advanced alternative to creating a traditional service operation with an overlay and the model on which the overlay is built.
A measure of data speed equal to the number of 1000 bits of data transmitted or received each second. For example, a transmission of 450 Kbps is 450,000 bits per second.
A measure of data speed equal to the number of 1000 bytes of data transmitted or received each second. For example, a transmission of 50 KBps is 50,000 bytes per second.
A word or phrase applied to content by content authors and used to conduct sorting and searching operations.

The steps required to deploy a software application and its supporting documentation and packaging for specific target languages and locales. The goal of localization is to create an application that appears custom fit to the culture and linguistic background of the subscriber.

Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol. A protocol that creates virtual private networks over the Internet. L2TP supports non-IP protocols such as AppleTalk and IPX as well as the IPSec security protocol. L2TP is a combination of Microsoft Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol and Cisco Layer 2 Forwarding (L2F) technology.
According to Newton's Telecom Dictionary, L2TP can be used as a method for providing secure, high-priority, temporary paths through the Internet.
A network of interconnected computers and other devices within a relatively small geographic area. The computers on a LAN can interact with each other.

This is a TR-064 service that enables the ability to set the password that will allow a device to be configured via the xml interface. There is one instance of this service for a given CPE device. This service is required for all CPE devices adhering to this specification.

This is a TR-064 service that models an Ethernet LAN connection on an IGD device. This service allows for the determination and modification of basic configuration information. This service must be implemented for IGDs that contain an Ethernet interface on the LAN side.

This is a TR-064 service that enables reporting of LAN-related device information and setting and configuring LAN IP addressing. This test is required for all devices except for simple bridges that do not include a DHCP server.

This is a TR-064 service that models a USB connection on an IGD device. This service allows for the determination and modification of basic configuration information. This service must be implemented for IGDs that contain an USB interface on the LAN side.

The connection between the customer and the telephone or cable company. Traditionally, the last mile was made up of copper-based telephone wire or coaxial cable, but wireless technology provides alternative options in some areas.

The geographic region set up to differentiate local and long distance telephone calls within the United States. Telephone calls among parties within a LATA (intraLATA) are handled by the local telephone companies under the jurisdiction of each state public utility commission. Calls between LATAs are handled by interexchange carriers (IXCs) under the jurisdiction of the FCC.
This is a TR-064 service that allows handling of the routing and forwarding configuration of a device. This service is required if the device supports multiple connections.

A software protocol designed to locate resources such as files and devices in a network on the Internet or on a corporate intranet. LDAP is a lightweight version of Directory Access Protocol (DAP), which is part of X.500, a standard for directory services in a network. LDAP is lighter because it did not include security features in its initial version.

LDAP originated at the University of Michigan and has been endorsed by at least 40 companies. Netscape includes it in its latest Communicator suite of products. Microsoft includes it as part of what it calls Active Directory in a number of products including Outlook Express. Novell's NetWare Directory Services interoperates with LDAP. Cisco also supports it in its networking products.
Source: whatis?com.
Technical support offered to subscribers. Usually, the service providers (Motive customers) provide this level of support. Use the term level 2 support to describe the support Motive provides BSPs.

Technical support offered to service providers. Motive offers level 2 support for its products; that is, we support only service providers. At Motive, sometimes the term level 1 support is used erroneously. Motive provides support to the service provider, and the appropriate term is level 2 support.

Fixed radio wireless technology. A digital wireless transmission system that works at about 28 GHz in the United States and about 24 to 40 GHz overseas. LMDS requires line of sight, from one to four miles depending on weather conditions, between the transmitter and the receiving antenna. LMDS is designed to provide the last mile from a data service carrier to a complex that is not wired for high-bandwidth communications. In areas without underground conduits, it is less expensive to set up LMDS transceivers than to go underground to install optical fiber.

A language plus culture. For example, there are several types of English, including U.S. English, U.K. English, and World English. Each of these types of English are English, but they are not exactly the same. One language can be spoken in many geographical locations, and a geographical area can have several languages and thus several locales.
The directory in which a Studio user works on files.

An event on the server that is logged. Most Activation Server services have associated log events. Each possible log event has an associated log message and is assigned one of the following severity levels in order from most severe to least: Critical, Error, Warning, and Information.
A description of the occurrence of a single log event.

The shared cable or DSL circuit that runs from the cable or telco central office to a group of subscribers and back again. In cable technology, the more subscribers on a loop, the slower the Internet connection may become.
A unique number that identifies a piece of hardware on a network. For example: 00-16-17-2C-3F-E4

On an activation host, a servlet that implements a management protocol that enables the servlet to respond to management operations (such as start and stop) from an administrative console. Unmanaged services cannot respond to management operations; instead, they can only respond to the main application functionality (for example, profile creation or updates) that the service implements.

Functionality that enables your deployment to implement different settings for different groups of prospective subscribers. Content authors create settings and manage them through the Managed Settings perspective in the Motive Workbench.
The browser-based interface for managing Motive servers and users and for generating incident and system usage reports.

This is a TR-064 service that allows configuration of a management server URL to establish the communication between a CPE device and a management server using the CPE WAN Management Protocol (CWMP) as currently defined in TR-069. This management server is also known as an Auto-Configuration Server (ACS).
URL for a CPE (customer premises equipment) device to connect to an Auto-configuration Server (ACS) server using the CPE WAN management protocol (TR-069).
A baseline list of files and values used as part of profilers and check actions that defines the state of a system component installed on a computer.

A Workflow Editor-related term. A shape in the stencil. When the user drags a master onto the workflow drawing, the Workflow Editor creates an instance of the master. The user can configure each instance independently.
In a Nokia Deployment Automation Framework (DAF) installation, the main controlling server, which contains an Open Source Puppet installation, and uses Puppet to manage the configurations of clients.
A Workflow Editor-related term.The workflow in which the extension workflow loads.
A measure of data speed equal to the number of one million bits of data transmitted or received each second. For example, a transmission of 5 Mbps is 5 million bits per second.
A measure of data speed equal to the number of one million bytes of data transmitted or received each second. For example, a transmission of 5 MBps is 5 million bytes per second.
A device that brings media such as video and audio from a remote location to another media center (television and/or stereo) over a wired or wireless IP (Internet Protocol) network.

Server that routes inputs from other infrastructure components to the appropriate back end or OSS component. The mediation server translates the raw data output of other components into a format that the back end or OSS components understand. Adapters are often written to run on these servers.
Time Warner version of CorrectConnect. The formal name is Road Runner Medic.
File that contains the keys and associated values for labels and messages. The purpose of a message catalog is to provide a mechanism for customizing or localizing content.
The Insight utility that enables CSRs to exchange messages with subscribers and other CSRs in a workgroup about specific incidents.
In Studio, an HTML element that is used to provide information about a document, such as indexing parameters.

Fixed microwave wireless technology. MMDS is a method for distributing cable television signals, through microwave, from a single transmission point to multiple receiving points. In an MMDS, the microwave signal is received by an antenna on top of the subscriber home; then, the signal is sent down coaxial cable to a device on the television set. This device decodes and decompresses the digital signal. Limitations of MMDS transmissions are the terrain and foliage in and around the installation area.
MMDS also is known as wireless cable and multipoint multichannel distribution service.

A device or program that enables a computer or other digital device to transmit data over analog lines. A modem converts outgoing digital data to analog so it can be transmitted over analog lines, and it converts incoming analog data to digital.

A set of preferences that defines how the Monitor service interacts with a service that is being monitored. These preferences define the exact request sent to the service and the response expected from the service as a result of that request. The Monitor service uses this response to determine the service status, and reports success or failure to a monitoring tool when requested.
Note that if a service can receive requests of different types, it may have multiple monitors (for example, Client Update and Client Update Acknowledgment).

A service that provides a standardized and centralized view of activation service status. Depending on its configuration, the service can enable monitoring services on local hosts and other hosts in the segment.

The aggregate hardware and software that enables providing support services to subscribers. Typically, the Motive environment includes a firewall, load balancers, and some number of dedicated hosts, depending on the number of clients supported.
The repository where Motive setup information, activation data, service request data, usage statistics, and other important data are stored.

A reference implementation support site for subscribers. The Motive Support Portal browser-based interface includes workflows for subscriber systems to register with the Motive deployment, execute automatic telemetry submission, run one-click fixes, and escalate problem resolution, depending on the product deployment. Typically, the Motive Support Portal workflows are customized as needed and then integrated into the provider's branded portal.

An Eclipse-based tool for authoring and activating managed settings. The settings defined using the Managed Settings perspective of Motive Workbench are key to providing effective self-service and assisted service.
The Redback messaging service that pushes messages to the agent.
A Motive HTTP-based protocol in which payload is encrypted. In Motive software products, MOTMSG is used for non-SSL communications, by default on port 2112.
The first document written by marketing to provide an overview about what products the market needs.
A company that operates more than one cable television system.
An XML-based standard that enables varied OSS (operations support systems) to communicate with one another.

The largest packet or frame that can be sent in a packet-based or frame-based network (such as a network using TCP/IP). MTUs are expressed in eight-bit bytes. MTUs that are too large can cause retransmissions when packets encounter a router that cannot handle a packet of that size. MTUs that are too small can cause packets to use more header overhead and acknowledgments than necessary.

The business requirements of supporting service activation for multiple ISPs. Supporting multiple ISPs means providers can conduct the ordering, provisioning (such as CPE and network settings), and installation processes efficiently.
Motive software that enables dial-up service providers to reduce costs and improve customer satisfaction by automating subscriber service and support.

Client software that subscribers use to answer questions and resolve problems while setting up or using online services over a narrowband connection. Narrowband Technician can be installed directly from a CD or downloaded from a support web site.

Translation of an IP address used within one network to a unique IP address known within another network. One network is designated the inside network and the other is the outside. Typically, companies map their local inside network addresses to one or more global outside IP addresses and unmap the global IP addresses on incoming packets back into local IP addresses. This helps ensure security because each outgoing or incoming request must go through a translation process that also offers the opportunity to qualify or authenticate the request or match it to a previous request. Also, NAT conserves the number of global IP addresses that companies need; it lets companies use a single IP address in its communication with the world.

Software that enables the process of translating the IP addresses used within an intranet or other private network and Internet IP addresses. The NAT process permits a larger number of addresses within the inner network without exhausting the limited number of available numeric IP addresses.

A column or columns that uniquely identify a record in a database table in another schema by referring to its primary key. A natural key in a table in a reporting schema might refer to the primary key of the source table in the OLTP schema.

For an Oracle client, an alias to the connect descriptor (host name, port number, and service name or SID) for a database. The mapping of the net service name to the connect descriptor may be stored in the Oracle tnsnames.ora file or in a centralized directory. Use the Oracle Net Configuration Assistant or the Oracle Net Manager installed with the Oracle client to configure net service names.
A group of computers and other devices, such as printers, interconnected through communication links.

Workflow functionality that performs communication with back-end systems in the provider network. In a self-activation scenario, this communication can enable autoprovisioning of billing and email accounts, association of service with a subscriber account, and registration of cable modems.

An expansion card or other hardware device used to connect a computer to a local area network (LAN). The network adapter can be a network interface card ( NIC) that provides a computer with a dedicated connection to a network such as the Internet.

Microsoft Windows Vista introduces the concept of network location, which automatically sets the appropriate firewall settings for the type of network that the computer is connecting to. There are three choices for network location: home, work, or public place. The home and work settings are for networks where you know and trust other computers on the network. The public place setting is for a network such as an airport or coffee shop where it is safest to keep the computer hidden from other computers around you.

A server application designed to use an algorithm to optimally choose the next best action based on which solutions were successful in the past and on how long it took those solutions to complete. The selection process, referred to as historical machine learning, occurs during execution of dynamic intelligent workflows. The NBA Engine, which is not part of the standard SMP feature set, can shorten resolution times across a customer base.

An expansion board on a computer that enables the computer to be connected to a network. Most NICs are designed for a particular type of network, protocol, and medium, although some can serve multiple networks.
A grey box, typically located on the side of a house, that provides an interface to the telephone system.
In Insight, a prompt that is used to inform CSRs about changes of state occurring within their assigned incidents.
Any kind of RAM (random access memory) that does not lose its data when the device's power is off.

An ID that uniquely identifies a row (record) in a database table. More generally, an OID uniquely identifies an object (in the object-oriented programming sense of the word) and maps to a primary key in a relational database representation of that object. OIDs are generated by a globally unique identifier (GUID) generator.
A database schema optimized for real-time business operations. OLTP schemas are typically highly normalized and designed to support a large number of concurrent users.

Self-service workflows accessible from different Motive clients and workflows on a provider portal. Subscribers run one-click fixes to solve a problem or complete a task on their systems. One-click fixes are designed for relatively quick execution. For example, subscribers can use one-click fixes to reset their browser home page, change their default mail account, create an email account, or run an email test.

Applications and services provided over closed IP networks rather than through Internet Web sites. By providing on-net content, companies secure tighter control over their relationship with subscribers, and they can guarantee that bandwidth is available to provide that content.
A means for subscribers to choose from among multiple ISPs. Typically, the term open access is used only in the context of cable technology.
Also known as managed access. Use the term open access instead.

The exact values that the provider deems optimal for the hardware and software settings on a prospective subscriber system. Usually, providers define optimal values for a subset of the telemetry values to be collected. By comparing optimal values with the actual values, self-service workflows and assisted service CSR tools can expose data for accelerated diagnosis and resolution.
writeronly Note: once SmartCare CSR Console is available (not as of Q2), replace Insight with this in the second sentence above.

Software designed to control the hardware of a general-purpose computer or other device. Computers must have an operating system to run other programs. Operating systems perform basic tasks such as recognizing input from the keyboard, sending output to the display screen, keeping track of files and directories on the disk, and controlling peripheral devices (disk drives and printers).
The back-end systems used by service providers to manage, monitor, provision, and guarantee the quality of network services (for example, order processing, line testing, and billing).
Not automated. For example, ordering a service over the telephone instead of using a computer to order the service is an out-of-band service.
A piece of data transmitted from one device to another on a network.
The gateway between the Internet and the WLAN in a femtocell deployment.
A Workflow Editor-related term.A user interface in which the workflow continues without action from the user.
A unique string of characters that a user types to confirm identity and access a system.
A link between two nodes in a network. A path also is the series of folders or subdirectories used to describe the location of a file, folder, or subdirectory in a file system.

Refers to subscriber-related service offers billed on usage rather than on a subscription basis. Usage typically is based on discrete events such as viewing a movie for $5.00, regardless of whether the subscriber watches the movie in its entirety or only half the movie. Pay per use also could be based on time used or packets transferred.
Similar to the term pay-per-view. Use the term pay-per-use instead because pay-per-view includes media that are not viewable such as streaming audio.
Cable television service offer that allows subscribers to view special programming for an additional charge.
Use the term pay per use instead of pay per view.
The repository of entries in Dial-Up Networking (DUN). Each phonebook entry corresponds to a specific number or network.
Virtual channel through which subscribers resolve service issues by using the phone call. The phone channel supports self-service and assisted service, depending on the deployment.
The voice XML (VXML) interface of the phone channel that enables subscribers to interact with the Motive environment through the phone.
Virtual solution through which subscribers resolve service issues by using a phone call. The phone integration supports self-service and assisted service, depending on the deployment.
The voice XML (VXML) interface of the phone integration that enables subscribers to interact with the Motive environment through the phone.
The protocol for testing if a particular computer is connected to the Internet by sending a packet to its IP address and waiting for a response.

An application designed to plug into a larger application to provide additional functionality. Also, a plug-in can be an application that works inside another application to provide specific functionality. For example, RealNetwork RealPlayer and Apple QuickTime have plug-ins for most web browsers so consumers can play video and audio segments through web browsers.
A subflow for inclusion as a step in an interactive workflow. A PoF can have zero or one entry, one or more remediation tasks, and exactly one exit.
The number of seconds after polling a given service or file that a consumer service is set to wait before polling again.

An access point to the Internet. A POP has a unique IP address. ISPs have a POP on the Internet and often several POPs. Usually, a POP consists of routers, digital/analog call aggregators, servers, and sometimes frame relay or ATM switches.
A server that uses POP to receive, store, and send email for clients. A subscriber computer connects to the POP server to download and upload email.

A method for running a server behind a firewall in which typically only a single port (or small series of ports) is exposed to the Internet. Port forwarding enables running several server types from different computers on your LAN. Many broadband routers include interfaces for configuring port forwarding for standard applications such as FTP, WWW, and Mail.

Category of workflow functionality that runs on a subscriber computer after the system establishes connection with the provider network. For example, network activation and computer activation are postconnectivity functionality.

Protocol that enables a computer to establish one or several connections to multiple servers. PPP inherently supports user authentication, which is appealing to providers for billing and provisioning.

Protocol that supports PPP using an ATM NIC and protocol stack in the computer. Because of the relative lack of knowledge and support for ATM in the consumer environment, PPPoA is less common than PPPoE.
Protocol that supports PPP using an Ethernet NIC (connected to the broadband modem) and protocol stacks in the computer.
Document written by Product Management in response to the MRD. This document provides the overview and requirements of a new product.
Category of workflow functionality that runs on a subscriber computer before the system establishes connection with the provider network. For example, basic access is preconnectivity functionality.
One or more columns that, taken together, uniquely identify a record in a database table.
A computer or device providing access to a printer over a network.
The urgency of an assisted service request. This value is configurable based on elements of the incoming service request.
The permission to perform specific tasks and view specific information.
Also, a task that can be performed within Motive software. Privileges are assigned to specific user roles.
The main focus of a subscriber problem, as defined by the subscriber from a configured list when submitting an assisted service request.
In Studio, a content type that lists the step-by-step instructions for performing a multi-step task.
Refers to a client, server, or a combination of client and server modules that are part of a solution.
Generally, when a customer is on an upgrade path, products are sold individually.
Compare with solution.
In Studio, an action that restores a corrupt application or system component to a working state.
A set of standardized rules designed to enable computers to exchange information.

The BSP's (broadband service provider's) branded subscriber support Web site that integrates elements from the Motive Support Portal. From the provider portal, subscribers can execute automatic telemetry submission and to run self-service workflows and one-click fixes on their systems.
The Studio process for combining problem-resolution content with HTML-formatted templates to create a service site.
Quality of service.
An area where calls and incidents are held based on routing instructions until a resource is available.

A type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly; that is, any byte of memory can be accessed without touching the preceding bytes. RAM is the most common type of memory found in computers and other devices such as printers.

Windows software that enables users to gain remote access to the network server through a modem. On Windows NT systems, RAS is the interface into Dial-Up Networking (DUN). Before setting up a DUN connection, a computer must have RAS installed and configured.

A description of the ability to interact with applications and systems to perform changes or actions as quickly as possible depending on network latency, bandwidth restraints, and other variables that cannot be controlled. In this context, real time does not mean instantaneously; instead, it refers to a best-effort approach.
A field or a group of related fields that store data.
An implementation of a solution, system, or component included with a product to give a sample deployment for easy learning and to provide the most commonly desired customizations for faster setup.
A standardized workflow. Reference workflows can be configured, branded, and updated for deployment to the customer subscriber base.

The capability for CSRs to access and work on a subscriber desktop to resolve service issues from the Motive environment. To establish a remote control connection, the subscriber must explicitly permit the CSR access.
A data set that provides information about the software, such as performance and usage statistics or ROI.
The Motive server user interface that displays reports from the Motive Data Mart in the Crystal Reports Server.

Note: This term has been deprecated as of the 4.13.3 release of the Data Mart.The optional Motive software server component that enables the Management Console to display reports generated by Crystal Enterprise Server. The Crystal Enterprise Server generates reports from the Motive Data Mart and the activation reporting schema.

A residential gateway is a device that connects a home network to a wide area network (the Internet). A residential gateway allows multiple computers to share a single internet connection and typically provides a NAT (Network Address Translation) firewall.
A service site that enables CSRs to research solutions for subscriber system problems.

A file used to store the responses to installer prompts for use when running the installer in non-interactive mode. For example, when installing Solaris packages, you can generate a response file using the pkgask command and install the package using pkgadd -r response-file.txt.
