The three primary colors used in video processing. RGB is a color model based on the mixing of red, green, and bluethe primary additive colors used by color monitor displays. The combination and intensities of these three colors can represent the whole spectrum.
A Java protocol in which one method in a network can contact another method in that network without knowing network details.
Time Warner broadband cable service.
A group of privileges that define the set of tasks a Motive software user can perform.

Device performing minimal data filtering that connects networks to steer traffic from one network to its destination network. There may be an arbitrary number of routers (and therefore networks) between any two hosts that are trying to communicate.
A protocol that enables one server in a network to request a service from another server without having to understand network details.

RPM Package Manager is a package management system with a particular storage format for software distributions. RPM can refer to the .rpm file format, files in that format, software packaged in .rpm files, or the package manager program itself. The RPM format was created originally for the Red Hat Linux operating system, but is now used more widely, even on non-Linux operating systems.
In Studio, a content type that runs actions automatically when subscribers select and open it.

Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP) is a TCP-based certificate enrollment protocol. The goal of SCEP is to support the secure issuance of certificates to network devices in a scalable manner, using existing technology whenever possible.
The CTI functionality that causes caller telemetry to appear (or pop) automatically for a CSR using phone channel.

The virtual boundary around a single activation deployment. The activation environment and subscriber computers that interact with the server in this environment are inside this boundary. Clients and servers within a segment cannot interact with the clients and servers in another segment.
Type of service in which a subscriber uses Motive software to resolve a problem without interacting with a CSR.

An service request that is resolved by a subscriber who views static content pages, active content pages, and service alerts (on pages other than the top-level home page), but does not attempt to contact a CSR.
A workflow that runs on the subscriber system to troubleshoot a specific problem such as resetting email configuration.

User interface that can be removed from the underlying software. For example, Virtual Truck Agent has a separable UI, which allows the application to be offered with or without a window into the agent.
In the activation environment, a software process that runs on a host and provides one or more services.
In the activation environment, Apache and Tomcat are examples of servers, while Client Update, SPM, and Registration are examples of services.
In the Motive environment, servers are the distributed instances of a web server on which Motive server components are installed.
A program designed for installation on a server host (such as an activation host) that provides server functionality for other programs that run on or connect to that host.
A configuration setting in the Motive server application that determines how the application functions.

For example, when using the Service Center Console to help manage operations in your service center, the designated start time for a 24-hour period and the time interval between database queries are configured through Motive server properties.
The categories of servers that run in a Motive software environment.

In a client/server architecture, a program or activity that provides support to other programs, generally at a low (close to the hardware) level. In addition, a service can be an Internet channel provided by an ISP. The service could be an entry point to the Internet or a content-specific channel.
Electronic notifications for subscribers about possible errors or recommended user actions. Service alerts can target these alerts for particular user configurations and activity.

Functionality that uses SmartBridge technology for the delivery of service alerts to subscribers. Server administrators create service alerts and configure filtering for them through the Management Console. The filtering enables providers to target service alerts to subscribers with specific user configurations.
To download and save the alerts for contextual display, the subscriber system must run Broadband Technician with SmartBridge.

A Motive Expert Service that exploits the wealth of operational and marketing data through advanced reporting and data warehousing/ Data Mart solutions for strategic reporting, analysis, and planning.

A type of service alert that provides information to subscribers about their service. Service bulletins are created with built-in filtering based on criteria such as locale, operating system, and phone number, depending on the configuration. Service bulletins are not associated with specific applications.
The browser-based interface that service center managers use to monitor CSR activity, incident activity, and queues.
Context-driven content that is authored in Studio and published to the Content server. All service content is presented to subscribers in Broadband Technician for Windows.
glossdef.remark: commenting this out while AnswerWeb is not part of the product as of Mont Blanc

glossdef.para: A type of service alert that is associated with a specific application. The delivery of the event is triggered by subscriber action in the specified application. Similar to service bulletins, service events are created with built-in filtering based on criteria such locale, operating system, and phone number, depending on the configuration. In addition, Outlook Express events can be associated with specific OE error numbers.

A Motive Expert Service that delivers integration solutions for the seamless flow of service information across enterprise systems and devices, including provisioning, CRM, knowledgebase, and OSS systems, as well as customer technology systems.
Statistics generated from the Motive Data Mart that provide a high level view of the provider's ROI from Motive solutions.

The name of an Oracle database as defined on the database host. On an Oracle client, a net service name maps to a service name, host name, port number, and protocol for a database. How this mapping is achieved depends on the naming method being used, but often the information is stored in the tnsnames.ora and configured using the Oracle Net Configuration Assistant or the Oracle Net Manager.
The technology platform on which products in the Motive software environment are built.
A configuration that a client or an SMP API requests to execute a specific overlay, Java service operation (JSO), or Node-RED flow.
A subscriber's attempt to resolve an issue using through self-service or assisted service using Motive software.
A future Motive product that will be a subscriber interface to provider applications and services.
A set of web pages that enables Subscribers to research and resolve their own issues as well as request assistance from CSRs, or that enables CSRs to research and resolve issues.
A web program that generates dynamic content in response to client requests received. Servlets are platform-independent Java classes that can be loaded dynamically into and run by a web server.

A container that manages servlets. The servlet engine, in conjunction with a web server, provides the network services over which requests and responses are processed. Servlet engines must support Hypertext Transfer Protocol ( HTTP) as a protocol for requests and responses, but may also support additional protocols such as HTTPS (HTTP over SSL).
For example, Tomcat is a servlet engine.
An active connection between a CSR using Insight and a Motive server.
A protocol that establishes and ends sessions for multimedia communication such as voice calls over the Internet.

A term related to the Managed Settings perspective in the Motive Workbench. A setting defines the subscriber system telemetry that is significant for a particular subscriber group. A setting determines the following: hardware, software, and CPE attributes to collect from a subscriber system and those to set; how to group the values for display in the CSR Console; values expected; values to encode in the diagnostic code; optimal or acceptable values for a subset of the expected values.
The measure of how critical an assisted service request is, as defined by the subscriber.
Functionality for silent installations that uses a single icon to launch an electronic channel Windows broadband or narrowband client. This option is enabled during the client configuration process.
A file that contains links to Studio documents, actions, and templates and is required to publish a Motive service site.
A set of graphics and text that can replace the default look and feel of a graphical user interface.
For example, Time Warner added a Road Runner skin to the CorrectConnect interface to produce Medic.

Motive client technology that regularly polls the specified server to download any new service alerts. The SmartBridge component also maintains subscriber context to control the delivery of alerts. commenting this out while AnswerWeb is not part of the product as of Mont Blanc
Short message posting.
Subscriber Management System (Redback).
A TCP/IP protocol for sending messages from one computer to another on a network. SMTP routes email.
The protocol that governs network management and the monitoring of network devices and their functions. SNMP is not limited to TCP/IP networks.
A software application used to make telephone calls via the Internet, using a computer instead of telephone hardware; a softphone is a form of VoIP (voice over IP).
A combination of client and server products designed to solve an issue or set of issues that customers face.
Generally, the sales team focuses on selling solutions, not products.
Compare with product.
In Studio, a content type that contains written descriptions of processes for diagnosing specific hardware or software problems and the corresponding actions to resolve them.
A secure Internet communication protocol.

A data model organized into dimension tables that relate to one or more central fact tables to facilitate reporting. A snowflake schema is similar to a star schema except that the dimension tables are subdivided into separate tables. This increases the normalization, but increases the complexity of the design and can affect performance.
A Studio document without attached interactive components.
An IP address that is assigned manually and does not change.

A Java application that facilitates inserting data into the Motive System. The narrowband clients must be enabled to access a statistics servlet to insert data into the Motive System. Some systems may have this enabled, but the properties should be reviewed to ensure the syntax is correct.
A Workflow Editor-related term.The area on the left side of the Workflow Editor screen (default) that displays the available work node.
The Motive product used to build and publish service sites.

A method used in word processing, desktop publishing, and web development to globally define the physical appearance of a document or document set, including its default typefaces, colors, margins, and other layout attributes. Style sheets often include any standard content to be included on particular pages (for example, company identification).

A portion of a network that shares a common address component. Subnet masks are used to help organize IP networks. In TCP/IP networks, subnets are defined as all devices with the same prefix in their IP addresses. For example, all devices with IP addresses that start with 100.100.100 are considered part of the same subnet. Dividing a network into subnets is useful for both security and performance reasons.
A screen of numbers that indicates which parts of an IP address can be ignored for devices on the same subnet.
In industry usage, an individual who pays for Internet access or other services from a provider.
In Motive usage, an end-user who uses Motive software as a result of purchasing services from a provider.

Attributes used to indicate in which scenario a service alert is relevant to a subscriber. The default attributes of subscriber context include the relevant geographical area, operating system, and application running.
The practice of paying for a product on a regular interval, such as once per month instead of all at once.

A logical grouping in a database of tables and indexes corresponding to one or more database files. Tablespaces allow the database administrator (DBA) to organize the tables and indexes in a database for stability and efficiency. For example, putting a storage quota on a particular tablespace prevents the size of the tables in that tablespace from affecting other more important tables in the database.
The intended subscribers of the Motive software environment.
On Windows 95 or later, the bar that appears on the bottom of the desktop (by default) and contains the Start menu. The taskbar displays an icon for each program that is currently open.
The protocol or set of rules that computers on the Internet use to communicate.

Diagnostic data gathered from a subscriber system or backend system. For example, the amount of disk space is telemetry collected from the subscriber system, and outage status is telemetry collected from a backend system. Telemetry is the primary data source used to solve problems in the self-service and assisted service models.

The Insight desktop utility that enables CSRs to view diagnostic data gathered about subscriber computing environments. This data may include information about component configuration, network connectivity, email access, server name, Internet Web browsers, and access speed.
Software that enables telemetry to be gathered from a third-party system such as an outage, provisioning, or billing database.
The Motive software server component that handles telemetry requests to third-party systems such as provisioning or outage databases.
A Studio file that is used to process content and present it to subscribers who access a Motive service site. Motive templates control the look and feel of HTML-formatted pages and content types.

Server software that enables the activation host to interface with third-party offer systems such as billing, network provisioning, and content provisioning systems. Using an API, the third-party integration layer hooks into selected third-party systems. Then the integration layer abstracts the data and initiates an appropriate, predefined workflow. Motive writes a custom integration adapter for each third-party system with which it needs activation hosts to interface.
The process of moving information through an organization.

Open-source server software that Activation Server uses as its servlet engine. Tomcat contains activation servlets that generate responses dynamically based on the client requests forwarded from Apache.
The sum of self-service requests and assisted-service requests.

Industry configuration specification for LAN-side DSL CPE devices. Built on top of the UPnP device architecture, the TR-064 protocol describes the protocol stack, discovery, security, and XML structure to be used to configure, manage, and operate LAN-side DSL CPE devices. See the DSL Forum web site for a copy of the TR-064 specification.
bjinternal A Motive Expert Service that provides turnkey activation services encompassing product configuration and quality assurance for initial and ongoing deployments.
User interface.
An open incident that is not currently assigned to a CSR.
In Studio, a content type that contains the written instructions and URLs for file downloads that fix or prevent problems.

A standard architecture that uses Internet and web protocols to enable devices such as computers, peripherals, intelligent appliances, and wireless devices to be plugged into a network and automatically know about each other. With UPnP, when a user plugs a device into the network, the device configures itself, acquires a TCP/IP address, and uses a discovery protocol based on HTTP to declare its existence on the network to other devices.

Some key characteristics of UPnP are: (1) No device drivers are used; common protocols are used instead. (2) UPnP is media independent; it can be implemented using any programming language and on any operating system. (3) No constraints are placed on the design of an API for applications; this enables vendor control over device user interface and interaction using the browser and conventional application programmatic control.
An address for a resource, typically a web page, on the Internet. Web browsers use URLs to locate Internet resources. For example, http://www.motive.com is the URL for the Motive, Inc. Web site.
A port on a computer for connecting peripherals such as printers, digital cameras, keyboards, network adapters and so on.

The series of interactions between people and systems that make up the processes that achieve a business goal. Qualification and installation are common use cases. For example, the qualification use case refers to the process and requirements of prequalifying consumers for service.
Any person with access to a system. Users are authenticated and have an assigned role within the system.

Reference to the entire interaction between a user and a software application, including the navigation, display of feedback and status, textual content, and aesthetic look and feel. A good user experience should seamlessly merge technology, graphics, layout, and text into an intuitive, simple interaction.

The process of offering subscribers compelling content and applications on top of basic broadband access. The objective of incorporating value-added service offers into the activation process is to maximize the value of an access package and increase the average revenue per subscriber.

A unique ID (also referred to as AppKey parameter) that is created and required when installing the Motive server to support multiple subscriber solutions or to support multiple operating systems. TODO: Check if this needs to be updated.
The Studio file management component that enables file checkout and checkin to a central repository.
Broadband telephony that enables making telephone calls through the Internet.
Video on demand.
The telephony hardware that interprets VXML generated by Motive voice service. The voice gateway guides the subscriber through an information-gathering workflow.

The Motive software server component that processes data associated with requests from a voice gateway or IVR for voice content. The Voice server hosts and server the deplpoyment-specific VXML-formatted content.
IP telephony that enables making telephone calls through the Internet.

A set of nodes on a public network that communicate among themselves using encryption technology so that their data is protected from unauthorized users as if the nodes were connected by private lines.
Markup language for technologies that allow a user to interact with Web services though a voice browser (telephone). The user listens to audio output and responds in a natural speaking voice.
A computer network that spans a relatively large geographical area. Typically, a WAN consists of two or more local area networks (LANs).
This is a standard UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) service that models WAN interface properties common across all connection services instances. This service is also part of the TR-064 protocol.

This TR-064 service models physical layer properties specific to a single physical connection of a DSL modem used for Internet access on an IGD. This service is required for an IGD with a DSL modem WAN interface, and is exclusive of any other WAN***InterfaceConfig service within a given WANDevice. The allowed values of the ModulationType state variable must reflect the supported modulation types of the device.

This is a standard UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) service that is also incorporated in the TR-064 protocol. This service models the ATM link layer properties specific to a single physical connection of a DSL modem used for Internet access on an IGD.
This service is required for an IGD with a DSL modem WAN interface.

This TR-064 service models physical layer properties specific to a single physical Ethernet connection of an RGW (residential gateway) used for Internet access on an IGD. This service is required for an IGD with an Ethernet WAN interface.

This is a standard UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) service that is also incorporated in the TR-064 protocol. This service models Ethernet link layer properties specific to a single physical Ethernet connection of a GW used for Internet access on an IGD (Internet Gateway Device). This service is required for an IGD with an Ethernet WAN interface.

This is a standard UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) service that that is also incorporated in the TR-064 protocol. This service enables a UPnP control point to configure and control IP connections on the WAN interface of a UPnP compliant IGD (Internet Gateway Device). This service is required for all WANConnection Devices not employing PPP addressing. This service must NOT be active for WANConnection Devices that do employ PPP addressing.

This is a standard UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) service that that is also incorporated in the TR-064 protocol. This service enables a UPnP control point to configure and control PPP connections on the WAN interface of a UPnP compliant IGD. This service is required if the WANConnection Device employs PPP connections. This service must NOT be active if the WANConnection Device does not support PPP connections.

A workflow that is deployed on a Motive server. Subscriber computers connect with the web server to access the workflow that executes tasks on the client and the server. For example, the web-based workflow may collect hardware and system data and configure email settings on the client while it commits the data collected to the database on the server. In an autoprovisioning scenario, the web-based workflow communicates with a back-end system in the provider network.
An application that is used to view HTML files and other Web content. Examples of web browsers are Internet Explorer, Netscape Navigator, and Opera.

A web site that uses two or more servers to handle user requests. A web farm is also known as a web server farm. A server farm is a group of computers acting as servers and housed together in a single location.

A server application that uses Hypertext Transfer Protocol ( HTTP) to serve the files that form web pages to clients such as a web browser. Examples of commonly used web servers are Apache and Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS).

Software that supports interoperable machine-to-machine interaction over a network. Other systems interact with the Web service's interface typically using XML over HTTP and other web standards. Applications written in different languages and running on various platforms can use web services to exchange data over networks like the Internet.
Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_services

The Web Services Description Language (WSDL) is an XML-based language for defining the interfaces of a service offered through the internet. A WSDL can also refer to a WSDL file, an XML file that adheres to the WSDL standard and describes a specific web service.

A system that determines the IP address associated with a particular network computer. WINS supports network client and server computers running Windows and can provide name resolution for other computers with special arrangements. Determining the IP address for a computer is a complex process when DHCP servers assign IP addresses dynamically. For example, it is possible for DHCP to assign a different IP address to a client each time the client logs on to the network. WINS uses a distributed database that is automatically updated with the names of computers currently available and the IP address assigned to each one.

A Workflow Editor-related term. A type of connection that is made up of an implied line between two work nodes. Wireless connections can connect to common destinations that several work nodes must connect to (such as an error message display) without having dynamic connectors for each. Or they can connect across pages of a workflow, or across workflows.

This service models an 802.11 LAN connection on a LAN device. This service allows for the determination and modification of basic configuration information. This TR-064 service must be implemented for IGDs that contain an IEEE 802.11 interface on the LAN side.

An automated series of steps that perform a process for the provider and subscriber. The workflow can be branded, configured, and updated. In workflows, programmers define inputs, outputs, rules, and the sequence of rules for each step that make up the workflow.
The Insight desktop interface element that lists the incidents assigned to or of interest to a CSR.

Industry configuration specification for LAN-side DSL CPE. The predecessor to TR-064 LAN-side DSL CPE protocol, WT-082 is the working text for the first draft of the TR-064 protocol. Some devices may support the WT-082 version of TR-064 which is not as comprehensive as full TR-064 support. See the DSL Forum website for a copy of the WT-082 specification.

A markup language that can be customized and is written in Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML). XML, which is designed to describe data rather than determine the format of data, can be used for the transfer of information through the web, intranets, and other applications.

A way to describe and validate data in an XML environment. This description is used to verify that each item of content in an XML document adheres to the description of the element in which the content is to be placed. (A schema is a model for describing the structure of information.)

A language for expressing style sheets to facilitate the transformation of XML documents and provide an XML vocabulary for specifying formatting semantics. For example, an XSL style sheet can determine how the data described in an XML document is presented in a web page. An XSL style sheet defines the presentation of a class of XML documents by describing how instances of the class are transformed into an XML document that uses the formatting vocabulary.

Language for transforming XML documents. XSLT is used to describe how to transform the source tree or data structure of an XML document into the result tree for a new XML document, which can be completely different in structure. XSLT programs are sometimes called stylesheets.
A data serialization notation with a concise syntax that allows you to store data in a human-readable format that can still be processed by software.

yum is an open-source package management utility for Linux operating systems that uses the .rpm file format. yum handles dependency management and automatic updates. It requires a repository, or collection of packages, accessed either locally or over a network connection, and uses the repository to satisfy dependencies.
A subscriber system that does not have an installation of the Broadband Technician.

An aggregate term for device access filters and user access filters. An access filter grants users privileges to operate on devices, the set of which is defined in a device access filter. Deprecated in HDM 3.0 (replaced by device group)

A service that stores and manages versions of configuration data for agents. ACS provides the functionality to target agent configuration deployment based on information in the subscriber profile. Also, it enables Control Panel users to view the status of agent configurations deployed across the segment.
An application that is installed on a subscriber computer. The application includes a workflow that activates broadband service.

Broadband service provider (BSP), operations-focused use cases that activation supports. The use cases are Qualification, Standard Activation, Regional CD, Conversion, Multiple ISP, and Self-Activation with autoprovisioning. The solution includes a reference workflow associated with each use case.
A module that centralizes server administration and client/server capabilities for enabling client/server communications, client updates and configurations, and managing services.
A generic term for a client application that runs on subscriber computers. An agent can, but does not always, have a user interface.

Also known as client and active agent. Use the term agent to refer to the software that runs on the subscriber computer from a CD. Use the term client to refer to the communication between the client and Motive servers.
The collection of data that characterizes an agent configuration, including the configuration data file, targeting filters, version, and other internal data.
The core of the agent software to which each agent plug-in connects. An agent harness is a subset of an agent.
The agent harness also is known as agent core. Use the term agent harness instead.
A system profile that describes an agent. There is an individual agent profile for each agent that runs on a subscriber computer.

A set of steps that activates service on a subscriber system. A workflow is made up of discrete functions that perform specific tasks, such as collecting information from a subscriber or configuring network settings on the subscriber computer.
In AnswerWeb Manager, a content type that is used to notify subscribers of issues that may immediately affect them.

Content created in AnswerWeb Manager to resolve subscriber questions. Answers are displayed Broadband Technician pages according to the current subscriber context when SmartBridge technology is enabled.
Knowledge base containing answer resources used in AnswerWeb.
A collective term for the answers, service alerts, experts, and mixins created by AnswerWeb Manager content authors in the Motive environment.
The intelligent question-answering infrastructure for the Motive environment, with a dynamic answerbase and processing system for delivering relevant answers in context.
An Insight desktop tool that content authors and managers use to create and maintain answer resources.

An Internet Explorer plug-in for the service management environment that allows authors to create answers in the context of a web page. The AnswerWeb Recorder stores the context of the web page currently displayed in the AnswerWeb answer that is created.

The Motive server component that provides an intelligent question-answering infrastructure with a dynamic answerbase and processing system. The AnswerWeb server also provides a querying system with connections to subject-matter experts who can answer questions from subscribers about business processes, tasks, and applications. In addition, AnswerWeb enables answers to be captured and stored in the answerbase for re-use in the same context.
An application-specific service that is installed onto the Activation Server through the installation of a server application.

A location the server assigns a subscriber computer based on the evaluation of a location registration rule. Typically, an assignment location is a location that is on the bottom-most location level such that it spans all location levels. For instance, if the defined location metadata is State.City.Department, an example of an assignment location is Texas, Austin, EastAustin.
A system profile that describes an audio device. There is an individual audio device profile for each audio device within a subscriber computer.
An action performed by a Control Panel user. Various functions executed through the Control Panel can generate audit events.

A service that provides audit trails of certain Control Panel user actions by creating audit event logs in the database. These logs provide an audit trail of certain Control Panel user actions that change activation data or that view sensitive data. Specifically, the audit logs identify the Control Panel administrator accounts used to perform certain operations and the dates the operations were performed.
A description of the occurrence of a single audit event.

Overall business requirements of integrating account/system provisioning into the self- activation process. In this use case, the subscriber computer communicates with back-end, provider systems to automate processes such as that of account creation, email account provisioning, association of service with a subscriber account, or cable modem registration. This automation accelerates deployment and generates significant cost savings for providers.

A queue-based, asynchronous XML communication package developed by Motive. A component of the foundation library, BMOM is a standard method for Motive clients and servers to contact and interact with each other.
This is an AMC term.
A Motive and Support.com end-to-end, joint solution that automates all aspects of subscriber assistance, from installation to ongoing support.

glossdef.remark: This is a deprecated defn from HSM,; the term was changed to policy to be more in line with HDM terminology
glossdef.para: A rule that defines a set of conditions (such as selection criteria), parameters (such as timeouts), and associated actions (such as install, start, stop, and uninstall) that can be performed on applications and deployment units on one or more service gateways at a time. If a service gateway meets the conditions of the parameters, then the specified actions for that rule are run on the gateway. A bulk operation continues to run against targeted gateways unless it expires according to the timeout configured in the bulk operation. Bulk operations run only on gateways that are currently enabled in Home Device Manager and not locked in Home Device Manager by an operator for manual operation.

glossdef.remark: This is a deprecated defn for ControlWorks.
glossdef.para: A short announcement about service status and updates. Bulletins are created in the Control Panel and can be targeted at specific locations and groups of clients through the use of location and system filters.

A special class in the bundle that, when its interface is implemented, allows the bundle to initialize (for example, registering services) when started, and to perform clean-up operations when stopped. The OSGi framework must instantiate this class and invoke the start and stop methods to start or stop the bundle respectively.

glossdef.remark: The term 'bundle container' is replaced by 'application' in HSM 2.0
glossdef.para: A logical grouping of bundles that corresponds to a subscriber-oriented application. Home Service Manager uses the notion of a bundle container, but this notion is not used by the service gateway.

A proxy to the underlying OSGi framework. The BundleContext object represents the execution context of a single bundle within the OSGi Service Platform. The framework creates a BundleContext object when a bundle is started.

A unique and persistent identifier of a bundle. Once its value is assigned to a bundle, that value is never reused for another bundle, even if the original bundle is reinstalled. Its value must not change when the bundle is updated, or as long as the bundle remains installed.

A file that describes the contents of the .jar file and provides information about the bundle. This file uses headers to specify parameters that the OSGi framework needs to correctly install and activate a bundle.

A Java object that manages the life cycle (installing, starting, stopping, updating and uninstalling) of a bundle through the management agent. For each bundle installed in the OSGi Service Platform, there is an associated bundle object.

An application service added to the activation environment by the SmartConnect server. The service enables the viewing of profile data collected by SmartConnect agents and implements behavior for actions such as querying the database for a set of results related to SmartConnect test report data. In addition, the service exposes functionality and configuration data for the Bulletin service in the Control Panel. This functionality includes the ability to publish bulletins, as well as to query and set the expiration date of active bulletins. CCServices interacts with other services in the Activation Server.

An application service added to the activation environment by the SmartConnect server. The service processes test report requests from SmartConnect agents and stores the test report data in the appropriate SmartConnect tables. CCUploadService interacts with other services in the Activation Server.

A use case available through subscription. The CD-based ChannelDirect use case refers to the process of adding compelling content and applications on top of basic broadband access. The objective of incorporating value-added service offers is to maximize the value of an access package and increase the average revenue per subscriber.
A menu on the Motive agent user interface that contains icons and that enables subscribers to use the modules or plug-ins.
The capability within Motive products to integrate the offering and fulfillment of value-added services into broadband activation processes.
ChannelDirect is not a product and is not an item on the price list. ChannelDirect is leveraged through the purchase of ChannelDirect offers.

A Motive solution that presents and fulfills a specific good or service through ChannelDirect capability integrated into an installation or qualification agent. Motive develops the ChannelDirect offer on behalf of a CAP or broadband access provider.
The production of a ChannelDirect offer requires two high-level development efforts on the part of Motive:

listitem.para: FoundationOn behalf of the value-added services provider, Motive develops core product functionality to encapsulate the offer for generic inclusion in agents. Work nodes must be designed, implemented, and unit-tested. All relevant operating systems, CPE, and other external systems must be supported.

WorkflowAfter the offer work nodes are developed, Motive must configure, customize, and integrate them into the unique fulfillment workflows of each broadband service provider ( BSP) that purchases the integration. This includes coordination of development efforts with the value-added services provider, customization for branding and BSP-specific functionality, and possible integration with relevant OSS in the BSP network. A quality assurance cycle also is a component in workflow development to ensure the product functions and is supported across relevant platforms.

glossdef.para: As products, ChannelDirect offers are on the price list.
Profiles that are children of other profiles in the profile hierarchy. For example, subscriber profiles and system profiles have children profiles.
A single file, such as a .zip file or a text file, that is downloaded and used by an activation workflow.

Files intended for activation software that runs on subscriber computers. The software can access client files based on server-rule evaluation. There are two types of client files: client workflows and client file packages.
The programming interface of the Motive Client Foundation that may become part of the Motive Software Developer's Kit (SDK).
The subscriber's system.
Use the term client computer, client system, client host, or subscriber computer instead.
Data files that update client and server software.
Also known as a patch. Do not use the term patch in customer-facing documentation. Use the term client update instead.

A directive to the Client Update service to determine whether the system matches the criteria for receiving a Motive software update notification. The directive contains logical expressions in prefix notation, modeled on LDAP search filters. These expressions specify rules that include or exclude subscriber computers based on profile attributes stored in the registry of the subscriber computer.

A service that enables the deployment of client updates to clients that already have the applicable agent installed. The Client Update service provides the functionality to target update deployment based on information in the subscriber profile and to view the status of updates deployed across the segment.

A .zip file that contains the code required to fulfill a client request such as installing service for a particular ISP. A client workflow can be absorbed and executed by an activation workflow on a client.
A service that supports the agent downloading of workflow.zip files required for fulfillment.
An individual, modular software routine that is compiled and ready to use with other components or programs.

Any given logic within a shared library that can be deployed without concern for its binary representation (that is, without concern that its deployment will affect the executable into which the component is compiled). By using this modular approach, new and existing components can be created, enhanced, and deployed without having to recompile and redeploy the entire system.

Time Warner brand of Virtual Truck is called Road Runner Connect. Previously, it was called InstallerConnect (when a Time Warner technician installed the software) and SelfConnect (when the subscriber installed the software).

Still a theoretical product as of 4th quarter 2000. A server that sits within the provider network and helps monitor, test, and repair applications and connections after the broadband connection is deployed. The Connection Management server is the replacement for the CorrectConnect server.

In the context of the activation solution, a .zip file that contains a collection of files and data and sometimes includes other .zip files. A container is used to upload data to the activation host, where the service to which it is targeted determines how the data is to be handled.
glossdef.remark: commenting this out while AnswerWeb is not part of the product as of Mont Blanc

glossdef.para: An Insight user who approves and manages answer resources.
A browser-based user interface for administering and configuring services in the Activation Server.

Modular, open, and programmable software that is the foundation of all Motive solutions. ControlWorks automates the otherwise complicated and costly processes associated with subscriber activation, marketing, and management. In addition, ControlWorks serves as a foundation for the cost-effective delivery of content, applications, and services. ControlWorks enables customers to maximize revenue and minimize the cost associated with their subscribers.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term ControlWorks. For example: ControlWorks

(BMW definition) A software package that provides the core framework services common to all server-side applications, including Registration, Profile, Security, Server Management, and Logging. The Core Server also includes certain server applications that manage interaction with Motive agents.

(Corvette definition) A software package that provides the core services common to all ControlWorks server applications. These core services include Agent Configuration, Auditing, Client Update, Data and Database, Data Publishing, Logging, Profile, Registration, Security, Server Management, Simple Event, SPM, and Tracing.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term ControlWorks. For example: ControlWorks Core Server

All ControlWorks deployments require the Core Server. Core Server is the minimum ControlWorks server component to be deployed or hosted. In addition, ControlWorks enhancements such as Warehouse may be installed on the Core Server.

Server-side software that manages and executes service fulfillment workflows. The Fulfillment Engine module drives service presentation (by providing a list of available offers), service selection, and service fulfillment for the installation agent. Also, the Fulfillment Engine module enables ISP selection using an installation agent. The Fulfillment Engine module is built on the Activation Server.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term ControlWorks Fulfillment Engine module. For example: ControlWorks Fulfillment Engine module
A server machine running Activation Server and possibly one or more ControlWorks enhancements (server applications and other components purchased separately).
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term ControlWorks machine. For example: ControlWorks machine
The aggregate deployment of physical servers in the ControlWorks environment.

An activation-supported use case. The Conversion use case refers to the process of migrating subscribers from another broadband service to its own or a retail ISP. In addition, it refers to the process of migrating subscriber computers to new access configurations and software so that the subscriber base always has the latest provider-supported technologies.
The software that loads, unloads, updates, and exposes a plug-in or component to any other component. The core performs these actions using APIs and the rules of the architecture defined by Motive.
The Motive Core Team is responsible for programming the fundamental components that are required by the architecture.
Motive client/server software that monitors and troubleshoots applications after deployment.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term CorrectConnect. For example: CorrectConnect
A profile that describes a cable modem or DSL modem. There is an individual CPE profile for each supported CPE in use by a subscriber computer.
A system profile that describes the vendor, speed, and class of a CPU. There is an individual CPU profile for each CPU within a subscriber computer.
A service provider.
A type of integration that provides the ability to exchange data between activation hosts and other applications.
A module that provides comprehensive subscriber data collection and tools for information exploration to make provider operational processes more effective.
An Activation Server application that enables dynamic activation on the client by providing agents access to files and content required in the activation process.

The set of rules that the server evaluates in response to client requests for a URL to an applicable target client file (such as a client workflow, client file package , or URL to another file). If the evaluation of a rule is true, the server sends the client the appropriate target URL.

glossentry.glossterm: device access filterDeprecated in HDM 3.0 (replaced by device group)

glossdef.para: A filter that targets a set of devices. Management privileges for this set of devices can be assigned to a user through a user access filter. Using a device access filter, you can filter for devices that fall within certain IP address ranges and have certain user tags, service tags, and device types. Each device access filter permits the assigned user to manage only those devices that meet its criteria.

A module that coordinates network activation and provisioning functions. In addition, the Distribution Manager dynamically manages the distribution of activation conversion solutions, such as target client files ( client workflows and client file packages), to subscriber agents.
A service that enables Activation Server services, such as the SPM service and Client Update service, to copy data from applications and then publish the data as files on each activation host.
A system profile that describes a disk drive. There is an individual drive profile for each disk drive within a subscriber computer.

A process that involves an activation workflow gaining access to unique functionality or content that is on a server and required to complete activation. The advantage of this process is supporting multiple, custom installation scenarios from the Activation Server.
An offer qualifier used for filtering at the time of deployment. For example, subscribers who reside in a specific postal code area may qualify for an offer.
An architecture that organizes and manages distributed services.

The act either by the subscriber or the system of submitting a request to a CSR for assisted service. Escalation occurs over the electronic channel and the phone channel. At times, a phone incident is escalated to a CSR automatically.
Also, in Insight, escalating is the act of a CSR routing an incident to another queue or administrator to resolve the issue when the CSR cannot resolve the incident.

A historical term that describes the third phase of products that Motive began developing in November 2000. ESD describes the service fulfillment capabilities provided by products like Warehouse. Also, ESD is the name of the team responsible for Virtual Truck Agent application development.

glossdef.remark: This is a deprecated defn for ControlWorks.
glossdef.para: An occurrence detected by the activation host in a given context. In the context of the Simple Event service, an event is an occurrence of new or updated data saved to the Activation OLTP database.
A threaded, high-volume, socket-based message protocol developed by Motive.
A service that is directly accessible to agents residing on client systems. External services are supported by internal services and, in turn, support agents.

Context-driven content that is authored and managed within AnswerWeb Manager. All FastAnswers content is presented to subscribers as answers, either in Broadband Technician for Macintosh or Narrowband Technician for Windows.

The process by which a private key is used to generate and append a digital signature to a file. The process has two purposes:
To authenticate the source of the file
To guarantee that the contents of the file have not been tampered with
The Data Publishing service (DPS) signs files when other services request it.
The distributed infrastructure shared between the client and the server. Part of the framework, the foundation provides:

listitem.para: File transferMoves files to and from the server.

Update managementDetermines which updates are available to an agent. If updates are available, the foundation initiates the update process. The foundation makes calls into the agent harness to perform these actions.
SecurityProvides a secure connection to the server using SSL (Secure Socket Layer).

glossdef.remark: Deprecated because 'bundle' now referred to as 'deployment unit' in HSM 2.0
glossdef.para: A system bundle that represents the OSGi framework itself. Through the system bundle, the framework may register services that other bundles can use. Examples of such services are the Package Admin and Permission Admin services.
Also known as the system bundle.

The act of enabling a subscriber to receive a service. Fulfillment may require several steps, including subscriber computer qualification, program installation, CPE provisioning, and OSS provisioning.
The part of the ControlWorks Fulfillment Engine module that executes service fulfillment requests. This involves locating the offer description and executing the associated workflows.

A .zip file that contains the code required to fulfill a client request such as installing a service offered to a subscriber. A fulfillment workflow can be absorbed and executed by an activation workflow on the client.

A list of URLs for all external services available to agents. Upon successful registration, agents download a full SPM from a specific URL provided by the registration server. Thereafter, the list is downloaded either at every startup or at a periodic polling interval during which the agent polls for the latest version of the full SPM.
Compare to initial SPM.
A type of integration developed to provide the ability to launch operations within:

listitem.para: An activation host from an external system (also known as a callin integration).
Other systems from an activation host (also known as a callout integration).

glossdef.para: A hierarchical data structure that can be serialized and that all work nodes in a workflow can read and add to. This data structure enables work nodes to make data available to each other without making the work nodes reliant on one another to find that data.

General description of the products and services offered to subscribers by broadband service providers. The goods and services offered may be digital such as software, content, and bandwidth; or they may be physical such as set-top boxes and networking cards. By offering subscribers goods and services, BSPs can generate revenue beyond access fees and differentiate their service.

The Motive service management solution for untangling the complexity of configuring and supporting home networks. Home Networking Manager enables service providers to provide subscribers a smooth, intuitive set-up process for home networking. The solution can be branded and customized.
A URL provided during registration that specifies the activation host directory where the Motive Client Foundation can find the full SPM.

An XML-based description that determines what information is collected from users and how it is processed for applications. For example, input templates make it possible to configure the database queries that can be made from the Control Panel.
A handler that is required for each input template to convert the user input to a Java object of the type that the service requires.

Subscriber profile reports that contain activation-specific data. Installation report data is gathered by agents that run on subscriber computers. The data is sent to an activation host. In the default configuration, the Control Panel displays install report profiles as children of the agent profile, which appears as a child of the system profile.
Custom Motive software that enables activation hosts to interface with billing, network provisioning, and content provisioning systems.

Also known as adapter, integration point, third-party adapter, and interface. In technical publications, use the term integration instead. Integrations are currently developed by Motive, but in the future they also may be written by third parties.
A module that integrates activation processes with other business processes by providing open interfaces between Activation Server and other systems.

A Motive software server plug-in application that connects the Motive system with third-party applications and acts as a data channel to pass information about key events between the Integration service and an application.

A network server containing information about subscribers, services, and network infrastructure. With this information, the intelligent server can be used to control the way services are created, marketed, and deployed to subscribers.

A component enhancement that enables integration into third-party systems such as operations support systems (OSS) applications and components. The Interface Gateway contains Motive-developed integrations that interface with third-party system integrations such as billing systems.
A service that is not directly accessible to clients, but may support client request servicing. Internal services support external services, as well as other internal services.
Level 1 application server. For example, Service Mediator is an L1AS.

Logical groupings that application administrators create through the Control Panel to partition subscriber system-related data on activation hosts and for deployment of client updates and other information to clients. For instance, if the defined location metadata of the segment is State.City.Department, examples of locations are:

The mechanism for organizing, controlling access to, and filtering subscriber information. Location metadata defines the location levels of the segment. The purpose is to define location levels that reflect the business hierarchy of the owners of the segment. In defined location metadata (such as Region.State.City), the location levels are separated by periods.
A service that records important system events in machine-readable format in real time for action by administrators, programs, or other systems.
Compare with Auditing service and Tracing service.
An Eclipse-based perspective in Motive Workbench that provides the functionality for deployment authors to create, edit, and activate settings.
A Workflow Editor-related term.A connection from the output of a work node to the input of a work node. One dynamic connector that is attached to work nodes only establishes a mapping.

On some wireless connections, one dynamic connector can establish two or more mappings. In a wireless connection with one start connector and one end connector that has two dynamic connectors attached to it, adding an additional start connector creates two additional mappings.
Double-clicking a start connector displays the number of mappings present for each dynamic connector attached to that start connector.

An XML file used by the Client Update service that contains the text of routine messages and button labels for display on the subscriber system during an update. For example, when an administrator notifies subscribers that an update is available, the Client Update service presents a standard announcement message from the message bundle. The bundle also contains generic advisory messages for subscribers who reject an update and for failed updates.
An answer resource that consists of a link and query that pull information from a third-party content source and display it in the Broadband Technician or Narrowband Technician.
Self-contained software component (or set of components) that handles a specific set of tasks.

A standalone Motive daemon-like application that typically is installed on subscriber systems by Motive agents. These desktop agents use the Motive Client Foundation to communicate with the Activation Server. The Motive Client Foundation also is referred to as Client Foundation Daemon (CFD) or Client Foundation (CF).
In external publications, use the term Motive Client Foundation instead of CFD.

The Motive technology platform, products, and service offerings that enable companies to automate service delivery across multiple products and throughout the subscriber life cycle. Motive SmartService Suite products include Business Class Manager, SmartCare, and SmartCall.

(bjinternal) This glossary term is deprecated for the Q2 2004 release (Mont Blanc).The flavors of the products in the Motive SmartService Suite. These include:
SmartActivation:
SmartActivation Residential Broadband Edition
SmartActivation Home Networking Edition
SmartActivation Business Edition
SmartCare:
SmartCare Home Networking Edition
SmartCare Narrowband Edition
SmartCare Residential Broadband Edition
SmartCare Business Edition
SmartCall:
SmartCall Residential Broadband Edition
SmartCall Narrowband Edition
A system profile that describes a NIC. There is an individual NIC profile for each NIC in the subscriber computer.

An incremental value-added service (VAS) provided through broadband, such as voice-over IP, firewalls, instant messaging, streaming video and music, software rental, video on demand, increased bandwidth rental, and collaborative gaming.
In addition, the term offer refers to the Motive-developed workflow required for the fulfillment of the offer upon subscriber selection.

A .zip file used to upload the offer to the server. The container always has a file named offering.xml that includes the values that describe the offer. It also may include an icon file, one extended attributes file, and one dictionary file. Note the offer container does not include the workflow.zip (the client workflow) file required to fulfill the offer.
Compare with workflow container.
A set of data maintained about a particular offer by the Offering Manager. This data can include references to pricing, qualification requirements, and fulfillment workflows.

An application service added to the activation environment with Offering Manager. The service enables the display of any graphical icons in the offer list through the agent interface. Each offer may have up to one associated icon. In addition, the OfferingIcons service interacts with other services in the Activation Server architecture.
A server application that enables the centralized deployment and intelligent distribution of ChannelDirect offers.

The Offering Manager provides the server functionality to:
Deploy offers for subscriber consumption based on qualification.
Analyze offer performance.
Configure offers.
A list of offers presented to the subscriber through the agent interface.

A repository of service offers that includes all parameters necessary to describe and define each service. The offer management system stores offer definitions, such as the cost of the offer; which subscribers have the option to select a service; which workflows are initiated when a service is selected; routing information such as the location of the content server on the network; and which applications are required to run a service.

Server application user responsible for administering the Activation Server from an application perspective. The offer manager creates services and target audiences. In addition, the offer manager creates and distributes service announcements and monitors service.
Also known as service manager. Use the term offer manager instead.

Mechanism by which the characteristics of a subscriber profile or system profile are used to qualify the subscriber for an offer. The server uses the qualifier defined in an offer to query the system and subscriber tables in the database for any matching values. The types are prequalification qualifier and eligibility qualifier.

An application service added to the activation environment by Offering Manager. The service receives offer list requests from agents, compiles offer list information per agent request, and sends offer list information to agents. In addition, the Offer service interacts with other services in the Activation Server architecture.
A client that cannot reach the server after a specified waiting time period. Editing an SPM service entry incorrectly, for example, can cause clients to be orphaned.
A deployed version of ControlWorks. The correct term is Activation Server.
The term Packaged Server is not appropriate for publication.
An Activation Server management module that controls and monitors the web server and application server processes. A PCS is configured to run locally for each host in the activation environment.
Legacy Motive agent no longer in development. Much like AOL Instant Messenger, PIVOT was intended to be a free download.
A Motive product that is a small executable that can be downloaded to test whether a subscriber computer meets the minimum requirements of the service provider.

An offer qualifier intended for hardware and software prerequisites (compared with those in the system profile) defined at offer creation time, such as the operating system (OS) type or the amount of free disk space.
A realm in which files and Depot rules can be deployed. Items deployed to the production realm are available to subscriber computers in production locations.
Compare with test realm.
A container of records that describe a subscriber and a subscriber computing environment.
In CD-based SmartActivation, profile data is accessible through the Profiles interface in the Control Panel.

A service that stores client system configuration information (such as operating system and RAM) and subscriber account information (such as account number, phone number and email address) in the database. This data is available for reporting purposes, targeting of client updates, and customer support for troubleshooting subscriber account problems.

A category of profile records that can be viewed through the Profiles interface in the Control Panel. For example, the system profile is a profile type that refers to records that contain data about subscriber hardware and software. A record of a profile type can contain records of other profile types. For example, a record of the system profile may contain records of other types such as the CPU profile, drive profile, and agent profile.

The process of tuning a server for a subscriber. The provisioning process is part of the fulfillment process, but not the entire process. Generally, the term provisioning is used in one of two contexts:

listitem.para: CPE/subscriber provisioningConfiguring the variables for front-end or back-end network components (such as a modem) for specific service usage.

Software installationConfiguring the variables for front-end or back-end network components (such as a modem) for specific service usage, as well as downloading and configuring certain software needed for that service usage. In general terms, this is setting up a system for service usage.

glossdef.para: Overall process of prequalifying subscriber computers for broadband access service.
Software that verifies that a computer meets the requirements for service (predeployment). The Time Warner version of PreQual is called Road Runner Qualifier.
Attribute used to control the deployment of files and Depot rules. The realms are the production realm and the test realm.

The business requirements of activating service in a subscriber base that has multiple regions, each with unique settings for email servers, proxy servers, and ISP selection. In addition, each region may be supported by its own operations organization.
The set of location and segment rules that the server evaluates to determine the assignment location and segment assignments for a subscriber computer during registration.

A service that enables clients to register with an Activation Server installation. When a subscriber or technician installs an activation agent, the software contacts an activation host running the Registration service. The Registration service assigns the client a permanent, unique identification number and an SPM. The client uses the SPM to locate additional activation services. The Registration service also assigns the client a segment and assignment location (from the defined location hierarchy) according to the evaluation of registration rules implemented.

The client component that enables Motive agents to launch server workflows. The remote workflow launcher provides the mechanisms to pass arbitrary input and output parameters to the workflow launcher.
A SmartActivation-supported use case. The Reporting use case refers to the business requirement of collecting and interpreting valuable subscriber data from the segment.

The administrator-designated state of a server on a given host; that is, the state you want the server to be in, as opposed to the actual state of the server. Administrators can enable or disable a server from the Control Panel, but that change may not take effect until, for example, PCS starts or stops the server. The run states are enabled and disabled.
Persistent data record that tracks the fulfillment and usage of a service ( offer) by a subscriber.
Do not use the term SCE.
The common technology and data that all Motive products share.

The term has been phased out because SCM does not clearly depict the Motive product line. The term SCM confused customers, who saw the adjective integrateda sufficient way of explaining the same concept.
Also, SCM was deprecated in the server architecture.

The key control point for the ESB. SCM serves as the centralized control mechanism for the set of distributed services that make up an ESB Segment. SCM controls state and configuration data for three types of entities: hosts, servers, and services. Each service is a component that is loaded into a server process (a server harness) for execution, and each server process runs on a host controlled by a process control service (PCS).

A service that authenticates administrators and authorizes them to work with the system. Authorized Control Panel administrators can promote new administrators and assign them roles, which enables the delegation of authority.
Generic, physical machine in a customer environment that is not part of the ControlWorks installation.
A service that enables administrators to enable and disable servers remotely through the Control Panel.

Postdeployment client/server software that gives a broadband service provider the ability to deploy connection-oriented services to network subscribers. Currently, only the client software is offered (for both Windows and Macintosh), and Motive hosts the server. SAM can be installed as part of the initial broadband installation or as standalone software once a subscriber computer is connected to broadband.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Service Access Manager. For example: Service Access Manager

A set of values that defines the settings for one service in the segment. The service entry includes the service address (such as a server URL), as well as settings specific to the service, and it indicates whether the service is enabled. Service entries are displayed on the Service Point Map (SPM) interface of the Control Panel.

An application that enhances the subscriber experience by helping subscribers control their suite of features or access new ones as they become available. Service Management Assistant can be used independently or with the Broadband Technician application. Unlike the Broadband Technician application, which is used to target and correct problems with connectivity, the Service Management Assistant allows users make changes to their accounts, profiles, and services.

The infrastructure your organization builds with Motive software to provide service and support to subscribers. Depending on the deployment, the environment may include an electronic channel, a phone channel, or both. Also, the environment may support self-service only or self-service and assisted service. Typically, your service management environment includes a firewall, load balancer, and some number of dedicated hosts, depending on the number of clients supported.

The packaged server built on Motive AMC framework that links the operations support systems and the hardware infrastructure systems. Service Mediator can automate service deployment, provisioning, billing, and subscriber management.

Service Mediator is the name for any Motive server built on the AMC framework. ControlWorks is the family name for any server components built with the newer BMW framework. It is not known when Motive will cease deployment or support of AMC-based servers, and until then, both names, Service Mediator and ControlWorks, are approved for publication in the appropriate context.
An alias to the configuration data stored in the Oracle tnsnames.ora file. This file tells Oracle the host name, protocol, port, and SID of a database instance.

A service that monitors the database at the interval defined. When data is created or updated in the Motive OLTP database, the Simple Event service notifies activation services that use the data. The services then restart automatically.

A comprehensive software solution (client, server, and database) that enables customers to activate services for subscribers. Implementing allows providers to lower operational cost, deploy service considerably faster, and decrease subscriber turnover. The solution supports several operations-focused activation use cases.

A comprehensive service activation solution that enables communication service providers and ISPs to initiate narrowband and broadband access and enhanced services on any IP access network. The Motive software reduces subscriber acquisition costs, increases average revenue per user, and reduces churn.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term SmartActivation. For example: SmartActivation. Starting with the Q2 2004 release, SmartActivation is no longer used.

A comprehensive software solution (client, server, and database) that enables customers to activate services for subscribers. Implementing allows providers to lower operational cost, deploy service considerably faster, and decrease subscriber turnover.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term SmartActivation. For example: SmartActivation. Starting with the Q2 2004 release, SmartActivation is no longer used.

The Motive customer service solution that enables communications service providers to provide automated troubleshooting and problem resolution via support call and optimize support call interactions. Call center support costs are reduced by deflecting calls through self service and by decreasing average handle times through assisted service.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term SmartCall. For example: SmartCall

The web-based interface that presents a consolidated view of telemetry gathered from SmartCall, the diagnostic encoding, and integration with third-party systems. The SmartCall CSR Console enables CSRs to resolve subscriber issues quickly even when the subscriber computer is not connected to the Internet.
The voice XML (VXML) interface of SmartCall that enables subscribers to interact with the service management environment through the phone.
The comprehensive Motive e-care solution that enables communications service providers to reduce costs and improve customer satisfaction by automating subscriber service and support.
Use a trademark symbol in the first mention of the term SmartCare. For example: SmartCare

The client interface for SmartCare that enables subscribers to run problem diagnostics and repair scripts on their own computers, access resource content to research problems, or submit incidents to CSRs.
Comprehensive e-care solution that enables dial-up service providers to reduce costs and improve customer satisfaction by automating subscriber service and support.
Comprehensive e-care solution that enables broadband service providers to reduce costs and improve customer satisfaction by automating subscriber service and support.
Client/server software that monitors and troubleshoots issues on subscriber computers after broadband service activation.
SmartConnect does not have a trademark.

Server application that provides support for profile-related and bulletin-related functionality. The profile-related functionality includes processing, viewing, and configuring views of test reports from SmartConnect agents that register within the segment. The bulletin-related functionality includes broadcasting, viewing, and expiring bulletins. The SmartConnect server application supports these functions through its CCServices and CCUploadService services.

The client directory of all services available within a segment. With this map, agents can locate server services. Administrators can enable and disable services and set the addresses of services from the Service Point Map (SPM) interface in the Control Panel.

A service that enables the Activation Server to manage SPMs and to make service addresses available to clients. The SPM service enables customers to change service locations as needed. The activation software on the subscriber computer uses an SPM to determine which hosts to contact for particular services.
Overall process of installing broadband access service on subscriber computers. The activation service solution supports self and technician-based activation scenarios.
The availability of client updates, agent configurations, and other client modifications. The states are enabled and disabled.
The default set of XSL templates that process install reports. When the VTIService is unable to find a matching XSL rule for the given VTID, the stock rules are used.

The VTIService attempts to use a stock rule to transform the report data for further processing. When Virtual Truck Installer server is installed, the file StockRules.xsl is installed in $BJROOT/conf/dbload. This file contains the set of XSL templates that make up the stock rule. As part of the configuration of Virtual Truck Installer server, the stock rule should be added to the database using the add_truck_xsl.sh script.

A module that includes the functionality to interact with the subscribers and their systems. The Subscriber Environment Manager automates subscriber-side activation and conversion processes through a robust set of presentation, configuration, and installation services.

A top-level profile that contains all profiles associated with a subscriber. The subscriber profile describes the customer and account information of an individual subscriber. Subscriber profile data is collected by all Motive agents and is stored in the Motive OLTP database.
In the default profile hierarchy, the subscriber profile has the following children profiles:

glossentry.glosssee: Deprecated because 'bundle' now referred to as 'deployment unit' in HSM 2.0framework system bundle

glossdef.para: A subscriber system-related filter for assignment to client updates and agent configuration data to target matching clients. For example, system filters can specify that only subscriber computers with certain attributes (such as 256 MB RAM or more) receive an update. System filters are assigned through the Control Panel.

The Oracle database system identifier (SID) used to uniquely identify the Oracle database instance running on the Oracle database. The SID is created when Oracle is configured on the database host. Often the same value is used for the database service name.
A profile that contains information about the subscriber system hardware and software. There is an individual system profile for each client ID associated with a subscriber.
In the default profile hierarchy, the system profile has the following children profiles:

A profile that contains a set of shared subscriber characteristics. Target profiles could be based on one or more characteristics such as subscriber geography, CPE type, credit history, or previous service usage.
For example, the target profile AustinHighEndPC may be based on subscribers associated with a postal code that begins with 787 and at least a 600 MHz Windows-based computer.
Compare with subscriber profile.

A realm in which files and Depot rules can be deployed before they are deployed to the production realm. Items deployed to the test realm are available to test clients only; they are not available to paying subscribers.
Reports that contain data about a test run by a subscriber or SmartConnect. Test report data is gathered by SmartConnect agents and is sent to the server.

When the SmartConnect server is installed on the Activation Server, the test reports are part of the default hierarchy of profiles that appear in the Control Panel. In the default hierarchy of profiles, test reports are children profiles of a SmartConnect agent profile, which is a child of the system profile.

A service that provides low-level information about server processes as they run, which is useful for troubleshooting. It is possible to enable and disable tracing service by service or enable specific types of traces within a service.

A unique identifier for a deployed client update. A single tracking ID is associated with multiple versions of the client update; however, it is possible to clone the client update to create a unique instance of the update with a unique tracking ID to monitor its status separately from other deployments.

A group of subscribers who share the characteristics defined by one or more target profiles. Target subscriber groups are created so that specific value-added services can be offered to members of the group.
