For example, videoconferencing services can be offered to subscribers who have a digital camera and a high-resolution monitor.
A type of integration that provides the ability to launch data between the Control Panel and any other application UI.
A filter that assigns device access filters to existing users. Users assigned to a device access filter can manage devices targeted by the device access filter.
A profile that describes a local user. In the future, there will be an individual user profile for each local user associated with the subscriber profile.

A service that adds value beyond the standard set of services offered. Services such as multiplayer Internet gaming, firewall protection, video on demand, and IP telephony are examples of value-added services in the traditional broadband ISP space.
Also known as enhanced service. Use the terms value-added service or VAS instead.
The owner of a value-added service (VAS). VAS providers (also called offering providers) partner with Motive and broadband service providers ( BSPs) to present offers to subscribers.
A system profile that describes a video device. There is an individual video device profile for each video device within a subscriber computer.
The family name for Virtual Truck products, including Virtual Truck Installer and Virtual Truck Qualifier.
Also known as VT. Use the term Virtual Truck instead. Use a registered trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Virtual Truck. For example: Virtual Truck

Client service fulfillment software that facilitates CPE qualification and provisioning, authentication, and service presentation. Virtual Truck Agent downloads and activates after Virtual Truck Installer performs the initial broadband installation. Virtual Truck Agent has a separable UI.
Also known as VTA. Use the term Virtual Truck Agent instead. Use a registered trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Virtual Truck Agent. For example: Virtual Truck Agent

For now, Virtual Truck Agent only runs on Windows and Macintosh operating systems. In the future, Virtual Truck Agent may be designed to run on any device running any operating system (for example, on handheld computing devices or a computer running UNIX).

A Motive agent that runs on Windows and Macintosh to automate the broadband service installation process. Virtual Truck Installer qualifies the subscriber computer, configures the operating system, performs connectivity tests, and provides reporting features. Virtual Truck Installer runs as a wizard, usually from a CD.

Also known as Virtual Truck and VTI. Use the term Virtual Truck Installer instead. Use a registered trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Virtual Truck Installer. For example: Virtual Truck Installer
Server application that uses the Registration service to process the subscriber registration.

The Virtual Truck Installer registration application is not sold separately, but it is included when a customer buys a server with the installation agent. Use a registered trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Virtual Truck Installer registration application. For example: Virtual Truck Installer registration application

Server application that provides support for profile-related functionality. The profile-related functionality includes processing, viewing, and configuring views of install reports from installation agents that register within the segment. The server application supports these functions through its VTIService service.

A Motive agent that runs on Windows and Macintosh. Virtual Truck Qualifier automates the minimum requirements verification process for broadband providers by testing the systems of prospective subscribers and then providing the subscribers with pass or fail information.
Also known as VTQ. Use the term Virtual Truck Qualifier instead. Use a registered trademark symbol in the first mention of the term Virtual Truck Qualifier. For example: Virtual Truck Qualifier

A number that uniquely identifies an activation workflow. The VTID is used to add the corresponding XSL rule to configure the Activation Server. The installation agent sends its VTID with any report upload requests to the VTIService. The VTIService uses this VTID to find the matching XSL rule for transforming the report data to do additional processing.
Typically, the ID value is provided by the workflow developer.
A service that processes install report requests from installation agents and stores the data in the appropriate tables in the Activation OLTP database.

A component enhancement to the Activation Server that provides agents dynamic access to installation client workflows, other client files, and ChannelDirect offers stored on activation hosts. Warehouse adds two server applications, Workflow Depot and Offering Manager, to the activation environment.

The Warehouse server functionality enables broadband service providers ( BSPs) to automate complex installation scenariossuch as support for multiple ISPs and tiered service levelsand centrally deploy and target ChannelDirect offers.
Control Panel Help-specific definition. Do not use this definition in other documentation.

Query strings that contain wildcard characters to return results that include the specified pattern. In a Control Panel query string, you can use the asterisk (*) as a wildcard character. To do a literal search on the asterisk (*) or backslash (\) characters, preface them with the \ escape character . For example, using the search string 512* returns results that start with 512, and using the search string 5\** returns results that start with 5*.

A .zip file used to upload the workflow to the server. The container includes the files that describe the workflow and the workflow itself, which also is a .zip file. Note that the workflow container can include multiple workflows.

A Motive, Visio-based application that programmers use to design client and server workflows in a visual manner. The Workflow Editor file of a workflow (such as file_name.wfe) is the formula or description of the workflow.

A workflow subsystem that launches workflows and manages their progress. On the server, the Workflow Engine is an application component of the Activation Server. On the client, the Workflow Engine is a utility available to agents.

Also known as WorkflowServices, which is a term that appears in GUI items. In general documentation, use the term Workflow Engine ; however, use the term WorkflowServices when referring to the GUI term. In the future, all instances of the term WorkflowServices will be converted to Workflow Engine.

An application service added to the activation environment by Workflow Depot. The service accepts workflow requests from the agent. In addition, the WorkflowLauncher service interacts with other services in the Activation Server architecture.

Also known as WorkflowLauncher, which is a term that appears in the GUI. In general documentation, use the term Workflow Launcher; however, use the term WorkflowLauncher when referring to the GUI term. In the future, all instances of the term WorkflowLauncher will be converted to Workflow Launcher.

The core engine that makes workflows run. The workflow subsystem includes all code and facilities provided for the support of workflows, including workflow creation and execution and work node creation.

A unit of code that automates a single function or step in a process, which can be combined with other work nodes or steps to accomplish computerized automation of an activation process. A set of work nodes make up a workflow.

A set of XSL templates that enables VTIService to extract the pertinent report data from the uploaded report data for a given workflow. There is a unique XSL rule for each activation workflow. As part of processing the report data sent by an installation agent, VTIService uses an XSL rule to perform the required data transformations to do additional processing.
Improper or excessive use of a service beyond the terms of a contract or license agreement.
A script that represents the service provider's response to an abuse event. Subscriber quarantining is an example of an abuse action.

A customer site employee that monitors the provider network looking for
abuse events such as bandwidth abuse, attacks, and viruses. The abuse analyst also views and manages abuse events using the UPM Console.

Subscriber system activity that violates the terms of the service agreement or threatens the security of the provider network. Examples of abuse events include virus activity detected on a subscriber system and excessive bandwidth consumption.

The most recent abuse action applied to the subscriber's account. Notified, quarantined and de-provisioned are examples of abuse status. Check the subscriber's history to determine relevant earlier activity because a recent notification may obscure an earlier quarantine status.

The Abuse web service provides an interface that collectors use to submit events to the UPM system. Upon receiving an event, the abuse service determines the subscriber associated with the event using the existing SIM from UPM.
The outcome of policy execution.

A policy class that categorizes policies which run in response based on an event received from an external entity such as a virus detection system. These events fire when some action or data considered abnormal for a given system, user, or network occurs. Examples include abnormal traffic patterns, user activity, and application behavior. An anomaly detection policy defines what the system does after such an event occurs.
An integrated solution for data-over-cable service providers to configure and manage broadband modems, and enable and administer subscriber self-registration and activation.
A software component that enables operations and customer care personnel to maintain current data on subscriber problems and status along with usage trends.
A software component that executes rules for implementing service and subscriber policy and automates policy variance detection.

A software component that generates abuse events. Collectors process data and can create an event if the data meets criteria defined in the configuration. A collector could be a Motive software component that acquires data, an adapter for existing performance management software, or a user interface in which analysts create abuse events manually. Collectors submit the generated events to the UPM using the Abuse web service.

A customer site employee who configures and manages the UPM collectors. In the Usage Policy Manager domain, the Collector Admin role includes the account privileges to create or modify collector configuration. To assign this role to a user account, use the Motive Management Console.

The UPM system requires a user account with the collector client role to read configuration values for the collector instances and to submit new events to the Abuse web service. To assign this role to a user account, use the Motive Management Console.
The definition that requires satisfaction to trigger an outcome.
To terminate a subscriber's network access. A de-provisioned subscriber does not have IP connectivity, and cannot authenticate with the provider network.

A set of rules that gets executed by the policy engine after being triggered by a receiving input (event) from an external entity such as a virus detection system. Authorized users can view, modify, or create policies using the Policy Builder interface in the Usage Policy Manager Console.

A customer site employee who defines the policies used to automate the system response to events such as virus detection, attacks, and bandwith abuse. In the Usage Policy Manager domain, the Policy Editor role includes the account privileges to create or modify policies using the Usage Policy Manager Console. To assign a role to an account, use the Motive Management Console.

A customer site employee who reviews the policies defined to automate system response to events such as virus detection, attacks, and bandwith abuse. In the Usage Policy Manager domain, the Policy Reviewer role includes the account privileges to view existing policies using the Usage Policy Manager Console. To assign a role to an account, use the Motive Management Console.

A policy rule is configured so that it has a set of conditions that must be satisfied to execute a set of actions. In the Usage Policy Manager domain, a policy rule is built by configuring a set of condition and action templates that are stored in the policy repository.
A software component that automates handling of policy enforcement, including provider communication to subscribers through multiple channels.
This web service provides the interface that is invoked by the clients to communicate with the different provisioning providers. This interface is used to quarantine, unquarantine a subscriber.
To restrict a subscriber to an isolated area of the provider network, such as a walled garden. A quarantined subscriber still has IP connectivity, but is limited to a subset of the provider network.
The resolution of a subscriber's problems or behavior that constitued abuse.
To reinstate a subscriber who has been de-provisioned.

Provides a way to identify a subscriber based on the abuse event data or any other search criteria suppported by the SIM. For example, abuse event data may include a subscriber's cable modem MAC address. A SIM can be used to identify the subscriber from a third-party system using the provided modem MAC address as a search criterion.

The Usage Policy Manager Console uses templates to build policies, events, notifications, and virus response definitions. Each template has a set of attributes that can be configured from the Usage Policy Manager Console. The templates are created using the Usage Policy Manager SDK and are stored in the policy repository.

Event that initiates policy execution. The trigger event can originate from integration points to external systems or network appliances called collectors. Also, a person may generate a trigger event. For example, subscribers can generate trigger events based on their activity or system status, and authorized provider analysts can generate trigger events using the Event Builder in the Usage Policy Manager Console.
To reinstate a subscriber that has been quarantined.
An application that providers can use to automate enforcement of service policies. Usage Policy Manager can address issues such as misuse of bandwidth by subscribers.

A web-based application that operations and customer care personnel can use to view and manage abuse events. Usage Policy Manager Console can be used to detect abuse events, notify offending subscribers, and take action against offending subscribers if necessary.

In computer security terminology, a piece of code that, like a biological virus, makes copies of itself and spreads by attaching itself to a host, often damaging the host in the process. The host is another computer program, often a computer operating system, which then infects other computers through file transfers or sharing of network and application resources.

Description of a virus for which Usage Policy Manager has known detection and remediation tools. The virus response definition provides virus identification information, the locations of applicable remediation tools, any required software updates, offers related to virus detection, and prevention resources available to subscribers. The resources defined in the virus response definition are used in the remediation web-based workflow that is executed by a virus policy triggered by a virus detection event.

A unique string of bits, or the binary pattern, of a virus. The virus signature is like a fingerprint in that it can be used to detect and identify specific viruses. Anti-virus software uses the virus signature to scan for the presence of malicious code.

An isolated area of the provider network in which the addresses that a user can visit are controlled. Walled gardens can be used to give subscribers limited access to the provider network for provisioning, parental control, virus remediation, or other purposes.

In computer security terminology, a self-replicating computer program similar to a computer virus that attaches itself to an executable program and becomes part of that program. A worm is self-contained and does not require another program to propagate itself.
Single-instance server that provides a contact point for the Managed Server instances and system administration tools in the WebLogic Server domain.

Standard web server software such as Sun One Web Server or Apache. Optionally, Bastion Web Server packages are installed on hosts in the DMZ to receive and redirect incoming subscriber system requests to application servers.

Motive product that provides both self service and assisted service for broadband subscribers. For self service, the BCM automates problem diagnosis, resolution, and service management capabilities across each of the primary support channelselectronic, phone, and email. For assisted service, the BCM helps CSRs (customer support representatives) pinpoint the cause of and resolution for service issues on behalf of high-speed data subscribers.
Personnel appointed by service providers to identify customer requirements and create/modify the SMP workflows delivered as a part of Motive's template solutions.

The method of assigning private IP addresses to customers by translating the network addresses at the service provider's level. It assigns private network addresses to the internal hosts and translates them back to public IP addresses which can be routed to the Internet. If this technique is adopted, multiple customers can be assigned behind a single public IP address. This approach is in practice to address the depleting IP addresses in IPv4 network design.

A platform that enables service providers to deploy and manage applications on devices and PCs in the home. It also provides an application support environment allowing application authors the greatest amount of functionality in a operating system neutral manner. A core part of CAF is the OSGi framework.
Plugin software that enables SMP to retrieve data from a particular data source such as an Oracle database, Home Device Manager (HDM), and Connected Device Platform (CDP).

The Discovery Data Server (DDS) is a component of HomeView 2011 that provides a merged view of a subscriber's home network layout. It combines data from different sources, such as the HomeView client and RGW, and provides it to the HomeView templates in the form of a devices list. The data is stored in DDS in an XML format. This devices list is used by the HomeView templates to perform the following functions:
HomeView CSC Network Map template: to provides a graphical representation of the home network.
HomeView Video QoS Management template: to displays a list of media devices.
Added during HV8.0

A solution that provides a generic mechanism for sending requests originating in the provider network to an application running on a client endpoint, and for returning a result. It is to be used by many current and future applications in the Motive product group that require an efficient, flexible, and reusable mechanism for message communication. For HomeView, this server component allows Service Management Platform (SMP) templates to discover and trigger the execution of services (enablers) on HomeView client instances deployed in the home network. Added during HV8.0

An XML-based open protocol for near-real-time communication. It is an extensible instant messaging protocol for client-to-server and server-to-server communication. It facilitates multiple applications, such as instant messaging, multi-party chat, voice and video calls (Jingle protocol extension), lightweight middleware, and generalized routing of XML data.Added during HV 8.1

Web-based application that provides interfaces for remotely managing CPE (customer premises equipment) such as residential gateways, IP set-top boxes, femtocell base stations, and VoIP terminal adapters. Network operations personnel use the interface:
To manage individual devices. CSR users can only manage one subscriber CPE at a time.
To create and manage device policies. For example, a policy may dictate required firmware for a device.
To create and manage action definitions.
To create and manage device types.
To create and manage firmware images.
To view, copy, and download communication logs for troubleshooting, as well as to set the global log level.
To create and manage device groups.
To create and manage device alarm definitions.
The scripts associated with the device types for zero-touch activation scenarios. These associations, or mappings, are configured on the Zero Touch tab in the IWE Workflow Administration Console.

A Motive solution that contains separately licensable templates, such as Multi-Channel Service Activation Template, Video QoS Management Template, and Home Network Management Template. These templates allow users to set up, diagnose, and troubleshoot modern connected, multi-device home networks. For example, the templates allow users to activate high-speed internet (HSI) services, set up email accounts and Wi-Fi connectivity, and troubleshoot various issues to improve the quality of video services in a home network.
A system for distributing video signals using internet protocols, typically in conjunction with an internet connection.

A version of Internet protocol that is designed to succeed and address the limitations of the previous version IPv4. IPv6 provides a solution to the problem of the fast-depleting address space of IPv4. It increases the address space from 32 bits to 128 bits, so that every IP device has a unique IP address. It also provides for stateless autoconfiguration, whereby, no network address translation (NAT) is required for customers.

A solution that provides a global, generic, and shared infrastructure to enable efficient customer premises equipment (CPE) management for all programs that require device management. M2M provides a centralized management console to aggregate the business support systems (BSS) data and the operations support systems (OSS) data. M2M provides an efficient business data exchange middleware and backbone that standardizes the data exchanges between the business applications and the CPEs.
Server instance that runs identical applications to its peer instances in a WebLogic Server domain.

A client installed on the subscriber's Windows or Mac computer that receives messages from the Endpoint Communication System (ECS) and executes remote procedure calls that manage or discover endpoint services and state. An SMP workflow sends a message containing a remote procedure call to the ECS server, which routes the message to the Management Agent through the ejabberd XMPP server. The Management Agent executes the endpoint operation and returns the result through the same channel, and SMP parses the result (HTTP XML-RPC response) and sends the appropriate signal (success, error, or timeout) to continue the workflow.
In HomeView, a graphical representation of a home network. Subscribers use the network map to view and manage devices in their network more easily.

Over-the-top (OTT) technology refers to the delivery of streaming video services directly to the subscriber's connected devices in a home network through internet. It allows the subscriber to access the services anytime, from any place, and on any device. It is referred to as over-the-top, because these services are available on top of the services that the subscribers already have and they do not require any business or technology affiliations with the network operators. MM: Added for HV 8.0. Mark plz review

A standard protocol of retrieving emails from a remote server. This protocol is typically used by email clients to download emails from a remote server using a TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) connection. Most email clients using POP usually connect to the remote email server, retrieve all emails to store them on the user's computers as new messages, delete them from the server, and disconnect. However, the email clients using POP can also leave emails on the remote server after download. A few versions of the POP protocol have been developed over the years, with version 3 (POP3) being used currently.Added during HV2012R1
A family of communications protocols that includes PPPoA and PPPoE.
To make a printer available to multiple computers on a network. The printer can be attached to another computer, a print server, or directly to the network.

The Motive reference user interface framework for end users accessing the Motive Customer Experience Solutions. Out of the box, the framework can be branded or integrated into the service providers web portals and mobile apps. The SSC framework offers a web app for both fixed and mobile devices, as well as mobile apps, that interface with SMP for the execution of workflows that manage the end-users home network and its devices.

Motive product that automates service activation for broadband subscribers. The Service Activation Manager software enables subscribers to turn up high-speed data and IP-based services without having to call a customer service representative (CSR) or request an onsite technician visit. The software can offer and fulfill IP-based services during activation events and increase adoption rates for existing and new services. Motive configures all necessary elements of an IP-based service through a CD-only solution in SAM 6.0. In versions of SAM after 6.0, Motive configures all necessary elements of an IP-based service through multiple fulfillment models, including CD-only, web-only (or CD-less), or a combination CD and web solution.

An element used in Service Management Platform (SMP) workflows. It facilitates executing a service operation and stores the results in a dictionary file. In a workflow, the available operations are the operations for each service operation in the active version of the application configuration. The service operations are visible on the Palette pane of the Workflow Builder.
A CPE (customer premises equipment) device for converting and displaying data from an IP network to a standard frequency (channel number) for display on a standard analog television set.

Sequence of characters that uniquely identifies a WLAN. The SSID distinguishes the wireless network from others. Each device that establishes a connection to a specific wireless network does so with the applicable SSID and other values such as a security key.

A standalone Motive solution that contains a reference user interface, workflows, pre-defined service models, and relevant integration adapters. Using a template, subscribers and service providers can perform a set of functions that enable them to diagnosis and troubleshoot home networks. Templates are extensible to multiple devices and separately licensable as products.Added during HV8.0

A Microsoft Windows user interface feature. Standard ToolTips provide textual clues in small windows that appear when pausing on a button, icon, or some other GUI element. Balloon ToolTips, another type of ToolTip, are usually caused by some other event, such as an unexpectedly dropped connection in the Motive Wireless Connection Client. Standard ToolTips have square corners, whereas balloon ToolTips have rounded corners with a stem pointing to the tool.

A standard way of identifying resources over Internet or on a private network. A URI identifies the name and location of a file or resource and is used by software programs or file sharing protocols to access or download files. It includes a string of characters for filenames, and may also contain a path to the directory of the file. URIs are of two types: URLs (Uniform Resource Locator) that are addresses with network locations, and URNs (Uniform Resource Names) that are persistent names, and are independent of network addresses. URI and URL are often used interchangeably.

A bundle of services offered to the subscribers by service providers in addition to the core services. These services add value to the standard services making the providers more competitive, as well as bringing in more revenue. Typically, these are nonessential, for example, email, Internet access, text messaging, video on demand, home shopping , and gaming.
A logically related group of WebLogic Servers for management as a unit. The domain always includes a WebLogic Administration Server and additional WebLogic Server instances called Managed Servers.

High-frequency WLAN. Wi-Fi is specified in the 802.11b specification from the IEEE and is part of a series of wireless specifications together with 802.11, 802.11a, 802.11b, and 802.11g. All four standards use the Ethernet protocol and CSMA/CA (carrier sense multiple access with collision avoidance) for path sharing.
A LAN that sends and receives data through radio, infrared optical signals, or other technology. WLANs do not require a physical connection between the wireless device and the hub.

The third-generation Wi-Fi security protocol for protecting data over WLANs. WPA2 is an upgraded security method to WPA for wireless networks. WPA support for the AES-CCMP encryption protocol is optional, whereas WPA2 requires support. WPA2 typically also supports TKIP.

A variation of WPA2 is WPA2 with a Pre-Shared Key (WPA2-PSK), which uses a static key or security phrase as with WEP. WPA2-PSK uses the shared key to negotiate a temporary key used for the connection. That temporary key is typically renegotiated at a time interval specified by the access point. WPA2-PSK can use either TKIP or AES-CCMP to encrypt the keys.

The Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS) standard was designed by Wi-Fi Alliance to simplify the process of configuring security on wireless home networks. WPS automatically configures the secured network name (SSID) and WPA security key for the access point and the WPS-enabled client devices on the wireless network. It commonly uses the Push Button Configuration (PBC) or Personal Identification Number (PIN) method to allow a device access the wireless network.Added during HV8.0

XEP-0009 is an XMPP protocol extension for transporting XML-RPC encoded requests and responses between two XMPP entities. This protocol supports all the XML-RPC syntax and semantics. However, this protocol makes use of XMPP instead of HTTP as the underlying transport.Added during HV8.1

XEP-0199 is an XMPP protocol extension for sending application-level pings over XML streams. Application-level pings can be sent from a client to a server, from one server to another, or from one endpoint to another.Added during HV8.1
An application is one of the component required to provide the service to the end user. The same application can be used by several services.
Transport Protocol used for business data communication. For example HTTP, XMPP. Protocol can be different for M2M Device and M2M Network Application.
Customer Service Console is an SMP platform component.
Endpoint is an abstract concept referring to either M2M Network Application, M2M Device or M2M Proprietary Device.
EPA is a third party software component that allows M2M proprietary devices to exchange business data with the M2M Network Application.

Lightweight M2M (LWM2M) is a system standard in the Open Mobile Alliance. It includes DTLS, CoAP, Block, Observe, SenML and Resource Directory and weaves them into a device-server interface along with an Object structure.
Communication client on M2M Device that provides communication channel for business data messages (currently XMPP/Bosh).
Composite product that enables the exchange of business data between M2M Device Application and M2M Network Application
Graphical User Interface Console to address FCAPS of the M2M Communication Controller.
FCAPS: F Fault, C Configuration, A Accounting, P Performance, S Security.
M2M Device or M2M Gateway. M2M Gateway may control many M2M Devices.
Business application deployed on the M2M device.
Business application deployed within the IT network of the M2M service provider.
M2M device that communicates through the External Protocol Adapter with the M2M Network Application. The M2M device use proprietary protocol towards the External Protocol Adapter.
Solution that addresses the End to End provisioning, activation and troubleshooting of an M2M network.
M2M CC Database holds the configuration about all M2M proprietary devices, external protocol adapters, M2M network applications as well as the message routing data.
Identifies the communication and messaging paradigm to exchange business data between a M2M device application and M2M network application, for example RestMS, mIa.

A service is the service offered to the customer (for example summary of the electricity consumption). The same application could be used by several services, and a service could required an application, or some upgrade or software installed inside the device.
A program that performs discrete functions that perform specific tasks to initiate broadband service on a subscriber computer.
Defines the Mcci ActiveX controls to include in the Service Management Client.
A NIC or a software program that allows a computer to attach to a network.
The Activation workflow step that installs the driver required for the adapter selected in the Adapter Selection step.
The Activation workflow step that displays a list of supported wireless adapters and asks the user to select the appropriate one for wireless activation.

A security protocol for wireless networks. AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) standard cryptographic cipher that uses a block length of 128 bits and key lengths of 128, 192, or 256 bits. AES-CCMP (Counter Mode CBC-MAC Protocol) is the encryption algorithm used in the 802.11i security protocol for wireless networks. It uses the AES block cipher, but restricts the key length to 128 bits.
Contains any applications needed by the Service Management Client. For example, the Agent bundle of the full client contains the System Tray application files.

Values defined for types of subscribers at which to direct particular service alerts. As a part of server-side filtering that determines which alerts download to a client, the Alert service compares the alert groups in the created alerts with those in the alerts attribute in the client request.

Motive Service that provides for publishing and filtering of alerts on the server. The Service Alerts Console uses the Alert service to validate the XML source of an alert. The Alert service generates the alert ID and adds the ID to the alert XML before storing it in the database. In response to a request from the Online Service Alert workflow, the Alert service filters all published alerts based on segment data and date/validity period and sends the results to the workflow.
A service alert form that includes pre-populated fields. In the Service Alerts Console, you can create a new alert based on an alert template.

Unique identifiers for the vendor applications in your deployment. For example, a GlobeCom deployment may include three applications, one for each supported service level with the following application IDs:
GlobeCom_Gold
GlobeCom_Silver
GlobeCom_Bronze

The state engine that manages the HomeView application state. Once the ApplicationState engine is started (after entitlement and network setup), it initializes local data structures and manages the periodic update of the local state and communication with the server.
Online workflow that applies changes requested by the CSR to the client machine by using the managed settings Set methods.

A directory of high-level attributes that describe the Motive deployment. Through the Motive Workbench, you create an attribute directory made up of the following reference attribute types, and you can also add your own attribute types: activeXBundle, agentBundle, alerts, configBundle, levelOfService, link, locale, managedSettings, offlineBundle, region, solutionContext, and subscription.

The protocol (if any) used to establish a connection with a particular WLAN. Subscribers specify the applicable authentication in the connection profile. The authentication types are open, WEP, WPA-PSK, and WPA2-PSK.
Motive Service that provides support for the creation and storage of bundles. The Bundle service does thus and so.
The Activation workflow step that presents cabling instructions for the modem specified by the user.
One-click fix workflow that empties the History folder for Internet Explorer.

An installer used to deploy the entire Service Management Client for new subscribers that do not already have the client installed. The client installer includes the installer executables generated from each of the bundle types: ActiveX, Agent, Configuration, and Offline Content. The client installer is delivered to the subscriber either on a CD or by using an HTTP download during activation of the subscriber.

Motive Service that enables CSRs to put work intended for a client in a queue from which the client can locate and run. In this case, the client refers to some form of the Electronic Support Client. The Client Queueing service is a replacement for follow-up maps run by a CSR.

The service that queues workflow requests for the client. The CSR Console uses the service to queue Apply Changes and Remote Control workflow requests for the client. When the subscriber runs the Online Escalation workflow, the workflow polls the CQS for work.
The phone call made by a subscriber when an issue has not been escalated by the Motive self-services solution.

Contains any configuration data needed by the Service Management Client. For example, the Configuration bundles of the full and minimal clients set several registry entries for the Offline Dispatcher workflow.
Motive Service that provides means of getting and setting global and server-specific configuration data. Other services use the Configuration service to retrieve their configuration data.
One-click fix workflow that allows the subscriber to specify how Internet Explorer handles cookies.
The Activation workflow step that pings a DNS address to verify the machine can access the Internet.

The individual components that make up the full functionality for a Service Management Client executable intended for particular subscriber systems. The primary content bundles are:
ActiveX bundle
Offline Content bundle (OCB)
Configuration bundle
Agent bundle

Motive Service that enables other services to read and write published content from or to the system. The service supports versioning and tagging for content authors using Motive Workbench to update content while an older, un-"available" version is in use by subscribers.

A JavaScript object that controls the entire execution of a flow. In the Offline Flow Architecture, a controller object reads a controller XML file, which describes the flow order and lists the objects and messages associated with each step. The objects are the logic and display pages; the messages are the signals sent between the logic or display object and the controller object. Data used by the flow is stored in a dictionary.xml file, which is also read by the controller. The controller loads the display and logic pages and then controls their execution.
The Activation workflow step that configures the RGW so that the user can connect to the ISP. This step also sets up the wireless network if the RGW supports wireless.
Online solution workflow that creates a new email account within the currently installed default email client (Microsoft Outlook, Outlook Express, Windows Mail, and Windows Live Mail).

Client activity implemented as an ActiveX control or script that the System Tray application runs as a result of some event on the subscriber system. For example, custom actions can run subsequent to the System Tray application starting up or subscriber activity in the notification area. There are several types of custom actions, including startup actions, menu-item actions, timer-managed (poll) actions, and tray-click actions. mk: edited 1/5/06
External system or software application from which SMP retrieves data using the applicable data source adapter (DSA) .
One-click fix workflow that deletes cookies from Internet Explorer.
One-click fix workflow that removes all files from the temporary Internet files directory, the Windows Temp directory, and the current user's temporary directory.
In HomeView, the process of changing the icon or friendly name associated with a device.
The type of client that provides only enough features for an offline phone page that can be used for both voice-based self-service and assisted service solutions.

Motive Service that provides support for encoding specified telemetry to a diagnostic code and for decoding a diagnostic code into the specified telemetry. The Diagnostic Encoding service also provides for uploading and enabling the encoding and decoding rulesets.
See modem and wireless dial-up modem.
A JavaScript object that stores data used by a flow. The dictionary contains top-level sections and subsections called keys. The data in these sections and subsections is in key-value pairs.
In HomeView the process of collecting data about the devices in the home network to which the subscriber's computer is connected.
A page that displays information to the user.
A network hierarchy that contains server and client computers.
Virtual channel through which subscribers resolve service issues. The electronic channel supports self-service and assisted service, depending on the deployment.
The process of Windows Vista or later operating system prompting the user for consent or credentials in order to use a user's full administrator access token.

Online solution workflow that repairs, tests, and profiles email accounts within the installed email clients as well as creates new email accounts within the currently installed default email client. Supported email clients include Microsoft Outlook, Outlook Express, Windows Mail, and Windows Live Mail.
One-click fix workflow that empties the Windows recycle bin.

The method for securing data transmitted over a WLAN. Subscribers specify the applicable encryption in the connection profile. In the reference implementation of the Motive Wireless Connection Client, the WEP encryption types are a 40-bit key or a 104-bit key; the WPA-PSK and WPA2-PSK encryption types are TKIP and AES.
Online workflow that registers or authenticates the endpoint ID of the subscriber's machine.
In HomeView, a JavaScript state engine used to enumerate or discover devices.
Motive Service that provides applications and other services to record events within the Motive system. The Data Mart ETL consumes the event data for reporting purposes.
Online workflow that uploads stored offline events to the server.

A hardware standard replacing PC Cards that was developed by the Personal Computer Memory Card International Association (PCMCIA). The ExpressCard technology provides a large increase in bandwidth over PC Cards.

The Activation workflow step that configures the Windows firewall so that the Activation workflow can run without firewall prompts. For third-party firewalls that are detected, the user is presented with instructions for manually configuring the firewalls.
Some firewalls are not detectable, such as firewalls that do not register with the Windows Security Center. Thus, at the end of the Firewall Configuration step, the user is asked to configure any firewalls that may not have been detected.
Web content created by Macromedia Flash. The Macromedia Flash Player allows you to view Flash content.

The type of client that provides the full set of features available for both self-service and assisted-service functionality, including access to all online and offline workflows, support for service alerts, and the System Tray, McciBrowser, and InstallHelper applications.
One-click fix workflow that determines which program the subscriber is using for email. Supported email clients include Microsoft Outlook, Outlook Express, Windows Mail, and Windows Live Mail.
The online GlobeCom reference application from which the solution workflows can be invoked.

The integrity level on Windows Vista or later operating system at which applications that have been granted the right to be elevated by the user run. This integrity level gives an application capabilities that are analogous to those of an application running under an Administrators account on Windows XP or older operating systems. Applications running at this integrity level are free to modify user and system managed areas of the file system and registry, as well as to affect system configuration in general.

With the Motive HomeView client or the HomeView portal, subscribers can set up, activate, support, and manage their wired or wireless home networks. If deployed with Customer Service Manager, the HomeView client sends telemetry to Motive server so that it is available to the CSR (customer support representative) in the CSR Console to use in assisted service requests.

The type of client that provides the HomeView application. Subscribers use the HomeView client to manage their home network through a visual representation of the network. By default, this client also integrates with self-service and assisted service, allowing subscribers to receive alerts and escalate issues to a CSR.
A location, such as a coffee shop, restaurant, or airport, that offers Wi-Fi access, either at no cost or for a fee.
Multi-port hardware that connects devices, either wireless, wired, or both, to a network.

Definition of an icon and associated ToolTip for appearance in the notification area. The System Tray application supports multiple icon states. This enables displaying an icon and associated ToolTip that are appropriate to a particular condition. Icon states are defined through registry settings.
Registry entry that identifies the vendor or application ID associated with the System Tray application executable.

One of a collection of workflows that provide the basic framework for client operations. For example, the Online Dispatcher workflow handles client requests for any online workflow (except the Online Service Alert workflow). Developers configure and brand infrastructure workflows, but they do not customize these workflows.

An application that provides Mcci ActiveX install and uninstall support. InstallHelper is installed automatically by every Mcci reference installer package and by every package generated by the McciInstallerGen utility. InstallHelper is used transparently during the installation process to perform tasks too complex for the installer scripting language. InstallHelper is also responsible for the Mcci ActiveX uninstall support provided by each Mcci installer.

A mechanism that controls the capabilities that a process (or other securable object) has on Windows Vista or later operating system. Also see low integrity, medium integrity, high integrity, and system integrity.
A subsection of a section in a dictionary.
In HomeView, a profile of the previously discovered network that is saved on the server.
The Activation workflow step that launches the online Activation webflow.

In the Motive Data Mart, line of business is a mechanism for segregating subscribers into arbitrary groups such as residential versus business subscribers for reporting purposes. The data that populates these reports is stored in the LINE_OF_BUSINESS table in the Data Mart schema. The details of how this mechanism is used is deployment specific.

Motive Service that writes entries to a log file for each service and application. The entries provide information to a Motive system administrator. Before writing entries to the log file, the Tracing service filters them based on entry points and categories of information.
A page that performs the business logic of a flow.

The integrity level on Windows Vista or later operating system normally associated with Internet Explorer protected mode and is the most restrictive level. Processes running in low integrity have very limited access to the file system and registry and cannot persist any meaningful changes to the system.
The steps of the Activation workflow that use the Offline Flow Architecture. This includes all steps except the Prequalification step.

A collection of attributes used to define the telemetry to collect or set on a subscriber system, the expected and optimal values, and the values to encode in the diagnostic code. You can use different settings for different segments of prospective subscribers.
A Motive script object API that helps implement the Service Activation Manager (SAM) 6.x Activation workflow. The MCAA API is built upon the Motive Mcci ActiveX controls.
The Motive scriptable ActiveX API that you can use to interact with computers running Microsoft Windows.

The next generation of MotiveBrowser. McciBrowser is a standalone browser application you can bundle in a client installer. The advantage of using McciBrowser is that it is a trusted container for the Mcci ActiveX controls, and you can execute it in hidden mode. Even when scripting is disabled for Internet Explorer on the subscriber system, the McciBrowser performs scripting.

A Motive ActiveX control that runs as a part of the Service Management Client on the subscriber system. McciContext stores the service alerts on the subscriber file system and performs client-side filtering to determine when to display an alert.
A Motive ActiveX control that allows workflow developers to persist ROI events being gathered when the client is offline.
An application that executes a series of executables defined in its XML configuration file.

An application that allows the Activation flow to run an offline Prequalification step to properly update the system before running the main Activation workflow. For example, the Prequalification step can install the appropriate version of the ActiveX controls and perform other operations such as installing Flash. McciInitializer first determines if the operating system is the correct version, which is Windows Vista or later for Service Activation Manager (SAM) 6.x, and provides a mechanism for dealing with legacy operating systems.

A self-contained command-line tool for generating deployment packages for Mcci ActiveX installation scenarios. The tool conforms to the rules and restrictions associated with deploying Mcci ActiveX controls within Motive client solutions. Motive Workbench provides a user interface to McciInstallerGen with its Content Bundle and Client Installer editors.

A tool that takes snapshots of the system state based on a profile definition. McciScriptProfiler can update snapshots and restore the configuration contained in a snapshot to the application or operating system. McciScriptProfiler can also compare the current application or system state against the latest profile snapshot and indicate to the calling process whether the profile snapshot is up-to-date.

An application that starts a program at a specified integrity level on Windows Vista and later operating systems. McciShim can be used in shortcuts, test scripts, or anywhere an executable can be run.

The standard integrity level on Windows Vista or later operating system at which all processes started by the user (or on behalf of the user) run. This integrity level provides read and write access to everything owned by the user, but restricts access to locations in the file system and registry that are managed by the operating system, and prevents system-wide configuration changes.
A custom action that the System Tray application runs as a result of a subscriber selecting the corresponding menu item text from the menu.

The type of client that provides enough features to enable portal solutions but does not provide the full set of features that the full client provides, such as the System Tray application and support for service alerts.
The Activation workflow step that determines whether the subscribers machine meets the minimum requirements for the service provider.

Modulator/demodulator. A device that modulates an analog carrier signal to encode digital data and demodulates the signal to decode the transmitted data. Modems can transmit data using analog lines or wireless technology over cellular networks.

The Modem Selection step determines the residential gateway (RGW) being used by the modem, the network type of the RGW (USB or Ethernet), whether the RGW supports wireless, and whether the user is activating the first PC for wired activation or the second PC for wireless client activation.

The n number of Managed Servers installed in the Motive environment. From the Administration Server, Motive product installers install a product on each host in the MotiveCluster. The software and functionality on each Managed Server instance is identical, and the number of instances depends on the load the deployment needs to support.
A WebLogic Server domain created by the Motive platform installer. The MotiveDomain is made up of an Administration Server and the MotiveCluster.

Motive Service module that enables subscribers to set up, activate, support and manage their own wired or wireless home networkincluding resource sharing. With Motive Home Networking Service Module, providers can offer a cost-effective, managed home networking service that can generate revenue and serve as a platform for future services in the home. removed "security" for now since not provided by HomeView yet. 12/1/05 MK

Software infrastructure that provides the interoperability, scalability, and performance for the Motive High-Speed Data products and solutions deployed. The platform runs in a BEA WebLogic Server domain that includes a WebLogic Administration Server and a cluster of Managed Servers. Formally, the Motive platform is referred to as the Motive Support Platform.

The Motive technology that provides the means of exposing functionality on the Managed Servers in the Motive environment. The Motive services are a collection of APIs for working with different products. Different products use different collections of these services.

The Motive client that subscribers can use to initiate a connection with a Wi-Fi (WLAN) or a dial-up (WWAN) network. The Motive client allows connection information to be saved in a profile and used for future connections. For Wi-Fi networks, the Motive client can detect access points that are broadcasting, regardless of whether a profile exists for the network. A dial-up profile must be used to connect to a dial-up network because there is no way to poll for available dial-up networks like you can for Wi-Fi networks. In managing profiles, subscribers can define a default connection and rank the profiles to be used for connection attempts during auto-connection.

An Eclipse-based tool that deployment teams use to create and publish subscriber attribute directories, content bundles, and managed settings. This tool also allows you to create client installers that install the content bundles.
An SMP installation in which there are multiple clusters installed. Each of the clusters are configured to use the same SMP Database.

A multi-screen software platform that enables service providers to manage and orchestrate the marketing, retailing and delivery of all their content (applications, video, music, ringtones, information, and so on) and content services to end users on any screen based on individual preferences, thereby integrating and enhancing the end users experience.

An SMP site in which n number of SMP installations are running at different geographical locations. Typically, a multi-site deployment implements either active-active geographical redundancy or active-passive redundancy.

Microsoft Windows specification for how communication protocol programs (such as TCP/IP) and network device drivers should communicate. At the Microsoft web site, see Networking and Wireless Technologies.
The Activation workflow step that configures the adapter for DHCP or static IP addresses.

A standard part of the Microsoft Windows desktop. Under the default settings, the notification area appears in the lower-right corner of the desktop to the immediate right of the taskbar. The current time appears in the notification area. Typically, icons for particular applications also appear in the notification area. Motive clients can be configured to have a presence in the notification area.
Offline workflow that attempts to repair connectivity issues between the subscriber machine and the provider network.

Collection of offline content files that are bundled into the vendor application intended for particular subscriber systems. Ultimately, the files are stored locally on the subscriber system. The makeup of the Offline Content bundle varies depending on the target subscribers and use cases supported in the deployment. For example, the Offline Content bundle of the full client includes these file types:
Applicable managed setting and profile definitions.
Templates for displaying service alerts.
The deployment-specific files of the Offline Dispatcher, Offline Escalation, and Offline Connectivity Assistant workflows, including HTML, script, CSS, and image files.
Mcci scripts needed to enable the client.
Instrumentation files containing methods used to collect and set telemetry. The supporting files of any offline solution workflows included in the client installation should also be included in this bundle.
Offline workflow that determines if connectivity to the provider network and Internet is available, and routes a workflow request to the appropriate offline workflow or to the Online Dispatcher.
The escalation page that generates a diagnostic code for disconnected subscribers. This page is stored locally on the client.

Offline workflow that allows the subscriber to escalate an issue by using the Offline Escalation Phone Page. This workflow collects telemetry data (storing it locally) and generates a diagnostic code that the subscriber can relay to the CSR over the phone.
An architecture that provides the framework for producing offline flows for the Service Activation Manager (SAM) and the Self-Service Manager (SSM).

The part of the Report Agent that is responsible for invoking the Online Report Agent Webflow. The Offline Report Agent checks connectivity and attempts to send data to the server by using the Online Report Agent Webflow. If the user cancels the flow and connectivity is still available, the Offline Report Agent may be able to send the data. If the data cannot be sent, the Offline Report Agent attempts to send the data at each reboot up to a maximum number of attempts.

Offline workflow that sends a request to the Online Service Alert workflow to determine if any valid offline alerts should be downloaded for the subscriber. The Offline Service Alert workflow then filters any downloaded alerts and registers them with McciContext for processing.
A workflow deployed on the subscriber system.

A self-service workflow that solves a problem or completes a task on the client system. A one-click fix is a particular type of solution workflow designed for relatively quick execution. For example, the Clear Browser History one-click fix allows subscribers to clear their browser history.

Online workflow that handles client requests for any online workflow (except the Online Service Alert workflow). Each time the Online Dispatcher workflow is invoked, it runs the Endpoint Registration, Event Upload, and Update workflows before running the target workflow.
The escalation page that allows connected subscribers to escalate an issue to the CSR by using the chat service. This page executes automatic telemetry submission.
The escalation page that allows connected subscribers to escalate an issue to the CSR by using the phone. This page executes automatic telemetry submission.

Online workflow that allows the subscriber to escalate an issue by using either the Online Escalation Phone Page or Online Escalation Chat Page. This workflow collects telemetry data and sends it to the back-end.

The webflow that registers the subscriber if the subscriber has not previously registered. Then, the webflow persists a profile of system information to the database. Finally, the webflow persists the report data XML to the database.

para.remark: this may change in SAM 6.1 and be done by the Activation online webflow

glossdef.para: Online workflow that receives a request from the Offline Service Alert workflow to determine if any valid offline alerts should be downloaded for the subscriber. The Online Service Alert workflow sends the request to the Alert service, which obtains and filters the alerts; then, the Online Service Alert workflow sends the valid alerts to the Offline Service Alert workflow.
A workflow deployed on a server in the Motive environment. Subscriber systems access and run online workflows through the Web.
WLAN authentication that does not require a security key. Non-encrypted WLANs have open authentication. Open authentication is completely insecure.

The exact values that the provider deems optimal for the hardware and software settings on a prospective subscriber system. Usually, providers define optimal values for a subset of the telemetry values to be collected. By comparing optimal values with the actual values, the CSR Console can expose data for accelerated diagnosis and resolution.

Also called a PCMCIA Card. A credit-card sized, removable interface designed for laptop computers. Standardized by the Personal Computer Memory Card International Association (PCMCIA), the PC Card is used to provide many kinds of devices, such as network adapters, modems, and hard disks. Compare to ExpressCard.
Ongoing client activity that occurs on subscriber systems in the background. Persistent tasks are initiated by the System Tray application based on the registry configuration.

The Activation workflow step that guides the subscriber through the process of updating the system to ensure that it is properly set up for the main Activation workflow. For example, this step can install the appropriate version of the ActiveX controls and perform any other necessary operations such as installing Flash. The Prequalification step uses McciInitializer to perform this operation.
Named collection of wireless settings for connecting a WNIC to a particular wireless access point or for connecting a wireless dial-up modem to a WWAN.

An XML definition template that describes the different configuration values for McciScriptProfiler to collect when taking a snapshot of the system state. The XML definition template may also make use of additional helper files containing JavaScript. The group of associated definition and helper files comprises the profile definition.
An archive file containing a collection of related application or operating system configuration settings, registry settings and files.

Online workflow that reads all profile definitions stored on the client and calls McciScriptProfiler to compare the most recent profile snapshot against the current settings. If the settings differ, the Profile workflow launches the workflow responsible for the profile definition to determine whether to update the snapshot.
The Activation workflow step that performs a reboot. This step can be called at any time during the main Activation flow steps.

Database in Microsoft Windows operating systems. The registry stores data about the user, the installed programs and applications, and the specific hardware. The following list identifies common parts of the registry:
First level items are system-defined and referred to as subtrees. For example: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
The next level is defined by developers. This level is referred to as a key.
All subsequent levels or levels below keys are referred to as subkeys.
An entire subkey path is referred to as a subkey, not a path. For example, a Motive subkey is:
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Motive\Rainier\vendor\McciTrayApp
In a subkey, the items in the Name column are entries, and the items in the Data column are values.
Online workflow that allows CSRs to use the remote control feature of the CSR Console to access a subscriber's computer to help resolve configuration problems over the Internet.

The component that sends ROI events defined by the flow developer and generated by the offline Activation workflow to the server. The Report Agent consists of the Report Agent Helper, Offline Report Agent, and Online Report Agent Webflow.
The McaaScriptReportAgentHelper object that converts the ReportData array of key-value pairs to an XML file and then invokes the Offline Report Agent.

Event data from a workflow, offline alert, or installation sent to the server and stored initially in the OLTP database, but copied by the ETL (extract, transform, load) process to the Motive Data Mart and used to create reports and populate the service metrics dashboard. ROI events are distinct from logging data used for troubleshooting the system. ROI events are also referred to as stats.

A top-level division of a dictionary in the Offline Flow Architecture. The dictionary has sections for global data, step configuration data, step data, step errors, and report data. Sections also refer to the top-level divisions in the controller and dictionary XML files.

The host at which subscriber and CSR desktops meet to establish a secure tunnel. Through the tunnel, CSRs can conduct a remote control session in which they control the subscriber system temporarily with the express permission of the subscriber.
The Secure Tunneling Gateway host is located in the DMZ of the Motive environment. Tectia server software is installed on each Secure Tunneling Gateway.

Motive Service that allows for direct socket connections to be made between CSR computes and subscriber computers. The Secure Tunneling service is the service that some solution flows and the CSR Console use to implement remote control.

The string of characters encrypted and decrypted to allow transmission of data between a WNIC and a WLAN or wireless access point.
WEP security keys are:
A security phrase such as My first dog was Truman.
A 40-bit hexadecimal string (10 characters) such as FDEA0928FA.
104-bit hexadecimal string (26 characters) such as 06e73cf43e98479dd0d5c25746.
The hexadecimal string cannot contain spaces and must include only the characters 0 through 9 and A through F.
WPA-PSK and WPA2-PSK security keys are always security phrases. The phrase must include a minimum of 8 characters and maximum of 63 characters.

Motive product that automates problem diagnosis, resolution, and service management capabilities across each of the primary support channelselectronic, phone, and email. With Motive software, subscribers can easily self-manage their IP-based services without engaging a CSR (customer support representative) or requiring a technician visit.

Motive product that automates service activation for broadband subscribers. The Service Activation Manager software enables subscribers to turn up high-speed data and IP-based services without having to call a customer service representative (CSR) or request an onsite technician visit. The software can offer and fulfill IP-based services during activation events and increase adoption rates for existing and new services. Motive configures all necessary elements of an IP-based service through multiple fulfillment models, including web-only (or CD-less), CD-only, or a combination CD and web solution.

Electronic notifications for subscribers. In the Service Alerts Console, you define built-in filtering per service alert such that the alert only downloads to and appears on the desktops of affected subscribers.
Browser-based interface for creating and storing service alerts. In addition, you use the interface to create alert templates and alert groups.
An instance of the WebLogic Managed Server that is running Motive product and or service module software. Before Motive software is installed, the Managed Server only includes WebLogic software.

The Motive application server that is on n number of hosts behind a firewall. The Service Delivery Server is an installation of all Motive interfaces, services, and infrastructure associated with Motive consumer products. In a Motive environment, the Service Delivery Server hosts are clones that have identical functionality. All interactions with an Service Delivery server are targeted at a load balancer.

A subject area to which both a subscriber chat request and a CSR are associated. Through the Talisma Agent Client, a CSR logs into his or her service lines and subsequently receives prompts to accept chat escalation requests. These requests originate from subscribers assigned to one of the CSR's service lines.

You create service lines through the Talisma CIM Channels Administrator interface. Typically, service lines are associated with particular geographic regions such as East and West or service types such as Gold and Silver.

A Motive client application (.exe file) that contains the content bundles intended for particular subscriber systems. The Service Management Client runs problem diagnostics and repair scripts through offline and online solution workflows. In addition, depending on the deployment, subscribers use the client to access provider portals.
The content in Service Management Clients is fully brandable and deployment-specific based on the use cases supported and desired customizations.

Motive provides the following types of clients that deployment teams use as a starting point for creating production clients: full client, minimal client, diagnostic encoding-only client, and HomeView client

Motive service modules that help providers execute on their strategies to roll out and manage new services in the digital home. Service modules are:
Packaged, service-specific functionality for subscribers, marketing, operations, and call center personnel.
Solution-specific workflows, user interfaces, and integrations that help providers address the management challenges with next-generation IP services, such as IPTV, home networking, mobility, and online security.
Based on best practices defined from working with providers in their efforts to bring new services to market.
Browser-based interface for configuring server properties. From the Services Configuration Console, application administrators can configure global properties and host-specific properties.
One-click fix workflow that empties the History folder for Internet Explorer.
One-click fix workflow that sets the default home page for Internet Explorer.
The component of Motive's IPTV Service Module that resides on the set-top box.
An SMP installation in which there is one cluster configured to use an SMP Database solely for that cluster.
An SMP site in which n number of SMP installations are running at the same geographical location.

A type of workflow that resolves a particular problem or completes a task on a subscriber system. For example, the Email Assistant workflow repairs, tests, and profiles email accounts within the installed email clients (Outlook and/or Outlook Express) as well as creates new email accounts within the currently installed default email client.

A screen that appears briefly when an application starts and then automatically times out (the timeout is configurable). The splash screen can display whatever content is needed before the user views the main content of the application. The content in the splash screen is DHTML (HTML/JavaScript). For example, McciInitializer allows a splash screen to be displayed when it starts.
A custom action that the System Tray application runs when it starts up.

A unit of a flow in the Offline Flow Architecture that performs a specific task. A step usually has logic and display pages associated with it, but it can have only a logic page. A step can have multiple display pages. The order of steps in a flow can be easily rearranged. Steps that are not listed in the flow order can be called as branch steps.

Data used to associate other objects and actions with a specific entity. For example, event information on the use of a solution workflow by a subscriber and the subscriber's registered endpoints are associated with the subscriber's subject. A CSR who launches the CSR Console is associated with a subject, and the actions that CSR takes in the Motive system (to resolve the subscriber's problem) are recorded as events associated with the analyst's subject.
Motive Service that provides a method for creating and looking up subjects within the system.

The server-based and managed settings-based values that affect the subscriber chat experience, including the applicable Talisma CIM Channels Server host address, service line, regather subscriber system telemetry interval, and client queuing polling interval. Some deployments require a single subscriber chat configuration while others require several.
Motive Service that provides an interface to an external subscriber database to enable querying for subscriber data. The Subscriber service also manages client endpoints.
Reserved for system services on Windows Vista or later operating system. This integrity level has the highest privileges and provides the same capabilities as a high-integrity process plus more.

The resident application for a Windows-based Motive client that runs on a subscriber system. The System Tray application controls all client activity, including the running of persistent tasks and custom actions. It is designed for full branding and configuration. You can deploy Motive clients with a System Tray application that runs in the background or provides for client presence in the notification area.

The graphical user interface (GUI) that CSRs use to chat with subscribers and to access subscriber system telemetry. There are two versions of the interface, an executable for installation on the CSR desktop and a Java client that the CSR accesses through a URL. The Java client is hosted by the Talisma CIM Channels Server.

The graphical user interface (GUI) that Talisma application administrators use to manage the chat solution. From the Talisma CIM Channels Administrator interface, application administrators and CSR supervisors can manage user accounts and service lines.

The OLTP (online transaction processing) schema for the Talisma CIM Channels Server and chat solution. The Talisma CIM Channels Server stores all server transaction and configuration data and chat usage statistics in the Talisma CIM Channels Database.

The server application installed on a Windows host in the Motive environment. The Talisma CIM Channels Server processes all chat escalation requests. It receives chat requests from the Chat workflow running on subscriber systems from the MotiveCluster; assigns requests to the applicable service lines based on the service line ID in a request; and prompts an available CSR to accept requests. Upon accepting, the CSR can initiate conversation with the subscriber.

A state engine used in HomeView to manage task execution. For example, HomeView establishes a connection to a remote file share, then displays a dialog box when the task is initiated if a TaskEngine is used. During task execution, the progress is updated in the dialog box; the task can take a variable amount of time depending on network conditions and computer processor speed. When the task completes, the dialog box is removed.

Motive Service that provides an API for applications to use for submitting telemetry to the server. Examples of these applications are a solution workflow and FIXME. The Telemetry service handles telemetry as a single file, with attachments, or that representing home networking topology.
The Activation workflow step that thanks the user for choosing this product.
A custom action that the System Tray application runs at a specific date/time.
A WPA protocol designed to protect against attacks common to WEP-based WLANs. The enhancements include key mixing, message integrity, rekeying, and initialization vector protection.

Motive Service that writes entries to a trace log file for each service and application. The entries recorded are exceptions or other development-specific information intended for Motive employees for diagnosing low-level problems. Before writing entries to the log file, the Tracing service filters them based on entry points and categories of information. The Tracing service is built on the Apache log4j package.
A type of workflow that requires the subscriber move to another PC to complete the remaining portion of the workflow.
A custom action that the System Tray application runs as a result of a subscriber double-clicking the corresponding icon in the notification area.
Online workflow that notifies the server if the client is uninstalled.
Online workflow that updates a client by detecting changes to the bundles on the server and downloading these changes to the client.
The Activation workflow step that installs the USB driver if the network type is USB.
A modem that plugs into the USB port of a computer.

A security enhancement on Windows Vista or later operating system used to manage user accounts. All standard users (including administrators) have restricted privileges, making it impossible for processes that are running under a standard user account to modify sensitive locations in the file system and registry directly, or to affect system-wide configuration. Instead, an application that needs to make such system modifications must go through a process called elevation. This process prompts the user to confirm whether the application should be allowed to perform the actions that must be executed in an elevated context. Also see integrity level.
The Activation workflow step that gathers subscriber information and, if applicable, technician information.

A 128-bit number used to uniquely identify some object or entity on the Internet. A UUID contains a reference to the network address of the host that generated the UUID, a timestamp, and a randomly generated component.

A workflow deemed by a given customer to provide a return on their investment in the Motive system. In the Motive Data Mart, certain reports break out data from valued workflows run, as opposed to all workflows run.
A mechanism that tells Mcci where to retrieve and store files and registry settings regardless of the process integrity level. Also see virtualization.

A channel on the set-top box that provides access to content from the set-top box agent to self-remediate a set-top box malfunction, view help content, and generate a diagnostic code that can be provided in the context of a voice workflow.

A security feature of Windows Vista or later operating system in which restricted file system and registry locations are virtualized into other areas and the application accesses these areas instead. Virtualization is a short-term solution that Microsoft will eventually remove. It is only provided to give software vendors time to modify their applications to work properly on Vista and beyond. Also see virtual data control.

A workflow deployed on the Voice server through which subscribers initiate self-service requests, some of which may be escalated to assisted service requests. Voice workflows are also referred to as voice flows.
