A security protocol for Wi-Fi networks. WEP was designed to provide about the same level of security to that expected of wired networks. It is available in 40-bit and 104-bit encryption modes. WEP protocol uses a static encryption key, which makes it vulnerable to hacking tools.
See the WEP specification in the IEEE Wi-Fi standard, 802.11b.
Compare to WPA and WPA2.
Radio-frequency spectrum for transmitting and receiving voice, data, and video signals for communications.
A WLAN transceiver that can connect a network to one or many wireless devices. APs can also bridge to each other.
The Activation workflow step that sets up the wireless client.
A type of modem that uses cellular networks to transfer data. Wireless dial-up modems are available as PC Cards, ExpressCards, and USB modems.

A type of wireless AP. Wireless gateways provide an access point for wireless devices in addition to providing NAT and DHCP. They may also provide VPN support, roaming, firewalls, and different types of security.
Compare with residential gateway.

Wi-Fi client hardware that communicates with wireless APs or gateways. There are several variations of WNICs, including:
Cards that fit into slots on laptops (also referred to as wireless cards or Wi-Fi cards).
Modules embedded into a laptop or desktop.
USB-based Wi-Fi radios.

JavaScript code that provides the logic for the pre-processing and post-processing phases of a workflow. A workflow wrapper allows developers to modify the behavior of a workflow without changing the workflow itself.Assume it's JavaScript, but check. Mention Client Queueing Service based vs. non-CSQ based?
Two or more computers networked together in a peer-to-peer network.

The second-generation Wi-Fi security protocol for protecting data over WLANs. WPA provides better data encryption than WEP. A variation of WPA is WPA with a Pre-Shared Key (WPA-PSK), which uses a static key or security phrase as with WEP. WPA-PSK uses the shared key to negotiate a temporary key used for the connection. That temporary key is typically renegotiated at a time interval specified by the access point. WPA-PSK can use either TKIP or AES-CCMP to encrypt the keys.

WPA is required to support TKIP encryption, but it may also support AES. AES encryption has more intense hardware requirements so many older access points cannot support AES because the hardware itself cannot. Access points with newer hardware typically only need a firmware update to support AES.
A wireless computer network that can span a wide geographical area. A WWAN uses cellular networks to transfer data. Compare to WLAN (wireless local area network).
An open platform for developers and sysadmins to build, ship, and run distributed applications, whether on laptops, data center virtual machines (VMs), or the cloud.
A tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications.
A stateless, highly scalable server side application that stores and lets you distribute Docker images.

Recording of all activity instances performed for the subscriber account in Customer Service Console (CSC). The account history includes entries for each activity instance performed during the current session and the instances from previous sessions for the same account.

A type of diagnostic for implementing programmatic changes in subscriber environments or on other systems affecting their services. In Customer Service Console (CSC), several types can surface, including component actions, general actions, and recommended actions.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), the unique instance of a task performed either proactively or automatically for a subscriber account. Most activity types are recorded in the account history, including each diagnostic, interactive workflow, and operation execution; tool selection; and session log.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a type of action that surfaces only in the context of a detected issue on the network map.

An SMP browser-based application in which CSRs create sessions to assist subscribers. The console has several customer assistance facilities in which to run deployment-specific content, such as diagnostics, operations, and interactive workflows.

A Motive product for reducing call handle times through presentation of root cause analyses and remediation options to CSRs. The CSC is built on the Service Management Platform (SMP), which provides a server runtime environment and several design-time tools, modeling data sources, and Web services in addition to the Motive Reporting application.

The test groups configured for automatic execution at session creation in the Customer Service Console (CSC). The same service operations that form a part of the Dashboard startup groups should also be included in the startup group to run at session creation.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a summary on a specific problem identified from executing a diagnostic. Detected issues may include instructions, component actions, and recommended actions.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), an individual test or action for execution on behalf of subscriber accounts.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a type of action that is available for execution at any time during a CSC session.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a group of health check diagnostics for execution on behalf of subscriber accounts.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a visual description and other information about the identified endpoints and components associated with the subscriber's network.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), a programmatic function for execution on an endpoint. For example, an operation might retrieve the full description and current settings for a residential gateway or reboot the device.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a type of action that surfaces only in the context of a detected issue or within the full results of a given diagnostic.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), a specific time period in which a CSR assisted a subscriber. A session begins upon entering valid subscriber information, after which the startup group runs automatically; the session ends upon proactively ending the session or logging off.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), recording of the activity instances performed during a particular session. The current session history does not include the session log because the log is not stored until the session ends.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a log including details the CSR chooses to document before ending a session. The content is saved to the session and later stored in the database at session end.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), a standard test group configured for automatic execution at session creation. The individual diagnostics in the startup group are executed based on system roles. If the logged-in CSR and the diagnostic do not have a system role in common, the diagnostic is not executed with the startup group.

In Customer Service Console (CSC), one or more related diagnostics intended for some collective purpose. For example, a test group might include several diagnostics with which to determine the current quality of service.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), hyperlinks to, or instructions for, an external utility.
In Customer Service Console (CSC), a standard test group configured with one or more general actions that a CSR can proactively execute from the Customer Service Console (CSC).
A list that maps handsets to subscription groups in an enterprise femtocell deployment to control access privileges to femtocell access points.
The solution that includes Home Device Manager, Intelligent Workflow Engine, the Femtocell Service Management Template, Service Operations Module, and typically one or more external business systems.

The URL to which CPE are configured to issue requests for the Home Device Manager environment. Typically, the ACS URL is the address for a load balancer. The load balancer fronts either the Bootstrap Servers or the Device Management (DM) Servers, depending on the activation status of the device. Ultimately, all CPE managed by Home Device Manager get provisioned to contact the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) on a Device Management (DM) Server.
As a part of installing the Administration Server, you define the ACS URL. In that context, the URL is for the load balancer that fronts the Device Management (DM) Servers.
The wrapper for a protocol-specific function run on a device. All actions contain protocol-specific functions, and all policies contain actions.

The state of a device when it has a record in the DEVICE table, has all of the correct parameters set and validated by the OSS, is ready to provide a particular service (such as Femto VoIP), and is fully operable by HDM; that is, operators may queue actions and functions on the device

An event that is created within Home Device Manager when a TR-069 device is fully preactivated. When a policy receives an activation event for which it has been listening, the policy can queue actions on targeted devices.
In TR-069 compliant devices, active notifications are Value Change Inform messages sent to the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) immediately when a specified parameter is modified.
An alarm type mapped to a script in the Intelligent Workflow Engine. The script is triggered and run when an alarm of the specified type is raised for a specified OUI/product class combination.
A framework that facilitates distributed processing of large data sets across clusters of machines using a simple programming model.

A data warehousing infrastructure based on Hadoop. Hive enables easy data summarization, ad-hoc querying and analysis of large volumes of data. It provides a simple query language called Hive QL, which is based on SQL. Hive QL enables users to do ad-hoc querying, summarization and data analysis easily.
A platform for analyzing large sets of data that consist of a high-level language for expressing data analysis programs, coupled with infrastructure for evaluating these programs.

The Home Device Manager application servers and OLTP database installed in a trusted network. The application tier is common to all deployments including standard deployments. The application servers make up the HDMDomain with an Administration Server and the HDMCluster.

A directory of high-level attributes used by the HDM CSR Console Plugin code to select the appropriate managed settings for particular operations and device types. The attribute directory structure is similar to LDAP or the Windows file system in its hierarchical usage. By using the Motive Workbench, you can import, customize, and publish the attribute directory shipped with the HDM CSR Console Plugin.

The protocol server component installed on each Managed Server. The ACS processes messages to and from devices in subscriber environments. It handles all device communication from the application tier in a standard deployment.

TR-069 devices send the ACS Inform messages regularly, receive commands called from the ACS, and respond to the ACS with results. The ACS can send TR-069 devices unsolicited messages (connection requests) requesting them to initiate a new session with the server. By contrast, SNMP devices and the ACS use a push model to interact: The ACS sends requests to SNMP devices, and the devices respond. Unlike TR-069 devices, SNMP devices do not continually send Inform messages to the ACS, and an Inform message is not required to run actions from the action queue on them.
On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that is sent to the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) upon completing an autonomous file upload or download.

An optional HDM feature that creates preprovisioned data for zero-touch devices. This feature is a special case of the zero-touch activation scenario, which allows preprovisioning of some of the device data while the device identity remains unprovisioned. In the Autoregistration Module activation scenario, you do not need to preprovision a serial number, OUI, and product class. So any device, regardless of the type and serial number, can register in this way. However, this depends on how the customer defines the correlator. The customer could include this information in the correlator, but this feature gives the customer a choice.

An HTTP authentication scheme in which the user name and password of the client are sent to the server in base64-encoded format. The server authenticates the client based on the user name and password sent in the header. See RFC 1945.

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, a message that is sent whenever the CPE is booted up or reset. The message does not provide information about how long the CPE has been attached to the current network environment, or whether or not the CPE has ever been activated.

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, a message that is sent the first time the device is installed, after the device is factory reset, or after the device's management server URL has been changed. Whenever a device contacts the Home Device Manager server with this message, the HDM server evaluates the activation status of the device. If the device uses the Bootstrap Server during activation, and the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) URL has been changed on the device to contact the Device Management (DM) Server, HDM waits for the device to send a Bootstrap Inform message indicating that the ACS URL was changed, and then HDM activates the device. If the device does not use the Bootstrap Server during activation, HDM immediately activates the device. Bootstrap Inform messages are sent continuously until Home Device Manager successfully acknowledges and processes them.
If a device is activated already, a Bootstrap Inform message deactivates the device, and the device must go through the activation process again. HDM treats this as a factory reset.

Type of Managed Server in the HDMCluster that not fully-provisioned CPEs communicate with initially. After authenticating, CPEs in the walled garden are redirected to a Device Management (DM) Server. Bootstrap Servers authenticate incoming CPE requests with a default user name and password for the associated device type. If the Bootstrap Server is configured for pass-through authentication, the CPE can authenticate without credentials.
The Bootstrap Server is also referred to as the Walled Garden Server.
Compare to Device Management (DM) Server.

A device at the core of an ISP's (Internet service provider's) network that routes traffic to and from the digital subscriber line access multiplexers (DSLAM) and aggregates user sessions from the access network. The ISP can use the BRAS for policy management and IP Quality of Service (QoS) policies.
Source.

A database record comprised of attribute and parameter values that have been configured or set on a device during device management. This record is updated each time a device contacts the server with value changes and whenever an operator or the Northbound Interface (NBI) executes an action on the device that modifies a parameter or attribute on the device. When any of these events occur, the device's old cached data parameters and attributes are updated with the latest values. The cached data record can be purged manually using Vathsala - HDM 3766 - replaced the term 'cleanup script' with 'purging script'.the purging script. Similarly, when you replace a device type, the cached data records of affected devices are invalidated. The invalidated cached data record remains temporarily until the affected device contacts the server with value changes or until an operator or the NBI executes an action on the device that modifies a parameter or attribute on the device.

An optional feature that forces a networked HTTP client to be redirected to a specified web page (for example, for registration or billing) before being released to interact with the Internet normally. Using HDM, you can set a whitelist argument that specifies the host for this web page in order to allow the client request to be redirected there. Typically, devices allow multiple host names and IP subnets to be whitelisted.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.In custom functions, a compound parameter with a protocol-specific meaning. Complex parameters are Request DTOs, which benefit from a special rendering in the HDM Management Console. The console provides specific forms to assist users in populating these parameters for a given protocol. For example, when FirmwareUpdateDTO is used as an input parameter, the HDM Management Console provides a list of managed firmware images from which to select. Other complex parameters include the RestoreDTO with a list of backups from which to select, the GetParameterValuesDTO with TR-069 parameters in a device type data model tree from which to select, and the SetParameterValuesDTO with TR-069 parameters in a device type data model tree from which to select, as well as type and value fields to fill out.
On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that occurs based on a request (ConnectionRequestURL method call) from the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) .
Web server that passes connection requests from the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) to a TR-069 device. In turn, the device sends an Inform message to the ACS.
glossdef.glossseealso: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) Connection Request Proxy Server

glossdef.para: A configurable array of strings used to identify a device in a zero-touch activation scenario. A correlator can include the IP address and MAC address of the device and other items that match the data model of the device type.

An industry standard for WAN-side configuration and management of devices such as gateways and modems. The CWMP, also referred to as TR-069, provides a framework for communication between CPEs and Auto-configuration Servers (ACSs) such as the ACS in Home Device Manager. The framework includes a mechanism for secure auto-configuration of a CPE and incorporates other CPE management functions. TR-069 establishes rules for how a CPE device communicates with and is managed by a remote management system.

A function written in JavaScript code that coordinates the execution of one or more primitive functions. A custom function accepts zero or more input parameters and returns one output parameter, which is of type JCFResult. The JCFResult object can contain a Response DTO. The input parameters passed to a custom function can be simple parameters or Request DTOs.

glossdef.remark: NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.
glossdef.para: A function that coordinates the execution of one or more primitive functions, which wrap TR-069 RPC methods. Home Device Manager provides several reference custom functions out of the box, and a toolkit that enables you tobut you can also create your own custom functions using theHDM Management Console.

ASz 6/17/2015 Replaced "standard" with "primitive"Custom functions can be run in the same way primitive functions are runthat is, as part of an action or on a device. Another term used for custom functions is multi-RPC functions.Other terms for custom functions are multi-RPC function and Java Custom Function.

glossentry.glossterm: custom multi-domain deployment (no longer supported as of 3.1)

glossdef.para: Home Device Manager architecture that includes two WebLogic Server domains, the HDMDistributedDomain (protocol tier) and the HDMDomain (application tier), installed on the same hosts all within the trusted network. The domains are separated by installing each on distinct interfaces attached to distinct subnets. Each domain includes a set of application server instances with only the HDMDomain configured to contact the Home Device Manager OLTP database. The initial CPE communication redirects from the protocol tier to the application tier. The primary purposes for a custom multi-domain deployment are to reduce hardware costs and to separate CPE traffic from user interface and Northbound Interface (NBI) traffic.
Compare to distributed domain deployment in which the HDMDistributedDomain is installed in a DMZ. Also, compare to standard deployment in which a HDMDistributedDomain is not installed at all.

Product that offers a highly scalable data collection and analysis system for the data collected from TR-069, OMA-DM and other similar devices managed by the Motive family of products. The Data Collection Manager splits data collection from the device management activities and hence is an independent module. It is positioned as a central data collection manager for the complete Motive portfolio and is device protocol agnostic.

glossdef.remark: NE: 11/15/2011. Definition created to address HDM-2617. Requested input from Hande Erdem. 11/16/2011: Writer's note: This glossentry comes from the common hdm-glossary. If you use this definition, please ensure that it is correct for your context. 11/28/2011: Updated with additional information provided by Hande Erdem and Filip Humble. 12/8/2011: Removed the following per Filip: "A deprecated item can be removed from the second major or minor release following the release in which the item became deprecated. For example, if an item is deprecated in HDM 4.0, the item is not removed from HDM 4.1; instead, the item may be removed from the next minor release, such as HDM 4.2, HDM 4.3, and so on, or removed from the next major release, such as HDM 5.0."
glossdef.para: A term describing an item, such as an NBI method, that is planned for removal in a subsequent release, that still works for a period of time for backward compatibility, and that should not be used for new development. Once an item is deprecated, users are encouraged not to use the item, but to use instead the new alternative solution, which is typically provided at the time the item is deprecated. Support continues for deprecated items as long as those items are not removed from the HDM product.
An indicator that a TR-069 device managed by HDM and enabled for alarms has experienced a communication-related anomaly, an operational anomaly, or a change in its configuration or status.
The list of device alarm definitions on the Alarms tab of the HDM Management Console.

A template that defines a type of device alarm. A device alarm definition describes the characteristics of the alarm such as its type and severity, and sets the automatic alarm-clearing behavior. Optionally, it can describe the expressions by which HDM determines whether an event should raise an alarm, for which devices, and if so, what action to take. Alarm administrators can create device alarm definitions from the HDM Management Console.

A filter that policies can use to target a subset of devices. Using a device group, you can filter for devices that fall within certain IP address ranges and have certain user tags, service tags, and device types. Each device group permits the associated policy to target only those devices that meet its criteria. If the policy applies additional filters, such as search criteria, the list of targeted devices is further narrowed.

Type of Managed Server in the HDMCluster that communicates with CPEs configured for activation. The DM Server instances run policies on the CPE to complete the activation process. On an ongoing basis, they implement policies on CPEs to keep them updated. Authenticating to a DM Server requires strict authentication including the device-specific credentials.
The DM Server is also referred to as the Public Server.
Compare to Bootstrap Server.
A collection of device types, user tags, service tags, and/or IP address ranges that define the devices that are part of a domain.

The definition of a class of devices based on the unique combination of the device manufacturer OUI and the product class. It contains a list of protocol-specific parameters that this class of devices accepts. A device type is a necessary component of devices and firmware images.

An XML schema created to represent a class of devices. A schema defines the device capabilities that can be managed by Home Device Manager. It includes the unique information that can create a device type template, which can be imported into Home Device Manager when a new device type is added to the system. A device type can have one or more data models, distinguished by software version. A data model can be associated with only one device type.

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that occurs to re-establish connection to the server after completing a diagnostic test initiated by the Auto-configuration Server (ACS).

An HTTP authentication scheme in which the server generates a challenge made up of some unpredictable data. The client uses a key based on the user's password to encrypt the challenge and sends the encrypted challenge back as a response. The server can then verify that the client possesses the correct password by decrypting the response using the stored password for that user. This process avoids the need to send the password in plain text and also avoids the overhead of an ongoing SSL session (although SSL could still be used if desired). See RFC 2617 for more information about Digest authentication.Adapted from .

glossentry.glossterm: distributed domain deployment (not supported as of 3.1)

glossdef.para: Home Device Manager architecture that includes two distinct WebLogic Server domains, the HDMDistributedDomain in the DMZ and the HDMDomain in the trusted network. The domains each include a cluster of application servers. In a distributed domain deployment, the initial CPE communication redirects from the application servers in DMZ to the ones in the trusted network.
Compare to standard deployment.

A group of Home Device Manager device management objects that are administered as a unit that represents a category appropriate to a business. Examples of such categories include all of the objects relating to a site, a region, or a service type, or all of the objects needed to administer devices within a given IP address range.

glossdef.remark: NE 11/30/2012, added frequent inform events per Serhat. Chains to domain_management_domain_aware_objects_table.xml in HDM content. If you change this glossary definition, change that object as well. NE: HDM-3645, 9/26/2012
glossdef.para: In the context of HDM Domain Management, an object that is associated with a given domain. The following objects are domain-aware objects: policies, actions, criteria templates, device types, firmware images, custom functions, alarm definitions, device groups, and frequent inform events.
In the context of HDM Domain Management, the overall structure of all domains in the HDM deployment.
See request DTO and response DTO.

A placeholder value that can be resolved to a device-specific, appropriate value at run time. It enables configuring device-specific preprovisioned parameters on a group of devices with a single instant-triggered or event-triggered policy.

ECS is a server component that provides a scalable solution for sending and receiving lightweight messages and events to and from multiple endpoints. These endpoints can be software clients running on consumer electronics devices (such as PCs, mobile phones, STBs, and RGWs) or OSS/BSS systems (including Motive HDM, Motive SMP and customer billing systems). For maximum flexibility HDM supports device activation, in an M2M environment, using an ECS.
Policy options that provide the ability to set service tags to given values after a policy has run successfully or unsuccessfully on a specific device.

A small cellular base station that is intended for use at home and in small businesses. The femtocell uses broadband (such as DSL or cable) for the backhaul connection to the service provider network. Femtocells offer subscribers improved coverage, often at a reduced cost, as well as new value-added services. Femtocells will offer service providers the ability to offload the macro network, increase mobile network capacity at a significantly lower cost, and a way to increase revenue and customer loyalty with better coverage and new value-added services.

A collection of Service Operations Module, Home Device Manager, and Intelligent Workflow Engine objects, such as service profiles, actions, device alarm definitions, custom functions, policies, workflow engine scripts, and device type data model XML files which support the activation and maintenance of femtocells through the Service Operations Module.
The solution that includes Home Device Manager, Intelligent Workflow Engine, the Femtocell Service Management Template, Service Operations Module, and typically one or more external business systems.

Femtocell-specific API customizations to the Service Operations Northbound Interface (NBI). For example, depending on the femtocell, Femtocell NBI Extensions might include methods that register handsets, replace access points, or mark access points stolen.
Also known as NBI Extensions for Femtocell.
The solution that includes Femtocell Business Logic and Femtocell NBI Extensions.

A collection of Home Device Manager and Intelligent Workflow Engine objects, such as actions, alarm definitions, custom functions, policies, workflow engine scripts, and device type data model XML files which support the activation and maintenance of femtocells through the Service Operations Module.

glossentry.glosssee: preprovisioned HDM and unprovisioned CPE activation
preprovisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: An operation that implements protocol-specific RPC (Remote Procedure Call) methods and can be run on a device. A function can be run as part of an action in bulk policies, or it can be applied to single devices on its own or as part of an action. Functions can be built-in or custom.
A programming model and software framework for developing applications that rapidly process vast amounts of data in parallel on large clusters of compute nodes.

The centerpiece of an HDFS file system. It keeps the directory tree of all files in the file system, and tracks where the file data is kept across the cluster. It does not store the data of these files itself.

The primary storage system used by Apache Hadoop applications. HDFS creates multiple replicas of data blocks and distributes them on compute nodes throughout a cluster to enable reliable, rapid computations.

A browser-based user interface associated with Home Device Manager that enables you to manage domains, as well as access the Services Configuration Console. With the HDM Administration Console, HDM domain administrators can control HDM Management Console user access to groups of policies, actions, firmware images, and/or devices using dynamic filter criteria (IP ranges, device types, user tags, and service tags).

Product that enables operators to collect large amounts of data from a variety of managed consumer devices, such as residential gateways, set-top boxes, and smart mobile devices and efficiently process them. It provides an analytics framework to enable linear filtering and data transformation. With protocol-agnostic capabilities, HDM Analytics Module is a scalable repository that provides the data required by any external data source, such as a device management system, to efficiently manage the subscriber's device.

The n number of Managed Servers in the application tier. The software and functionality on each Managed Server in the HDMCluster is identical, and the number of instances depends on the load the deployment must support.

A plugin that integrates Home Device Manager and the Motive Customer Service Manager's CSR Console. With this plugin, CSRs (customer support representatives) can troubleshoot and resolve subscriber CPE (customer premises equipment)-related issues as part of their problem-resolution flow. The device management capabilities of Home Device Manager enable CSRs to get and set configuration parameters, reboot CPE, and run diagnostics on CPE.

A Customer Support Representative (CSR) with access to the HDM Management Console and privileges to modify the configuration and firmware for a single device. The CSR role is used for service providers who wish to give their CSR personnel direct access to the HDM Management Console, as well as for integration with the Customer Service Manager application.

The n number of Managed Servers in the protocol tier. The software and functionality on each Managed Server in the HDMDistributedCluster is identical, and the number of instances depends on the load the deployment must support.

A WebLogic Server domain created by the protocol tier installer. The HDMDistributedDomain is made up of an Administration Server and the Managed Servers in the protocol tier. It is optional to install the Managed Servers into a cluster (HDMDistributedCluster).
A WebLogic Server domain created by the application tier installer. The HDMDomain is made up of an Administration Server and the HDMCluster.

The Home Device Manager DSA (data source adapter) is a software component of Home Device Manager that is intended to be used with the Customer Service Console. It abstracts communication with HDM to make authoring Service Management Platform (SMP) models easier. Rather than having to write a web service client to communicate with the HDM Northbound Interface (NBI), you create a model that uses the HDM data source.

The HDM DSA method makes web service calls to the NBIService deployed on the HDM Managed Servers. The NBIService provides an interface for executing single device operations and managing data in the HDM OLTP database.

Network Operations management personnel with access to the HDM Management Console and all the privileges available to the NetOps persona, along with the ability to manage policies and firmware images.

Front-line network operations personnel with access to the HDM Management Console and privileges to modify the configuration and firmware of CPE devices individually or using bulk operations. This persona also has the ability to create, read, update, and delete device definitions and current device settings.

A SOAP-based programming interface for HDM that integrates the application tier with that of applicable OSS (operations support systems) that maintain subscriber data. The NBI includes web services and notifications. The NBI web services component is a set of methods that an OSS or other third-party system invokes. By default, this communication happens over HTTPS; it is optional to configure the HDMCluster to expose the NBI over HTTP. The NBI notifications component is a set of asynchronous events sent from a Device Management (DM) Server (HDMCluster) to the OSS over the Java Messaging Protocol (JMS). The HDM Northbound Interface, or NBI, is also known as the Service Model NBI.

A web-based application that enables users to monitor Home Device Manager health metrics on each Managed Server, as well as globally over the entire HDMCluster. Monitoring results are stored in a round-robin database that handles time-series data, from which the dashboard generates graphs. The graphs, whose data can be exported, show views of Managed Server and cluster health data over a choice of time frames from JDBC, Northbound Interface (NBI), Southbound Interface (SBI), and server-related sources.

With the HDM Performance Dashboard, IT and application health administrators can monitor Managed Server and HDMCluster health status; view graphs of monitoring data over time; configure automated exporting of data; and view and analyze southbound traffic.
The HDM SaaS Package includes Software as a Service (SaaS) content for Home Device Manager, which provides actions, policies, and custom functions for activating and managing gateway devices.
The HDM Traffic Regulation module helps input throttling of Informs to the Home Device Manager in a controlled way that is more CWMP-aware than the basic load balancers.

A browser-based user interface that enables Home Device Manager administrators to view a list of users currently logged on to the HDM Management Console and to log users off the HDM Management Console if necessary.

A Nokia product that allows broadband providers to remotely manage CPE that support the TR-069 and SNMP protocols. Functionality includes policy-based tools to automate device configuration and management, ability to perform single as well as large-scale bulk device configuration, troubleshooting, firmware upgrades, event management, user management, communications logging, reporting, device alarm management, and device alarm monitoring.
The aggregate hardware and software dedicated to configuring and managing the CPE in subscriber homes and businesses across your network.

glossentry.glosssee: partially provisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: A message sent from a TR-069 device to establish communications with the Auto-configuration Server (ACS). This message serves to initiate the set of transactions requested and to communicate the limitations of the device with regard to message encoding.
An object passed as an argument in an ordered collection to a custom function. An input parameter can be either a simple parameter or a complex parameter.

An application that is installed on top of Home Device Manager that enables users to define workflows. Workflows assist in simplifying zero-touch activation integration, creating alarm extensions, creating policy extensions (associating policies with scripts), and configuring scripts to run unattended on schedules that users define. Each workflow relies on a script that is associated with a device type, alarm type, policy, or schedule. The IWE Workflow Administration Console provides the interface through which these Home Device Manager objects and schedules can be associated with scripts.

A unique number that identifies a mobile terminal such as a mobile phone or a femtocell access point. It identifies the physical device and has no relation to the subscriber. It is a 15 decimal digit number consisting of a Type Allocation Code (TAC), a serial number and a checksum.

A unique number that identifies a mobile phone or a femtocell access point. The IMSI is stored inside the SIM card of the phone or femtocell access point and cannot change. It consists of the Mobile country code (MCC), the Mobile network code (MNC), and the Mobile subscription identification number (MSIN).
A user interface through which Intelligent Workflow Engine users can associate a device type, alarm type, policy, or schedule with a script.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.The result returned by the execution of a primitive function or a custom function after the function is completed. A JCFResult contains a flag that indicates whether the custom function succeeded or failed. If the custom function failed, the JCFResult includes detailed fault information. If the custom function succeeded, the JCFResult contains a Response DTO A custom function developer must instantiate, populate, and return a JCFResult explicitly.
A pure Java-based HTTP client/server, WebSocket client/server and servlet container (Application server) developed as a free and open source project.

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, a one-time Inform message that indicates that the session was established for the purpose of web identity management and that a Kicked method will be called one or more times during this session. Note that this inform message type has been deprecated by the TR-069 CPE WAN Management Protocol.

A collection of attributes used to define the telemetry to collect or set on a subscriber system. The HDM CSR Console Plugin uses managed settings to define the TR-069 parameters that are displayed and retrieved in each operation of the CSR Console.
A type of policy that is created by HDM when the user creates a policy to run on multiple devices either through the NBI or on the Policy page of the HDM Management Console.

The Organizationally Unique Identifier for a manufacturer assigned by the IEEE Registration Authority. The OUI in combination with the model and serial number allows individual devices to be uniquely identified. The OUI follows a format with a six-digit hexadecimal value (uppercase letters: A, B, C, D, E, F and any zero to the left).
A primitive function that completes in more than one HTTP session.

An application that consists of two components: the NPM Test Manager and NPM Test Server. The NPM Test Manager can be installed on top of Home Device Manager or on a standalone server. The NPM application enables HDM administrators and NBI users to perform bandwidth and UDP Echo tests between the CPE and NPM Test Servers which are strategically deployed either on a Service Provider's network or over the Internet. NPM Test Servers send performance test results to the NPM Test Manager, and the NPM Test Manager processes the results, takes measurements, and sends notifications to the DMP and HDM.

A load balancer that fronts the Managed Servers in the HDMCluster of the application tier and offloads SSL activity initiated by HDM Management Console, Services Configuration Console, and/or OSS (operations support systems) users.

The system created by using the HDM integration features, collectively referred to as the Northbound Interface (NBI), to integrate HDM with the service provider's Operations Support Systems (OSS). By using the NBS, the OSS can call into HDM, and HDM can send notifications back to the OSS.

A human-readable name that can be substituted for a number instance in an object string on a TR-069-based device. For example, InternetGatewayDevice.WANDevice.1 could be mapped to InternetGatewayDevice.WANDevice.Router.
A server based Workflow Engine for Hadoop. It is specialized in running workflow jobs with actions that run Hadoop MapReduce jobs, Apache Pig jobs and so forth.

An optional capability of a device, such as firewall monitoring, content screening, VoIP, or remote access, that is managed through a voucher. In Home Device Manager, options can be transferable or non-transferable (the default). A transferable option is one that remains enabled when the device is provisioned by a different service provider.
The object returned by a function. An output parameter must be of type JCFResult, which can contain a Response DTO.

glossentry.glossterm: partially provisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.An activation scenario in which HDM is preprovisioned only with unique HTTP credentials for the CPE. In this case, the CPE ID (OUI, product class, and serial number) is not identified for the device. The CPE is preprovisioned with at least the public PPP credentials and public HTTP credentials. The CPE contacts the Device Management (DM) Server with the public HTTP credentials. The CPE is assigned an appropriate CPE ID, is configured with connection request credentials, and then is configured for activation. Also, if the CPE informs with a different CPE ID than was previously registered, device replacement may take place. This activation scenario is also known as HTTP Pre-provision activation and Pre-provision HTTP Provisioning Mode.

In TR-069 compliant devices, notifications inform the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) that a specified parameter has changed. Passive notifications are included in the next PERIODIC Inform message after a value has changed.

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that occurs based on a periodic inform interval configured for the CPE device. For example, a device may be configured to send a message to an Auto-configuration Server (ACS) once every 24 hours.

A rule that defines a set of conditions (such as selection criteria or device groups) and associated actions. If a device meets these conditions, then the specified actions for that rule are run on the device. Within Home Device Manager, policies are used to manage devices. A policy continues to run against targeted devices unless it expires or reaches a failure threshold or retry count configured in the policy. Policies run only on devices that are currently enabled and not locked by an operator for manual operation.
A specific policy mapped to a script in the Intelligent Workflow Engine. The script is triggered and run when the action for that policy is completed.

glossentry.glosssee: preprovisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation
preprovisioned HDM and unprovisioned CPE activation

glossentry.glossterm: preprovisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: NE 10/11/2012, Reworded to eliminate bullets.An activation scenario in which HDM and the CPE are preprovisioned with at least the public PPP credentials, public HTTP credentials, and the CPE ID (OUI, product class, and serial number). The CPE contacts the Device Management (DM) Server with the public HTTP credentials. The CPE is configured with the connection request credentials and then is configured for activation.
These scenarios are also known as full-HDM-unique-CPE activation, Pre-provision activation, and Pre-provision Provisioning Mode.

glossentry.glossterm: preprovisioned HDM and unprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.An activation scenario in which HDM is preprovisioned with at least the public PPP credentials, the public HTTP credentials of the device, and the CPE ID (OUI, product class, and serial number). The CPE is not preprovisioned and therefore contacts the Bootstrap Server with the default HTTP credentials. The CPE is provisioned with the appropriate authentication parameters at the Bootstrap Server, and is then redirected to the Device Management (DM) Server to be configured for activation. This activation scenario is also known as full-HDM-default-CPE activation, Pre-provision activation, and Pre-provision Provisioning Mode using the Bootstrap Server.

glossentry.glosssee: partially provisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation
preprovisioned HDM and preprovisioned CPE activation

glossentry.glossterm: Pre-provision Provisioning Mode using the Bootstrap Server
glossentry.glosssee: preprovisioned HDM and unprovisioned CPE activation

glossdef.para: In the context of Domain Management, the lowest level domain within a hierarchy of domains where a given device should be managed.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.A function such as setParameterValues that is built into Home Device Manager and maps to a TR-069 RPC. Primitive functions either return a result that is of type JCFResult or return nothing. For example, the call to the GetParameterValues function using execPrimitive() takes GetParameterValuesDTO as an input parameter and returns a JCFResult that contains a GetParameterValuesResponseDTO. Another example is the call to the FactoryReset function using execPrimitive(), which takes no input parameters and returns no JCFResult.
Primitive functions can be either single-session primitive functions or multi-session primitive functions.

The high-level categorization of CPE that describes the basic capabilities of a class of devices. A protocol represents the underlying communications protocol as well as object model paradigm for a device. Examples of device protocols include TR-069 and SNMP.

The Home Device Manager application servers installed in the DMZ of a distributed domain deployment. The protocol tier is dedicated to handling incoming communication from CPE; its servers make up the HDMDistributedDomain with an Administration Server and one or more Managed Servers. When the protocol tier Managed Servers are clustered (optional), they are members of the HDMDistributedCluster.

The applicable protocol Managed Server uses RMI over IIOP to load balance and direct CPE communication to an available Managed Server in the application tier. Unlike the application tier servers, the protocol tier servers do not communicate with the Home Device Manager OLTP database.
Compare to application tier.

The state of device in which sufficient information is available to HDM for the device to be recognized by HDM when the device contacts the HDM Bootstrap Server or the HDM Management Server for the first time
Depending on the provisioning mode used, the information needed may be only a device type record in the DEVICE_TYPE table or a device record in the DEVICE table.
Data collection mechanism in which TRM pulls data from the devices without the knowledge of the management server and forwards it to Data Collection Manager.

Data collection mechanism in which the devices send data to TRM through Periodic or Value Change Informs. All the Informs with Periodic and Value Change event codes are forwarded to Data Collection Manager for data collection.

The state of a device that has contacted HDM, has a record in the DEVICE table, is known to HDM, is not yet activated, and is not fully operable by HDM; that is, operators may not yet queue actions and functions on the device

For TR-069, a method that defines a single call between an Auto-configuration Server (ACS) and a device. An RPC is distinct from a function in that a function as used in this context is an HDM concept and maps to one or more RPCs.
A collection of related reports organized under a report group name.
The window of a generated report that displays the requested report data.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.A protocol-specific compound input parameter, implemented as a Java class, or Plain Old Java Object (POJO), and stored in the package alamotv.hdm.functions.types.request. These parameters benefit from a special rendering in the HDM Management Console, which provides specific forms to assist users in populating these parameters for a given protocol. Request DTO parameters may also have content that can be validated more extensively, depending on the capabilities of the protocol (for example, validation of CWMP data model parameters). In addition, these parameters usually map to messages sent by the Protocol Tier to devices. For example, in the case of CWMP, a GetParameterValuesDTO map to the GetParameterValues RPC is sent to a device.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.A protocol-specific compound output parameter, implemented as a Java class, or Plain Old Java Object (POJO), and stored in the package alamotv.hdm.functions.types.response. These parameters are monitored by application services, which can then update the HDM database accordingly (for example, update the cache when a GetParameterValuesResponseDTO is detected). Response DTO parameters usually map to messages returned by devices as a reply to a request. For example, in the case of CWMP, a GetParameterValuesResponseDTO map to the GetParameterValuesResponse RPC is sent by a device.
Software as a service (SaaS) is a software delivery method in which the software and its associated functions are hosted on a remote server and accessed through a web browser, over the Internet.
On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, a one-time Inform message that occurs based on a request (M ScheduleInform method call) from the Auto-configuration Server (ACS).
In Intelligent Workflow Engine, a log file that a scheduled script generates when run.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.A collection of search parameters that can be used to locate devices. The HDM Management Console provides a set of default search criteria templates. Users can add custom templates from the HDM Management Console. A search criteria template is also known as a criteria template.

A descriptive name/value pair that you can associate with a device to group devices in relation to the services that are deployed on them (for example, VOIP=enabled). You can set service tags as exit options on policy success or failure.

In the context of HDM Domain Management, any domain-aware object that is created in one domain, but is available to multiple other domains within the same domain hierarchy. For example, an object created in the super domain is available to all users in all domains.

In a custom function context, a single-value parameter that is not bound to a protocol (such as TR-069 or SNMP). Supported types of simple parameters are string, integer, text, date, boolean, unsignedInt, long, unsignedLong, and hexBinary.

glossentry.glossterm: Simple Traversal of User Datagram Protocol (UDP) Through Network Address Translators (NATs) (STUN) Server

glossdef.para: An Internet-facing server that implements the STUN protocol to set up UDP communication with a device behind a NAT in the subscriber environment. The STUN Server creates the binding by informing a device (STUN client) of the type of NAT with which it is associated, along with the public IP address and port number for the NAT. The binding enables the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) to send connection requests for Inform messages to the STUN client through a User Datagram Protocol (UDP) Connection Request Proxy Server.
A primitive function that completes in a single HTTP session.

A load balancer that CPE contact for redirection. Depending on the deployment, the southbound load balancer redirects CPE to a Bastion Web Server in the Web proxy tier or to an application tier Managed Server. Typically, the southbound load balancer is configured to offload the SSL requests from CPE such that they are forwarded over HTTP.

The Home Device Manager architecture that includes a single WebLogic Server domain in the trusted network. The domain (HDMDomain) includes an Administration Server and a cluster of application servers (HDMCluster). Typically, the standard deployment also includes one or more Bastion Web Servers in a DMZ. A Bastion Web Server redirects device communication from the DMZ to the trusted network.
A small smart card used in a mobile phone or femtocell access point that stores the IMSI used to identify the subscriber.

NE 8/17/2012, HDM-3804, rewrote to eliminate bullets.An activation scenario in which neither HDM nor the CPE is preprovisioned. When the subscriber connects the CPE to the DSL line at home, the CPE contacts the Bootstrap Server with the default HTTP credentials and is registered with HDM. HDM provisions the CPE with initial parameters and then waits for the subscriber to run the self-registration activation flow. When the subscriber runs the self-registration flow, HDM provisions the device with authentication parameters and then redirects the CPE to the Device Management (DM) Server. At the Device Management (DM) Server, the CPE is configured for activation. The subscriber self-registration activation scenario is also known as Self-registration Provisioning Mode.

A user in Home Device Manager that has been granted access to the super-domain, domain, which is established in the HDM Administration Console out-of-the-box (OOTB) during HDM installation or upgrade. Users in the super-domain can add shared resources, which are made available for use across all domains, and view all resources across all domains.
A Connection Request Proxy Server that passes connection requests from the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) to a TR-069 WAN-connected device. In turn, the device sends an Inform message to the ACS.
A web application in which periodic timer-based tasks can be scheduled. Periodic timers invoke functions at regular intervals.
The CWMP protocol defined by the Broadband Forum. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-069 report that documents the protocol.

NE 1/23/2012 HDM-2283, Created new glossary term to indicate HDM support for TR-098.An extension of the Broadband Forum's TR-069 protocol that describes the Internet Gateway Device data model for the CPE WAN Management Protocol. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-098 report that documents the extension.

NE 1/23/2012 HDM-2283, Added second sentence to specify difference between TR-106 devices and TR-098 devices.An extension of the Broadband Forum's TR-069 protocol that specifies a baseline object structure and set of parameters accessible to TR-069 that must be available on any TR-069-enabled device. A device will always have a single root object, which will be called either Device or InternetGatewayDevice. The latter is exclusively to accommodate the TR-098 specification and is only to be used if the device is an Internet Gateway Device The latter is exclusively to accommodate the TR-098 specification and is only to be used if the device is an Internet Gateway Device. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-106 report that documents the extension.

An extension of the Broadband Forum's TR-069 protocol for remotely managing devices connected to LANs through NATs. Examples of such devices include VoIP phones, media set-top boxes, and gaming systems. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-111 report that documents the extension.

NE 1/19/2012: HDM-2283. Added new glossary entry.An extension of the Broadband Forum's TR-069protocol that defines the Device:2 device type data model. With the Device:2 model, an interface stacking mechanism is defined. Through this mechanism, network interfaces and protocol layers are modeled as independent data objects that can be stacked, one on top of the other, into whatever configuration a device may support. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-181 report that documents this extension. HDM-2283, end of new paragraph.

The Traffic Regulation Module (TRM) regulates the traffic between the HDM and the devices. It helps input throttling of Informs to the Home Device Manager in a controlled way that is more CWMP aware than the basic load balancers.
On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that occurs when a previously requested download or upload (successful, or unsuccessful) completes.

A type of policy that is created temporarily by HDM in order to run an action on a single device when the user queues the action to the device either through the NBI or on the Manage Device page of the HDM Management Console.

glossentry.glossterm: User Datagram Protocol (UDP) Connection Request Proxy Server

glossdef.para: A Connection Request Proxy Server that implements the UDP protocol to pass connection requests from the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) to a TR-111 device. In turn, the device sends an Inform message to the ACS. The communication is possible as a result of the binding that a STUN Server creates on the device.
A descriptive name/value pair that you can associate with a device to group devices in relation to user segments (for example, location=Austin, TX).

On devices that support the TR-069 protocol, an Inform message that occurs based on a change to one of the parameter values included in the Inform message. The values included in the Inform message are described in the Broadband Forum TR-069 protocol specification.
An XML file that describes optional value-added services that can be enabled on a device. For example, a voucher could enable a device to provide higher bandwidth than standard subscribers receive.

An event created so that a TR-069 device can inform the Auto-configuration Server (ACS) when it wakes up from standby. The ACS defines parameters as policy elements in the data model which allow the CPE to determine conditions required before issuing the wakeup event.
Collective reference to any Bastion Web Servers and Connection Request Proxy Servers in a DMZ of a Home Device Manager deployment.

The predecessor to TR-069 CWMP protocol, WT-087 is the Broadband Forum working text for the first draft of the TR-069 protocol. Some devices may support the WT-087 version of TR-069 which is not as comprehensive as full TR-069 support. See the Broadband Forum for a copy of the WT-087 specification.

An activation scenario in which neither HDM nor the CPE is preprovisioned. When the subscriber connects the CPE to the DSL line at home, the CPE contacts the Bootstrap Server with the default HTTP credentials and is registered with HDM. HDM provisions the CPE with initial parameters and then contacts the OSS for subscriber data. HDM saves the subscriber data in the data store, provisions the CPE with authentication parameters, and redirects the CPE to the Device Management (DM) Server. At the Device Management (DM) Server, the CPE is configured for activation.
Also known as Zero-touch Provisioning Mode.

A set of OSGi bundles that runs on the OSGi framework and communicates with the remote manager to provide management of a device. The ALM Management Agent is pre-installed on a managed device, but it can be updated remotely after the device ships.
The Application Lifecycle Manager user interface that enables remote management of applications, deployment units, and the execution environments that run on managed devices.
An NBI that provides methods that allow you to manage the life cycle of applications on managed devices.
Within Application Lifecycle Manager, an application is a logical grouping of deployment units that corresponds to a subscriber-oriented application.

Product that enables broadband providers to remotely manage applications on devices. Functionality includes application, deployment unit, and device management, as well as the ability to implement policies on devices. A configuration page enables you to set parameters such as FTP and HTTP locations and ports.

A module consisting of a .jar file that delivers and deploys code and resources (for example, images and libraries) and contains a bundle manifest file that supplies code dependencies and other information about the bundle. Bundles hide their internal implementations, communicate through services, and are managed by the OSGi framework. A more general term for a bundle is a deployment unit.
A deployable module of code and/or data. A deployment unit may contain one or more execution units. On the OSGi framework, deployment units correspond to bundles.
A system capable of running the ALM client/platform, and therefore manageable by ALM. Add glossterms to this; get this reviewed.
A framework on a managed device which provides APIs for managing deployment units, including installing, starting, and stopping them.
An executable component of a deployment unit.

A component of an application definition in Application Lifecycle Manager. A flavor specifies a set of deployment units and configuration information along with criteria for applying them. Flavors allow you to deploy an application differently for different circumstances.
See service gateway.
In Application Lifecycle Manager, an application becomes inconsistent when one of the deployment units it depends on is stopped or uninstalled.
An object such as a service that is defined by a bundle running in an OSGi framework and that can be managed and configured by Application Lifecycle Manager.

A Java-based specification for service platforms that can be managed remotely. The OSGi framework specification provides a standard for modularizing applications into smaller bundles whose external dependencies, if any, are explicitly declared. It also defines an API-based application life cycle management model for installing, starting, stopping, updating and uninstalling bundles; a service registry that detects when new services are added; an execution environment that defines the methods and classes available on a specific platform; and a security layer that restricts bundle functionality to predefined capabilities. The OSGi framework is part of the OSGi Service Platform, which can reside on every device in the home network, on a centrally placed service gateway in the home network, or both simultaneously.
Also known generically as the framework.
A mechanism for organizing Java classes into namespaces. bundles can export packages to other bundles.

Policies allow you to perform operations on sets of devices, or perform operations automatically in response to certain events. For each policy, you can define criteria that determine which devices the system should apply the policy to, and actions that describe the operations to perform.
One or more systems in the operational environment that are communicating with managed devices to provide remote management.

In the context of OSGi, an interface of a Java object which is registered in the OSGi service registry, allowing other bundles to use it. A single bundle can register multiple services. A service consists of a Java class or interface (the service interface), along with a variable number of attributes (the service properties) that are name-value pairs.
A physical or logical device running an execution environment that allows ALM to manage the device.

The combination of the managed device and the OSGi framework. Avoid using this in 3.0 and later versions of ALM, because the emphasis on OSGI is less and I've removed all references to this term in the main text.

A server which provides authentication, authorization and accounting services for an organization. Other servers use the AAA server to determine whether to grant a user or client access, and what privileges to allow the client/user.
A Microsoft technology that provides network services. System administrators use AD to store information about the corporate users, assign security policies, and deploy software.
The World Wide Developer Relations (WWDR) intermediate certificate is used to authenticate the communication between MDM and APNs.
The process of configuring a device or mobile handset such that it can establish a management session with a secure management server.
A phrase that refers to personal computing devices such as smartphones, laptops and PDAs, brought to the workplace for use and connectivity on the corporate network.
Connection and network data included in GSM standard networks.
Initial over-the-air configuration of mobile devices through SMS messaging as defined by OMA CP.

A channel access method used by various radio communication technologies. CDMA is an example of multiple access, where several transmitters can send information simultaneously over a single communication channel. This allows several users to share a band of frequencies.

A Motive solution that automates root/cause analysis and problem resolution for FMC (fixed mobile convergence) service on behalf of subscribers. Converged Services Manager runs on the Service Management Platform; the solution includes pre-defined service models and overlays, user interfaces and workflows, and integration adapters.

Customer teams configure the pre-defined content to include deployment-specific business logic and to model supported services and associated devices. The resulting content queries the applicable device management servers, evaluates device data acquired there, and dynamically generates user interfaces for subscribers and CSRs. To resolve service issues, users are presented with relevant operations to initiate on applicable devices. Depending on the service policy, the solution may initiate one or more of the operations automatically before presenting user options.

The CounterPath Client Configuration Server allows an enterprise to manage VoIP devices. The system can install the appropriate configuration to the end user's device, or update its configuration, and it can schedule configuration and software updates so that they occur over time.
Browser-based interface that CSRs use to resolve service issues on behalf of mobile, broadband service, and/or FMC (fixed mobile convergence) subscribers.

For each applicable subscriber service, there are one or more associated devices. Per device, the Customer Service Console provides CSRs with a bootstrapping workflow in the case that the device is not activated with the applicable management server; device details including a device diagram; a list of available operations to initiate on the device such as that for a firmware upgrade or resetting a non-optimal setting; and device history lookup.
The Managed Servers of the Service Management Platform host the Customer Service Console.
A Nokia standard for software product deliverables that allows them to be automatically deployed using tools like Open Source Puppet.
An object that allows you to manage the devices capabilities. You can select and remotely enable or disable the capabilities.
The data structure and capabilities for a device model. Each OMA DM-enabled device model has a DDF.

Management of device configuration, updates, and other managed objects of mobile devices as defined by OMA (Open Mobile Alliance). Generically, DM refers to all methods and activities associated with mobile device management.
Device management software installed on a mobile handset. The DM client communicates with the MDM Server to enable remote management, configuration, and updates on the device.
The application server component of Mobile Device Manager that enables backing up and restoring data on mobile handsets.
Device software such as operating systems, drivers, call processing stacks, and user interfaces. Although device firmware may require updating, it is non-downloadable.
Wireless mechanism for mobile subscribers to install and configure firmware upgrades on their handsets eliminating trips to a service center.

Fixed and mobile telephony service from a single phone with the handset configured to switch between mobile and Wi-Fi (Wireless Fidelity) networks. For example, British Telecom offers an FMC service called BT Fusion.

Packet-switched mobile data service available on GSM mobile handsets. Multiple users share the same transmission channel, only transmitting when they have data to send. GPRS provides for moderate speed data transfer by using unused TDMA channels in the GSM network.
A globally accepted standard for digital cellular communication.
IOT content, which is a universal content to manage several devices and in MDM you can reference the mobile devices.
An operation provided by Open Mobile Alliance (OMA), which allows remote locking and wiping of the personal user data in case the device is lost or stolen.

Browser-based application for mobile operators and terminal manufacturers who run FOTA and other device configuration updates OTA. Operators use the MDM Console to plan and manage data required to implement firmware and device configuration updates.

For example, an operator populates the MDM Server with property details for data elements such as tenants, subscribers, devices, models, manufacturers, updates, and profiles; then, the operator uses the stored data to create jobs for provisioning and updating devices within the field. Provisioning requests are scheduled based on the timing requirements of the operator. At the scheduled times, applicable devices are updated.

The IP-based over-the-air server component of Mobile Device Manager. The Mobile Device Management Servers provide the core functionality to send configuration settings and firmware updates to mobile handsets. The servers support OMA-based CP and DM specifications.

Motive product that allows service providers to remotely provision, update, and manage mobile devices and services throughout the device life cycle. The product provides for individual and bulk device configuration, problem resolution, firmware upgrades, event management, user management, and reporting.

A Motive product that allows service providers to build client software for mobile devices that do not have an OMA DM client, or to provide capabilities beyond those provided by OMA (Open Mobile Alliance) DM clients. The SDK enables carriers to build features like remote control, file management, process list, application installation, application updating, and advanced information gathering, on supported platforms.

A deployment of integrated Motive products that enable providers to manage subscriber service and associated devices. The solution includes the Service Management Platform, Customer Service Console, and Mobile Device Manager and/or Home Device Manager.

A physical infrastructure through which Internet service providers (ISPs) and Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) exchange Internet traffic between their networks. Nowadays referred to as Internet exchange point (IX or IXP).

The Microsoft implementation of the SCEP, a communication protocol that enables software running on network devices such as routers and switches, to enroll for X.509 certificates from a certification authority (CA).
Organization that develops open specifications designed to facilitate interoperability in the mobile industry based on market requirements. For more information, see the OMA site.
Wireless mechanism for sending provisioning data or updating firmware or software on mobile handsets. Typically, a device management client enables an OTA configuration.
Type of multicast and group calls.
Inter-networking with the Internet (IP protocols) and X.25 networks.
A client that is installed on the device once the device is ready for operation. It is not a factory device.

A basic construct that defines the input and output parameters of a logical set of commands, that can be executed on a device, being managed by MDM. The definition and implementation of a primitive is available in $JBOSS_HOME/server/all/conf/primitives.xml. The format of a primitive implementation can either be a Domain Specific Language, or ProfileList, which is XML syntax containing device commands.

A collection of attributes for configuring a mobile device to provide for a particular service or function. Mobile Device Manager provides standard profile templates on which to base new profiles such as bookmark, data synchronization, email, MMS, push to talk, and video streaming.

A reference implementation support interface for mobile subscribers. Subscribers can access the browser-based interface through their handset desktops. From the site, subscribers bootstrap their devices; run device-supported workflows such as that for updating firmware or backing up data; and escalate to a CSR, depending on the deployment. Typically, the Self-Service Console workflows are customized as needed and then integrated into a service provider-branded portal.
A Motive application which can be deployed along with the Customer Service Console to provide subscribers with access to a web-based interface for self help. Depends on the Self Service Manager.
SMS is available on most digital mobile phones that support short messages or text messaging between mobile devices.

Allows you to manage the software components on a device remotely, during installation, uninstallation, activation or deactivation of software components. This object manages all types of software components except firmware, for example, certificates, licenses.
Platform-independent information synchronization standard. Companies such as Nokia and Sony Ericsson support SyncML in their products.

A Motive kit that contains a reference user interface, workflows, pre-defined service models, and relevant integration adapters. The template content is designed to solve a specific business and technical challenge. For example, Motive offers the following templates: mobile device management self-service, mobile device management assisted service, mobile device remote control, dual mode phone self-service, and dual mode phone assisted service.
A number entered before the area code when dialing a long-distance number within the same country; it is omitted when dialing internationally.
An XML file that stores the firmware image and all the related details required to download the image on a device.

A Motive product providing WiMAX device management via virtual server which uses the Service Management Platform to allow web service calls for WiMAX devices to be delivered to appropriate device manager products such as the Mobile Device Manager or Home Device Manager.
A fast wireless communications technology designed to enable the delivery of last-mile broadband access, and intended to serve as an alternative to cable or DSL.
A standardized protocol for accessing information over a mobile wireless network.
An activation scenario in which the device is provisioned without interaction from the end user, using data taken from the carrier's database of service plan information.
A system alert configured with an activation date in the past, and either no expiration set or an expiration set to a date and time in the future.

The version of the config currently in effect in the runtime environment of an SMP installation. From Configuration Manager, you can create, load for editing, or make active a different version of the config.

Open-source services framework with which to build and develop services using front-end programming APIs. Several protocols such as SOAP, XML/HTTP, RESTful HTTP, and CORBA are in use by these services. The protocols work over different transports such as HTTP, JMS, and JBI.

On an SMP installation, the combination of SMP content and config items. For example, individual workflows, models, and resource files are SMP content assets, and workflow modules and service operations are config items. The application configuration, sometimes referred to as the solution of an SMP deployment, includes the content and configuration settings intended to be effective across installations in a given deployment.
A name and value pair that defines either a built-in property that has system-wide effects or a custom property on which deployment-specific content depends.

A test that the SMP is configured to run automatically when you display subscriber details. Such tests must be members of the startup group. When running automatic tests, the system skips any tests for which it has prior results.

In an interactive workflow, a user interface on which the user must provide input to continue execution (for example, type or make selections and/or click a button). The interface is rendered based on a corresponding display step node in the interactive workflow.

A type of workflow in which the steps complete a service delivery process involving multiple participants (for example, to provision a service). The participants may include backend systems that automate part of the process (for example, to generate a subscriber profile) and qualified personnel who complete user tasks (for example, to ship hardware).
In Model Builder, a group of methods with which to retrieve data for a model component from the associated type of data source.
A set of capabilities.

A provider of phone services for mobile devices. A carrier may have multiple tenants. A tenant may only have one carrier per type (MDM or MDS). If neither MDM nor MDS is used in a deployment, then tenants do not need to be linked to carriers.

A target audience for which to render the user interfaces of an interactive workflow. The interfaces are defined with Display Step nodes and channel-specific properties configured in the interactive workflow. SMP provides template sets for several generic channels.

For a given interactive workflow, a separate workflow containing logic for one or more specific channels. When an interactive workflow is requested with a channel for which there is a channel workflow, there is a match. The first such match determines which channel workflow is executed. Otherwise, the Default workflow for the interactive workflow is executed.
In MORSE, a tenant added directly to another tenant, or to a tenant beneath that tenant in the tenant hierarchy.

A caller application that communicates with SMP. For example, clients send operation execution requests for a named endpoint operation to the Endpoint Operations API. A CSR application deployed on the SMP server can be written to use the API methods directly, while a northbound interface installed outside of the SMP server can use the Endpoint Operations Web Service to call the methods.
