Utility for uploading, downloading, and activating a version of the application configuration from the command line.
On an SMP installation, a version of the group of configurations defined, such as workflow modules and service operations.
Browser-based tool for defining the active version of the application configuration, one or more other versions of the application configuration, and the environment configuration.

Command line interface (CLI) for exporting and importing application configuration data. The client supports an export in which only marked workflows are exported with the exclusion of unmarked workflows and all other assets from the application configuration. This enables expediting the propagation of marked workflows from one server environment to another (for example, from test to production servers).

A system alert intended for display on a prominent area of a client such that CSRs see it without having to proactively open a separate part of the application. By default, SMP classifies an alert as critical when the alert is configured with either a High or Medium priority.

Browser-based application the provides members of your application and IT teams health metrics on each Managed Server, as well as globally over the entire cluster. Monitoring results are stored in an OLTP database that handles time-series data, from which the Dashboard Console generates graphs. The graphs, whose data you can export, show views of Managed Server and cluster health data over the past hour, day, or week. The Dashboard Console is a separately-licensed additional feature.
Plugin software that enables SMP to retrieve data from a particular type of data source such as an Oracle database, Home Device Manager (HDM), and Connected Device Platform (CDP).

For a given interactive workflow, the separate workflow containing logic acceptable for most any client request, regardless of channel. Each interactive workflow has a Default workflow; it is executed when the interactive workflow does not have any channel workflows, or there is not a matching channel workflow.

The set of values required to establish communication between SMP and the data source for an installed data source adapter (DSA). Individual DSA connections are defined in the environment configuration.

A system user account added to a tenant in the provider's tenant hierarchy. An EAC admin can manage data on that tenant and its child tenants. The role with which the account is added and roles in the account itself affect the type of management permitted.
In MORSE, a record added to a tenant or to a subscriber record. The record defines an individual device or system targeted for management (for example, a mobile phone, DSL modem, or an operator OSS).

An individual device or system targeted for management. Management may include retrieving data, configuring an update, or running other specific functions. Examples of endpoints are a mobile phone, DSL modem, and other individual systems such as an operator OSS.

Data that describes a specific endpoint. The first step of executing an operation on a given endpoint is to retrieve the endpoint's descriptor from the applicable manager. All client requests to execute the operation for a given endpoint operation must include a valid endpoint descriptor.

A string of characters that uniquely identifies an endpoint such as a MAC (media access control) address. The endpoint identifier is deployment-specific and based on the type of endpoints slated for management.
A data configuration stored in the application configuration. The configuration defines the manner in which SMP is to handle a client request to execute the operation assigned to the configuration.

A web service that provides for exposing normalized operations for execution on individual endpoints. With a normalized operation, the client does not need to expose the full APIs of the applicable managers or to invoke multiple managers.
In MORSE, a record that defines the explicit relationship between a subscription instance and an endpoint. EndpointServiceActivation records are created through calls to the MORSE API.
Browser-based tool through which a service provider and its customers manage tenants and tenant data (subscriptions, subscribers, and endpoints). The data is stored in MORSE.

In MORSE, a tenant created either on the service provider tenant or on a virtual service provider tenant. An enterprise tenant represents a company that subscribes to services offered. For example, companyXYZ could be one of the enterprise tenants on a service provider named Globecom, or on a virtual service provider named GlobecomAsia.

On an SMP installation, the configuration that defines items such as DSA connections, environment properties, and execution auditing settings. Typically, the settings in the environment configuration are not the same on the installation types of a given SMP deployment (for example, on development, quality control, and certification and production installations).

A name and value pair that varies from one database to another. Environment properties allow maintaining differences between two databases when testing changes in one database and then moving them to another database when they are ready for use. Environment properties are defined in the environment configuration; they are not tied to the application configuration in any way.

Settings that enable reporting on the duration and outcome of specific tasks in troubleshooting application and performance issues. The execution auditing settings are defined in the environment configuration.

A part of the application configuration that stores SMP-based templates. A template is applied when it is referenced within a model or overlay that it is executing. The template types supported are shared functions, overlay actions, and overlay types.

In MORSE, a tenant created either on an enterprise tenant or on another group tenant. A group tenant represents a division of an enterprise or a smaller group within a division of the enterprise. For example, HR could be a group tenant on an enterprise named companyXYZ. At the same time, Recruiting and Benefits could be group tenants on the HR group tenant.
Browser-based tool in which assignees manage user task instances to completion. Until completed, the task instances block associated business process workflows from continuing.
A type of workflow in which the steps guide a single user type through a service assurance or customer care process (for example, to troubleshoot a problem with service).
Each instance of the JBoss application server in a group installation (also called a cluster) is called a node.

Software application that communicates with, and manages, a set of endpoints, such as computers, mobile devices, broadband devices, or other systems. Examples of managers are Home Device Manager (HDM) and Connected Device Platform (CDP).

Version of a workflow deemed ready for export. The export of marked workflows occurs automatically after running the applicable command through the Configuration Upload and Download client. The workflows become unmarked immediately following the export until marked again through the Workflow Builder.

glossentry.glossterm: MORSE (Motive Object Repository for Services and Enterprises)

glossdef.para: The SMP data model that provides for storage and retrieval of a service provider's tenant data. MORSE defines a tenant hierarchy based on inputs from the service provider and its customers.

Mechanism for controlling the load that northbound interface (NBI) requests generate on SMP. The NBI requests are calls to SMP NBI APIs and web services. The mechanism is implemented through northbound throttling policies defined in the environment configuration.
Either the model and overlay, or a Java service operation (JSO), based on which to execute the operation on an endpoint. Operation implementations are assigned to service operations.
A set of validation rules for properties defined in a service. For example, an Email service may have a Globecom optimal setting for validating subscriptions to Globecom Email.
A collection of optimal values for a particular service. For example, the Globecom tenant has a Globecom Email optimal setting, which defines the optimal values for the Email service for that tenant.
A single optimal value for a particular service attribute, and assigned to one or more tenants. For example, an Email Address optimal setting value for Globecom might be *@globecom.com.

An installation option for the Service Management Platform in which you create a WebLogic Server domain for the platform. The process involves creating the domain and its Administration Server and one or more Managed Servers.

An installation option for the Service Management Platform in which you install the platform into an existing WebLogic Server domain. The process involves updating the existing domain's Administration Server and Managed Servers with the platform.
Within an overlay, the operation triggered when a check returns a particular value (for example, run a command or send an email).

A template for a type of overlay action. Action templates are created in Overlay Builder; they are stored in the glossary of the application configuration, such that overlay authors can re-use them in different overlays.
A business rule that analyzes a model to address a business problem. Overlay checks are defined with expressions or JavaScript code; they can have associated overlay actions.
A property value yielded from executing an overlay. The one or more result properties in an overlay are defined by its overlay type.

An XML file that defines the result properties for an overlay. Each overlay is associated with a single overlay type. At execution, overlays with the same overlay type return the same result properties. This allows for an application to use the same code to render results from overlays of the same overlay type.

In MORSE, the tenant directly on which one or more tenants, subscriptions, subscribers, and endpoints are added. The parent tenant is the owner of those objects. At the same time, a subscriber is the owner of subscriptions and endpoints added directly to it.
A workload management component that handles client requests within SMP. PARP is accessed either through SMP Java APIs or associated web services.

Browser-based tool for validating a solution. Validation involves replacing the existing SMP content with the Knowledge Management Platform (KMP) content from the specified solution, and validating that the resulting SMP content is complete. A lead application admin provisions the validated solution generated in the console to the deployment's certification or production environment.

The display name, result code, and role-based descriptions for individual results returned during execution of service operations. Result analyses are configured per service operation. The priorities set for result analyses determine the order in which requesting applications display the results returned.

A configuration that provides the mechanism for using SMP to determine permissions on an external entity not created and managed within the platform. Each role-based property includes assignment of one or more user roles. Only those users with accounts including at least one of the assigned roles are permitted to use the resources associated with the role-based property.

In MORSE, an object representing a program or functionality offered to enterprise customers (for example, Email or IPTV). Tenants and subscribers are entitled only to the services for which subscriptions are added to their respective parent tenants. Entitled services are added to subscriber records through subscriptions.
In the Customer Service Console, a service is a set of features. In the database, it is a feature in the system, for which you can define optimal settings in the database. For example, Email.
A particular field for a service. For example, Email Address.
A comprehensive software toolset and action engine for customer experience management. SMP serves as the foundation of most Motive solutions.

Browser-based tool through which a service provider defines the services it offers to enterprise customers. In the SOC, the service provider can also define optimal settings per service. The data is stored in MORSE (Motive Object Repository for Services and Enterprises); in turn, the service provider uses the Enterprise Admin Console (EAC) to manage subscriptions, through which tenants are entitled to particular services.
Browser-based tool through which a service provider defines the services it offers to enterprise customers and optimal settings per service. The data is stored in MORSE.

Mechanism for controlling the invocations of specific service operations. This control also determines whether the associated NBI and southbound system requests are initiated; as a result, service operation throttling provides for a middle ground between northbound throttling and southbound throttling.
A defined behavior to execute as a result of a given event. Service policies are defined in the application configuration.

In MORSE, the top-most tenant in the tenant hierarchy. Per deployment, there is only one service provider tenant. The service provider tenant represents an organization that provides services to many customers. For example, Globecom could be the service provider tenant for a service provider named Globecom.

A function for invocation from a model property. Shared functions are defined with Rhino JavaScript in Model Builder; they are stored in the glossary of the application configuration, such that model authors can re-use them in different models.
One or more nodes created in what is referred to as a group installation. The SMP applications are deployed on each node in the group.

The SMP database instance in which the runtime environment stores all content and transaction data. The SMP Database requires a majority of the SMP tables. However, the SMP Database may not include a few tables for reporting on workflow execution, depending on whether your team opts to create the SMP Reporting Database.
A single cluster installation or multi-cluster installation of SMP.

An optional SMP database instance that is reserved for a few tables for reporting on workflow execution. If the SMP Reporting Database is not created at installation or upgrade, the tables for reporting on workflow execution are in the SMP Database with the rest of the SMP tables.

An operational database for storage and maintenance of the operation implementations and corresponding endpoint operations. The Endpoint Operations API gathers information from the SMP Repository in response to client requests.

A unique period of time during which a client interacts with a platform application, such as Customer Service Console (CSC). An SMP session begins with an authenticated login or client request; it is ended either proactively by a user or through an automatic timeout or final response issued by the application. In addition, the lives of individual requests made to SMP web services and REST APIs are SMP sessions.

A product that provides pre-authored SMP content, such as models, overlays, and workflows for solving a set of related business problems. The content is based on best practices developed from solving the same problems.

A browser-based client that your team can optionally deploy with the Service Management Platform (SMP) in a test environment. The console provides a facility for testing preliminary content (for example, service operations and system alerts). In the SMP Test Console, essentially you assume the role of a CSR (customer support representative) and simulate service validation by conducting the following types of activities: run tests; view and sort test results; use any utilities; view active alerts and use the critical alerts area.
The data created each time the discovery scripts in a model are executed to retrieve property values.

Mechanism for controlling the load that SMP generates on southbound systems. Southbound systems refer to data sources on which SMP content depends, such as Home Device Manager (HDM). The mechanism is implemented through southbound throttling policies defined in the environment configuration.
A test group slated for automatic execution at session creation in an SMP-based console, such as the Customer Service Console (CSC). Startup test groups are defined in the application configuration.
In MORSE, a record that defines an end user of services offered. The subscriber record is added to a tenant.

Data that describes the subscriber associated with a specific endpoint. In the configuration of an endpoint operation, you can create a filter to limit usage to individual endpoints associated with subscribers with a particular attribute.
In MORSE, a record for an entitled service. The subscription record is added to a tenant or a subscriber record; it defines the service property values to apply for the tenant or subscriber.
A message with important service information that is intended for CSRs who are logged into a client with one or more particular roles. For example, an alert might announce upcoming system downtime.

In MORSE, a member of the tenant hierarchy for the service provider. A tenant represents the service provider, a virtual service provider, an enterprise, or a group. Subscription, subscriber, and endpoint records are created on particular tenants.

A tenant is a subset of a carrier with its own optimal settings. For example, a single phone service carrier might want to apply different settings for customers in different companies, so it would set up a tenant for each country.

The complete definition of a service provider's tenants and tenant relationships. The tenant at the top of the hierarchy is reserved for the service provider tenant. Under that, the service provider and its customers define other tenants for virtual service providers, enterprises, and groups. The tenant data is stored in MORSE.

A web-based interface for creating and configuring tenants, optimal settings, device classes, and capability groups and capabilities. These elements in addition to services, service attributes, and device platforms define the application configuration for a given solution.
A set of one or more service operations. Test groups are defined in the application configuration; they are available for execution by a client or an SMP API.

Data that describes the client user making a request for a given endpoint operation. In the configuration of an endpoint operation, you can create a filter to limit usage to users with a particular attribute.

For a model input common to one or many service operations, metadata to return to a client, such as its label, type, default value, whether optional, validation expression and message, and a help URL.

Work that requires human intervention to unblock the associated business process workflow. A given user task instance involves saving inputs to a form or completing guided steps in an interactive workflow.

In MORSE, a tenant created either on the service provider tenant or on another virtual service provider tenant. A virtual service provider tenant represents an entity with its own set of enterprise customers. For example, GlobecomAsia could be a virtual service provider tenant for a service provider named Globecom.

A series of automated and/or user-guided steps for completing service assurance and service delivery processes. In Workflow Builder, workflow authors can create two types of workflows, interactive workflows and business process workflows.
Browser-based tool for authoring, updating, and publishing interactive workflows and business process workflows.
The SMP web application that handles client requests to execute workflow modules assigned to interactive workflows. The Workflow Engine generates the user interfaces during execution.
A configuration that defines for the Workflow Engine which interactive workflow to execute, and the manner in which to execute it on behalf of a web client.
Browser-based tool through which application administrators view, manage, and troubleshoot instances of interactive workflows.

An entity in the context of which services are provisioned. An account may be associated with an enterprise deployment or a residential deployment. In an enterprise deployment, an account represents a business or a regional division of a business. In a residential deployment, an account represents an individual subscriber household, a billable entity from the service provider's perspective.

A management server that interacts with a set of client endpoints using well-defined protocols to get and set configuration data, run commands or operations on the endpoints, collect data periodically from the endpoints, and/or upgrade the endpoints with newer versions of applications or operating system software. One example of an element management system is Home Device Manager.

A Service Operations Module deployment that typically contains subscription groups, subscriptions, and properties. Enterprise deployments usually cluster subscriptions into subscription groups to allow different levels of subscription access and to improve subscription management. For example, an enterprise deployment might cluster subscriptions into open groups (allowing guest access) and closed groups (only allowing employee access), or into coverage for different floors of a building.
Stands for operations, administration, maintenance, and provisioning.

An operations adapter that runs service profile operations on element management systems (EMSs). For example, out of the box, the Femtocell Device Management System (FDMS) includes a Home Device Manager (HDM) operation executor that initiates service profile operations on Home Device Manager via the HDM Northbound Interface (NBI).
A Service Operations Module deployment for a subscriber or small business that contains subscriptions and properties; subscription groups option is available and can be used if required.

An object that represents a program of functionality that is enabled in the context of a device. Services have a life cycle, typically starting with a provisioning phase when the service is enabled. Management operations can be performed on the service once it is provisioned. A service may be deprovisioned at the end of its life cycle. Associated with the service is the notion of entitlement or right to use the service. Entitlement is a prerequisite for provisioning a service, and is typically accomplished when a user pays a fee to the service provider. Examples of services include residential and enterprise femtocell services. [Writer's note: For products other than femtocell, you might want to update this definition.]

A sto be deprecatedecure, web-based user interface used by the service provider to provision and maintain service management entities stored in the Service Repository, such as services, subscription groups, and subscriptions, as well as initiate OAMP operations against managed services and devices using service profiles as high-level abstractions.

A key component within Motive Product Groups Service Management product portfolio that enables operators with OAMP capabilities using a single, integrated solution that provides a consistent user experience for all multi-play subscriber services. The Service Operations Module consists of the Service Repository, the Service Operations Console, and the Service Operations Northbound Interface (NBI).

In the Service Operations Module, a web services interface used by northbound systems such as OSS/BSS used to provision and maintain service management entities stored in the Service Repository, such as services and subscriptions, as well as initiate OAMP operations against managed services and devices using service profiles as high-level abstractions.
Also known as: Service Repository Northbound Interface (NBI)

An object that is exposed as a high-level OAMP operation (for example, provisioning, diagnostic, alarming, or monitoring) for a specific service which can be applied to or associated with an existing subscription using the Service Operations Console or the Service Operations Northbound Interface (NBI). The service profile acts as an abstraction for a set (one or more) of device management actions known as service profile operations.

A processor that runs all service profile operations configured in a service profile using an operation executor. The Service Profile Engine can run multiple service profile operations on multiple, different element management systems. It is responsible for tracking all operation execution states and service profile execution states.

An object that represents an abstraction for a lower-level device management action that exists within an element manager. A set (one or more) of operations is associated with a specific service profile.

In the Service Operations Module, an operational database for storage and maintenance of service management entities including services, accounts, subscription groups, subscriptions, service profiles, and service profile operations.

An object that represents an individual service to which an account is entitled, and which will be managed by the service management system. Each subscription may be associated with one or more devices onto which the service is provisioned.

An object that represents a collection of subscription records that share common service provisioning attributes. Subscription groups facilitate grouping of subscriptions into meaningful clusters to manage them better and isolate them from other subscriptions.

For example, in an enterprise femtocell context, the set of all devices on the first floor of an enterprise could represent one subscription group. This subscription group could maintain a shared Access Control List representing end-user handsets that are allowed to connect to any of the femtocell access points on that floor.
The Access Point Name (APN) is the name for the settings your phone reads to set up a connection to the gateway between your carrier's cellular network and the public Internet.

An App ID is a two-part string used to identify one or more apps from a single development team. The string consists of a Team ID and a bundle ID search string, with a period (.) separating the two parts. The Team ID is supplied by Apple and is unique to a specific development team, while the bundle ID search string is supplied by you to match either the bundle ID of a single app or a set of bundle IDs for a group of your apps.
A file that contains personal information used to generate a signing certificate. This file also contains the public key to be included in the certificate, along with identifying information.
A development certificate identifies you, as a team member, in a development provisioning profile that allows apps signed by you to launch on devices.

A distribution certificate identifies your team or organization in a distribution provisioning profile and allows you to submit your app to the store. A distribution profile is required if want to release your iOS application through the online Apple App Store.

A type of provisioning profile that authorizes an app to run on devices without the assistance of Xcode and allows them to use certain services. A distribution provisioning profile is used to submit an app to the store or export it for distribution outside of the store.

Keytool is a key and certificate management utility. It allows users to administer their own public/private key pairs and associated certificates for use in self-authentication (where the user authenticates himself/herself to other users/services) or data integrity and authentication services, using digital signatures. It also allows users to cache the public keys (in the form of certificates) of their communicating peers.

An abstract representation that defines an application configuration, which is the IT infrastructure (including hardware and software components, relationships and dependencies) of a mission-critical application or business process.
A Motive desktop application which enables you to author models.

A configuration based on a particular model. Each overlay consists of one or more checks that evaluate an application issue. Each check is associated with one or more actions with which to address the issue.

Overlay Builder is a Motive desktop application which enables you to create overlays that help users address issues within their application environment. Overlays are available within the Motive model-based web applications to users who support application environments.

Motive product that helps customer support representatives (CSRs) identify service issues and resolve them, by allowing broadband service providers to define the hardware and software that a service depends on and then poll the relevant systems to determine whether the systems are operating correctly.
A web application that displays tests that CSRs can run to validate service for a particular subscriber.

A Short Message Service Centre is a network element in the mobile telephone network. Its purpose is to store, forward, convert, and deliver SMS messages. The full designation of an SMSC according to 3GPP is Short Message Service - Service Centre (SMS-SC).
5520 Access Management System
5523ADSL WorkStation
7300Advanced Services Access Manager. The 7301 ASAM is the name for release 5.0 or later of the 7300 ASAM.
7301Advanced Services Access Manager
Release 5.0 or later of the 7300ASAM.
7302Intelligent Services Access Manager
The 7302ISAM is a frame-based DSLAM that is based on a frame forwarding architecture in a packet aggregation network. The data in the 7302ISAM is forwarded according to Ethernet bridging rules.
7330 Intelligent Services Access Manager Fiber to the Node
Nokia 7342 ISAM Fiber To The User
A symmetric algorithm, which is based on the Rijndael algorithm, that uses a 128-, 192-, or 256-bit symmetric key.
The 7300 Advanced Services Access Manager and 7301 Advanced Services Access Manager.
application programming interface

Broadband digital communications connection that operates over standard copper telephone wires. It requires a DSL modem, which splits transmissions into two frequency bands: the lower frequencies for voice (telephone calls) and the upper band for digital data, especially for connection to the Internet. Data can be transferred using DSL at much higher rates than with ordinary dial-up modem service; the range of DSL signals, however, is very small. Connections can be made only within a few miles of the nearest transmitting station. ADSL can transmit analog (voice) and data information on the same line simultaneously.

DSL and xDSL are umbrella terms under which a variety of protocols and technologies fall. ADSL is a popular type of DSL in which most of the bandwidth of the connection is devoted to downloading data from the network to the user, leaving only a small-scale connection for uploading data. In HDSL and SDSL the data stream is symmetric; that is, the upstream and downstream rates are the same. UDSL, VDSL, and others still under development are intended to offer even greater rates of data transmission.
asynchronous transfer mode

This is based on the existing RFMU feature that provides a one-time collection of data based on a list of OIDs provided in the configuration file. The main difference with the real-time variant is that the data is collected internally in the system at preconfigured intervals and stored locally in files. This de-couples the internal collection from the external upload of the data by the operator.
The frequency with which SDC collects data from the DSLAMs. Possible values are TWO_DAYS, DAILY, HOURLY, and FIFTEEN_MINUTE.
A text file that contains one record per line and one or more fields delimited by commas.
An unclassified, U.S. government-sanctioned encryption and decryption technology that uses 56-bit encryption, with 8-bit error detection.
downstream power backoff
downstream
CSV and EML providers. A system that can provide a list of DSLAMs.
EMS manages the components of a network.
Element Management Layer
A type of node provider. An EML provider is the 5523AWS or the 5520AMS element-management systems.
General Bandwidth G6 Universal Media Gateway
A voice gateway manufactured by General Bandwidth Inc.
gigabit passive optical network

HDSL delivers 1.544 Mbit/s of bandwidth each way over two copper twisted pairs. Because HDSL provides T1 speed, telephone companies use HDSL to provision local access to T1 services whenever possible. The operating range of HDSL is limited to 12,000 feet (3658.5 meters), so signal repeaters are installed to extend the service.
secure hypertext transfer protocol
inverse multiplexing over ATM

The ITU is a civil international organization established to promote standardized telecommunications on a worldwide basis. The ITU-R and ITU-T are committees under the ITU. The ITU headquarters is located in Geneva, Switzerland. While it is older than the United Nations, it is recognized by the U.N. as the specialized agency for telecommunications.
IGMP is a protocol that is used between hosts and multicast routers on a single physical network to establish hosts' membership in particular multicast groups.
See 7302 ISAM and 7330 ISAM FTTN.
Java2 Standard Edition
Java Development Kit
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol
loss of frame
loss of link
line termination unit or line termination
LT is equipment that terminates the access line at the network end.
The MIB is a block of data in a network device that contains statistical and configuration information.
MIB-II collects DS1/E1 and DS3/E3 statistics.
MD5 is an encryption algorithm that can be used to determine whether the content of a message has not been modified and to authenticate the source of the message.
An open source relational database management system that uses Structured Query Language to add, access, and process data in a database.
Network Analyzer
NA performs analysis and diagnosis of DSLs for ADSL, SHDSL, VDSL, and multi-DSL cards on element-managed nodes.

The Nokia Network Analyzer-Fiber (NA-F) is a remote management solution for fiber access networks. NA-F leverages the service provider's existing equipment capabilities to speed up fiber activation, detect faults, and localize them in the access infrastructure.
Northbound interface
network element
number
network termination
object identifier
OAM refers to costs, tasks, or other aspects of operating, administering, and managing a telecommunication network.
Methods and procedures that directly support the daily operation of a telecommunications infrastructure.
OC is the optical equivalent of an STS-1 signal. It specifies a line rate for transmission of optical signals.

An ONT provides the subscriber-side interface of the optical access network and is connected to the Optical Distribution Network (ODN). It includes functionality that allows interfacing with user terminals. An ONT is used for Fiber To The Premises (FTTP).
protocol data unit

The capability of SDH networks to monitor the quality of a signal. The quality parameters are: number of bit errors, number of errored seconds (the client signal is disturbed), severely errored seconds (signal interruption).
The SDH node can log the parameters for both signal directions in 15-min and/or 24h intervals. At any time, the current performance parameters can be obtained.
Account profile for user management.
Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service
reach extended-asymmetrical digital subscriber line

This feature is used to retrieve a larger amount of statistical data than using the SNMP protocol on the network. RFMU continues to use the MIB OIDs and SNMP protocol internally within the ISAM node, but the resulting data collection is formatted to reduce the amount of information that is transferred to the management system through Xftp.
Statistics and Data Collector
The SDC collects and stores node-related statistics on a network-wide basis.
A 160-bit unpatented hash algorithm.

SMTP is the IETF standard for transferring electronic mail messages from one computer to another. It is the main protocol used to send electronic mail on the Internet. SMTP consists of a set of rules for how a program sending mail and a program receiving mail should interact.

SNMP is the IETF Internet network management protocol, the standard protocol for management. SNMP provides the means to monitor and set network configuration and runtime parameters. SNMP originated in the Internet community as a response to the need to manage TCP/IP devices. SNMP provides access to a device's MIB.

Examples of SNMP-compatible devices include routers, hubs, and switches. A device is SNMP-compatible if it can be monitored and/or controlled using SNMP messages. Devices that are SNMP-compatible contain SNMP agent software to receive, send, and act upon SNMP messages.
SOAP is a XML-based protocol for exchange of information in a decentralized, distributed environment. SOAP is defined by the World Wide Web Consortium (w3c).
A message that is originated by an agent application to alert a managing application of the occurrence of a significant event (not necessarily an outage, a fault, or a security violation).
An operating system used by Sun workstations. Solaris is a trademark of Sun.
A DSLAM node (DSL toward the subscribers and ATM or Ethernet toward the network) manufactured by Nokia.
Software management version.
SHDSL is a digital subscriber line technology that allows symmetric speeds up to T1 or E1 rate over a 48 twisted copper pair using an international transmission type.
SDH is an ITU standard for optical interfacing. It uses a synchronous high-speed signal and provides easy access to low-speed signals by mapping low-speed signals into VTs.
SDH is an international standard that is technically consistent with SONET, which is North American.

SONET is an ANSI standard for fiber optic transmission of high-speed digital traffic. SONET allows internetworking of transmission products from multiple vendors and defines a physical interface, optical line rates known as OC signals, frame format, and an OAM protocol. The base rate is 51.84 Mb/s (OC-1), and higher rates are multiples of the base rate.
SONET uses synchronous high-speed signals and provides easy access to low-speed signals by mapping them into VTs.
SONET is a North American standard that is technically consistent with SDH, which is international.
SPE is the user data part of an STS-1 data structure.
STS-1 is an electrical SONET construct that carries data at the rate of 51.84Mb/s. OC-1 is the equivalent optical signal.
threshold crossing alarm
Trivial File Transfer Protocol
Transaction Language 1
TU is an information structure within an SDH frame consisting of a VC payload and a TU pointer. TU is equivalent to a VT in a SONET frame.
UDSL is a unidirectional version of HDSL.
A type of node provider. A URL provider is a URL to a list of Nokia nodes that is used to synchronize the nodes with the SDC.
upstream
universal time code
very high speed DSL
VDSL2 is designed to support the wide deployment of triple play services such as voice, video, data, high-definition television, and interactive gaming.
A VC is a logical channel that is available across a physical ATM interface. This communications channel provides the sequential, unidirectional transport of ATM cells.
A logical group of nodes which may or may not be on the same physical network segment, but they share the same IP network number.
A VT is an information structure within a SONET frame. It consists of an SPE and a VT pointer. A VT is equivalent to a TU in an SDH frame.
A workstation is a personal computer or Sun workstation that can be used to perform tasks using the NA-SBI GUI.
ADSL, ADSL2, ADSL2+, RE-ADSL, SHDSL, VDSL, and VDSL2
LAC is unique number of current location area. A location area is a set of base stations that are grouped together to optimize signaling.

The served area of a cellular radio network is usually divided into location areas. Location areas are comprised of one or several radio cells. Each location area is given an unique number within the network, the Location Area Code. This code is used as a unique reference for the location of a mobile subscriber. This code is necessary to address the subscriber in the case of an incoming call. The LAC forms part of the Location Area Identifier (LAI) and is broadcasted on the Broadcast Control Channel (BCCH).
RAC is a fixed length of one octet and identifies a routing area within a location area. The RAC is part of the Routing Area Identity (RAI).

SCP brings intelligence to device management with advanced features that allow service providers to remotely manage and troubleshoot indoor small cell devices in both residential and enterprise markets. SCP delivers key management capabilities to accelerate time to market for subscriber services and to successfully deploy and maintain those services.

glossentry.glossterm: Small Cell Orchestration and Provisioning Data Source Adapter (SCOPE DSA)

glossdef.para: The SCOPE DSA is a software component of SCOPE that is intended to be used with the Small Cell Customer Service Console. It abstracts communication with SCOPE to make authoring Service Management Platform (SMP) models easier. Rather than having to write a web service client to communicate with the SCOPE Northbound Interface (NBI), you create a model that uses the SCOPE data source.

glossentry.glossterm: Small Cell Orchestration and Provisioning Engine ( SCOPE)

glossdef.para: SCOPE modelling is built on top of an SMP Motive Object Repository for Services and Enterprises (MORSE) tenant hierarchy customized for typical Small Cell deployment requirements.
SCMC enables the service providers to remotely provision, configure, update, manage, troubleshoot, and optimize Small Cells in both residential and enterprise markets.

The TAC is the initial eight-digit portion of the 15-digit IMEI and 16-digit IMEISV codes used to uniquely identify wireless devices. The TAC identifies a particular model (and often revision) of wireless telephone for use on a GSM, UMTS or other IMEI-employing wireless network.
Portions of the optical link that require an external power source, specifically, the OLT (optical line terminal) and ONT (optical network terminal).
A wavelength, or lambda, that transports a GPON signal, a TWDM channel pair signal, an XGS channel pair signal931scox ONA-8967.
A group that combines different channel pairs (with different wavelengths) onto the optical network.
A dedicated wavelength pair on an LT port.
In an optical link, a fiber section between two splitters.
A passive element of the PON branch that connects one fiber section to another.
In an optical link, a fiber section between the last splitter and the ONT (optical network terminal).

A fault is a problem in the optical infrastructure that degrades the received power. Faults that have reduce the received power level of at least one optical link by more than one dB and faults that interrupt the service of at least one optical link are major faults. These faults are identified immediately and based on the first sample were they are apparent. Minor faults are faults that do not affect any optical link by more than one dB and do not interrupt the service on any optical links. These faults are not identified immediately, but instead identification is based on an evaluation of data collected over time.
A fiber section in an optical link between the PON port and the first splitter.
A section of fiber cable between two elements in the optical link (that is between splitters, between OLT and splitter, and so on).

The ONT address is the TL1 address of the port on the network element with the ONT number appended. For example, SOMEGPON:1-1-1-1-1, where SOMEGPON:1-1-1-1 is the TL1 port address and the final digit (-1) is the ONT number.

In a PON (passive optical network), an OLT is the device that terminates the optical local loop at the edge of the service provider's network. The OLT generates downstream optical signals and receives upstream signals from the ONT (optical network terminal) at the subscriber's premises.
In a PON (passive optical network), the optical transmission channel, including the active and passive equipment.
Portions of the optical link that do not require an external power source such as the splitters, connectors, and fiber sections.

A PON consists of an OLT (optical line terminal) located at the Central Office (CO) and a set of associated ONTs (optical network terminals) located at the customer premise. Between them lies the Optical Distribution Network (ODN) comprised of fibers and passive splitters or couplers.

All ONTs share the upstream and downstream bandwidth of the ODN. There are several kinds of PON, such as ATM Passive Optical Network (APON), Broadband Passive Optical Network (BPON), Ethernet Passive Optical Network (EPON), Gigabit Passive Optical Network (GPON), and Time- and wavelength-division multiplexed Passive Optical Network (TWDM NG-PON2).
An fiber optic technology in which a fiber connects a transmitter to a single receiver in contrast to GPON, which is a point-to-multipoint technology. Jan: Please review this.
The portion of the optical link that includes only the passive equipment.

The data about the splitters and fiber branches in the PON and their relationship to each other. That is, which splitters are connected to which other splitters or ONTs and which fiber branches are connected to which ONTs.
A unique identifier of the PON. Channels map to the parent object PON through the PON ID. The PON can be GPON-only, TWDM-only, or GPON-TWDM.

Service impact classifies the optical link according to its optical performance and the (potential) impact the performance has on the service. Possible service impact classifications are: Available, Reduced robustness, Close to interruption, Interrupted, Switched off, and Unknown.

An optical joint which connects two optical fibers together. The splice has a low optical attenuation insertion loss in the transmission window and adequate mechanical strength during the whole of its lifetime. Two technologies of splicing may be used: fusion splicing and mechanical splicing. Source
A passive element of the PON that branches a single fiber into two or more branches.
An administrative domain to separate different providers or services.
A provider-defined string that uniquely identifies the subscriber.

DELT is a technology for testing the twisted pair transmission line and the DSL physical layer using both the CO and CPE DSL transceiver. DELT is based on broadband measurements. Note that the definition of DELT used by Nokia is broad in the sense that it covers all of the measurements for which communication between the CO and the CPE DSL transceiver is required. It includes in-service monitoring. DELT is not limited to the Loop Diagnostics measurement mode introduced in ADSL2 and VDSL2; it also includes in-service monitoring.

In contrast to SELT and NBLT, which are specific tests that must be invoked through the GUI or an NBI call, DELT is an integral part of NA-C activity, including LQDs, network analysis, and DLM. For DELT, there is no button in the GUI or specific NBI call. Instead, it happens behind the scenes in the context of these other activities. DELT inspections include line state diagnosis inspections, line quality diagnosis inspections, short line quality diagnosis inspections, and dashboard inspections.

There is no separate DELT standard. Instead, DELT measurement parameters are included in the different standards for ADSL (ITU G.992.1), ADSL2 (ITU G.992.3), ADSL2plus (ITU G.992.5), VDSL (ITU G.993.1), VDSL2 (ITU G.993.2), and SHDSL (ITU G.991.2). ITU recommendation G.997.1, which describes the physical layer management for digital subscriber line (DSL) transceivers, is especially of interest.

In Network Analyzer-Copper, Dynamic Line Management (DLM) is an automated process that evaluates DSL port behavior based on service templates, and determines whether a profile switch can improve port performance or stability. DLM automatically chooses the optimal configuration profile for a specified service, depending on the measured line conditions. If line problems are detected, settings can be adjusted automatically, which prevents or minimizes service interruptions.

The VDSL2 / G.fast electrical length is the value in dB at 1 MHz of a model of the loop attenuation with a perfect square root-of-the-frequency characteristic. Because this loop attenuation model does not characterize the loop perfectly, the VDSL2 / G.fast electrical length may deviate from the loop attenuation measured at 1 MHz. 920scox NA-19649
Errored seconds are defined in the DSL standard as a count of 1-second intervals with one or more CRC-8 anomalies, or one or more LOS defects, or one or more SEF defects, or one or more LPR defects.
MTBE is measured in Mb and is determined by upstream and downstream, coding violations in showtime.
MTBR is showtime divided by the number of spontaneous resynchronizations.
Network Analyzer-Copper is a Nokia product that performs analysis and diagnosis of DSLs for ADSL, SHDSL, VDSL, and multi-DSL cards on element-managed nodes.

NBLT is a technology for testing the twisted pair transmission line, the POTS transceiver at the DSLAM side, and the POTS transceiver of the phone set. NBLT is based on narrowband measurements. It applies to POTS and DSL.

ITU recommendation G.996.2 (G.lt) standardizes NBLT as MELT (Metallic Line Testing), but only for DSL. MELT-PMD (measurement function) is integrated in the DSLAM. MELT-P is integrated in NA-C NBLT package.

Note that NBLT remains the name for the NA-C package both for POTS and DSL as well as for the measurement function of the ISAM-V for POTS. MELT will only be used for the measurement function of the ISAM for DSL.

Severely errored seconds are defined in the DSL standard as a count of 1-second intervals with 18 or more CRC-8 anomalies, or one or more LOS defects, or one or more SEF defects, or one or more LPR defects.

SELT is a technology for testing the twisted pair transmission line directly from the central-office (CO) DSL transceiver when the CPE (Customer Premises Equipment) is not yet installed or no synchronization between the CO and CPE DSL transceiver is possible. SELT is based on broadband measurements. ITU recommendation G.996.2 (G.lt) standardizes SELT.
A Field Tehnician (FT) is a professional who diagnoses and rectifies DSL connection issues on the field.
Field Tech Console (FTC) is an interface which allows field technicians to perform real-time DSL diagnostics.
Line Quality Diagnosis (LQD) monitors a DSL on-demand over time for troubleshooting complex intermittent service quality problems.
Line State Diagnosis (LSD) provides on-demand the current view on a DSL for troubleshooting equipment fault and stationary loop impairments.
Plain Old Telephone Service (POTS ) is the voice-grade telephone service that is based on analog signal transmission.
Alternate name for a subject that can be used in search paths. Aliases can be used to normalize device names so they are consistently located. For example, Blackberry 9800 = Blackberry Torch.

A content item that adds value to a fact. For example, the location of the Ethernet connector of a modem is a fact; this fact has an image of the device highlighting the connector on the back of the device. This image is an asset that can be retrieved by the user, allowing a better understanding about the precise location of the connector.
The different types of content that can be stored as assets belonging to facts are divided into asset categories:
Documents: Adobe PDF, Word docs, spreadsheets, PowerPoint presentations and slideshows, text, HTML, XML, and so on.
Media: images, video PIC, PNG, GIF, BMP, WBMP, JPEG, TIFF, MP3, MP4, WAV, AVI, MOV, MPEG,WMA, WMV, and so on.
Articles: how-tos, FAQs, wiki pages, and so on.
Binaries:firmware, SMP workflows, and so on.

Different rules are used for acquiring, storing, and retrieving the information depending on its type (category). For example, an article downloaded from the web needs an HTML renderer; a video is streamed, and so on.

An entity that defines a characteristic of a subject. A subject is identified by its set of attributes. An attribute consists of a name and a value. Examples of attributes for a Device subject might be: Make, Model, Hardware, and Firmware.
Typically, a user would retrieve the facts associated with a subject by querying KMP using the attributes that identify the subject.

The result of a query in which an application receives either exact matching results or the next best match based on inheritance. The order of the facts returned is based on the state of the fact: Applicable, Not Applicable, or Unconfirmed. Compare to exact match query.

A system for storing binary assets that mimics a file system implemented in a database. For facts that go beyond simple sets of key/value string pairs such as images, PDF files, or firmware images, the facts have references compatible with JSR-170 (JCR) into the content repository for these binaries.

The result of a query that requires specific information regarding a subject. The exact match is either the data directly associated with the subject node or the data inherited with verification for this subject. An exact match should be used when data relevancy is critical for the use case. Compare to best available match query.

A piece of information known about a subject.Facts are instances of a general class defined by a fact type.Facts themselves are broken down further into properties and tables of properties that characterize the fact.The properties have validation criteria associated to them by a fact type. A fact can also contain assets, which can be, for instance, a picture of a device showing the location of the power switch. Facts can have tags to help with data queries. Facts can be added to any subject at any level. Facts added at higher levels are inherited by any subjects below.

A fact can be a simple property with a value, a knowledge article, a device model, a workflow package, or anything that can be associated with a subject. For example, here is a simple property with a value:

A class that allows facts to be modeled to contain certain data values and assets. The fact types allow an application to predetermine the type and format of data returned from a query response. Data values and assets can be constrained to maintain data integrity (list, Boolean, numeric, asset size, and so on).

Fact instances (or just facts for short) are instances of fact types.Fact types define the properties that a given fact can (and potentially must) have. Fact types themselves can inherit property definitions from other fact types to create a hierarchy of inheritance. Through this inheritance mechanism, fact types can inherit the properties from another fact type with the ability to modify (overload), extend (add), and remove individual properties. Fact types are also responsible for defining validation criteria that can be used to ensure fact instances are created correctly.
Example:
glossdef.programlisting:
Fact Type = USB_Port
Property = "Port Type" = List: A, B, Mini-A, Mini-B, Micro-A, Micro-B Property = "Number of Ports" = Integer value ; Constraint: 1-24

glossdef.para: The program that conducts device testing as well as the collection and management of knowledge for device certification. See also Knowledge Management Service (KMS).
The web-based user interface that provides the KMP administrator and other users with the tools to manage and use KMP.
A collection of subject types, subjects, and the facts associated with thesubjects.

An SMP integration component. KMP provides a central repository for configuration management of SMP content such as workflows and models and config items such as workflow modules and service operations. In an SMP installation, the content and config items make up the application configuration.

A service that manages and distributes support information through a cloud-based service. This information includes device specifications, knowledge articles, and other support assets. With this knowledge, providers can enhance their support capabilities for both self-service and customer-service support. In addition, the information includes statistics for reporting query usage patterns and popularity.

An entity that defines a simple piece of information that is part of a fact. A property consists of a name and a value. For example, suppose that something you know about a device is that it is green (fact), but what is green? You can say that green is a color. So, by defining a property named color, KMP can store the information about a subject being, for instance, green or red (property value).

Aunique entity or concept. Examples could be anything from 2-Wire 2200 router to Windows 7.Subjects can have factsassociated with them.Subjects are also uniquely identified by a set of attributes that identify the tree structure or levels.Attributes for a device could include Make, Model, Hardware, and Firmware.
Subjects are collected in hierarchical fashion using a tree model. The tree model provides an organization that is easy to use and allows for inheritance of knowledge.
Acollection or domain of subjects that share the same attributes. Subjects are grouped together into subject types. Here is an example pertaining to devices:
Device is a subject type where its subjects are characterized by the attributes Make, Model, Hardware, and Firmware.
Metadata for facts that can help locate the proper information for a query.

Added for HDM 4.0.0, HDM-2612The protocol describes requirements for an Auto-configuration Server (ACS) Northbound Interface (NBI) that allows Operational and Business Support Systems to access ACS functionality. These requirements are derived from a set of device management and service management use cases. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-131 report that documents this protocol.End of content for HDM-2612
The initial eight-digit portion of the 15-digit IMEI code used to uniquely identify a wireless device.
AE is a Nokia product that allows all data computation resulting in KPIs and Events that are merged in HDFS with the final devices inventory table to be displayed based on several dimensions.

An Alcatel-Lucent product that offers a highly scalable data collection and analytics system for the data collected from TR-069, OMA-DM and other similar protocols, which are managed by the Motive family of products. The DMP splits data collection from the device management activities, is positioned as a central data collection manager for the complete Motive portfolio, and is device protocol agnostic.
Before release 2.0, DMP was known as Data Collection Manager (DCM).

HQL is a query language similar to SQL that enables you to query the data in a file system. It uses a predefined set of configuration parameters that control query execution. It is used in the DMP Administration Console.

SBI is a component of DMP that is responsible for collecting data from the devices, filtering of collected data, and uploading the data to the data store. The SBI framework implements a plug-in architecture that can support multiple device protocols such as, TR-069, IPDR, and other custom formats.

Just like Windows PC systems use a .exe file for installing software, Google's Android operating system uses APK as the file format to distribute and install application software and middleware. APK files are ZIP file formatted packages based on the JAR file format, with .apk file extensions.
A special feature supported by some phones, where users can update their handset firmware over the carrier network.
An Open Mobile Alliance specification for updating the firmware of mobile devices over the air.
A command that uses key and certificate information from a keystore to generate digital signatures for JAR files.

A datatype used to store large amounts of data (maximum size is 4 Gigabytes) in a table column. Examples of data stored as LOB: ASCII text, National Character text, files in various graphics formats, sound wave forms.

An Alcatel-Lucent product that allows service providers to remotely provision, update, and manage both fixed (for example, a residential gateway) and mobile devices and services throughout the device life cycle. The product provides individual and bulk device configuration, problem resolution, firmware upgrades, event management, user management, and reporting. UDM belongs to the Motive CXS family of products.
DAF is a set of tools and methodologies used to automate the deployment.

Motive HAL is a Nokia product that is composed of a home insights module to report the insights on the current status of the home Wi-Fi network and a recommendations module to provide home experience repair and improvement recommendations.

glossentry.glossterm: Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State (HATEOAS)

glossdef.para: Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State (HATEOAS)
Key performance indicator
Key quality indicator
Mobile Native Test and Diagnostics (WES)
MAS provides a highly scalable and fully functional analytics platform within which multiple analytics/ portfolio applications can seamlessly interoperate as a solution.
NBI is an interface used to retrieve the historical view of KPIs, KQIs, and recommendations.

RDD is an abstraction provided by Spark application. It is a collection of elements partitioned across the nodes of the cluster that can be operated on in parallel. RDDs are created by starting with a file in the Hadoop file system (or any other Hadoop-supported file system), or an existing Scala collection in the driver program, and transforming it. Users may also ask Spark to persist an RDD in memory, allowing it to be reused efficiently across parallel operations. Finally, RDDs automatically recover from node failures.

SBI is a component of MAS that is responsible for collecting data from the devices, filtering of collected data, and uploading the data to the data store. The SBI framework implements a plug-in architecture that can support multiple device protocols such as, TR-069, IPDR, and other custom formats.
The wrapper for a protocol-specific function run on a device. All actions contain protocol-specific functions, and all policies contain actions.

Setting up a device so that it can securely connect using the OMA DM protocol. The process involves adding information into the device. The parameters consist of the URL of CDP, server username, server password, server nonce and a client username, client password and client nonce which are shared in the exchange between the server and device. Nonce means not once and is used to protect against replay attacks.

Known as "campaign" in CDP, it is a job running against multiple devices identified by a selection criterion. Properties of a bulk job include the action, selection criterion, exit options, and setting options.

A job running against multiple devices identified by a selection criterion. Properties of a campaign include the action, selection criterion, exit options, and setting options. In CDP, it is also known as "bulk job".

The Nokia Motive Connected Device Platform (CDP) is a system for managing a wide range of devices across fixed, mobile, and converged networks. Service providers and enterprises can also use CDP to securely manage billions of devices resulting from Machine-to-Machine (M2M) technology and the Internet of Things (IoT).
A protocol for device management, representing the underlying communications protocol as well as object model paradigm for a device. Examples of device protocols include TR-069, LWM2MOMA-DM.
A GSM device identifier consisting of a subscriber ID (MSISDN or IP address), a network ID (IMSI), a device ID (IMEI or MAC address).
Identifies specific a make, a model, or a generic category of devices with certain common characteristics including authentication method, supported operations, and data model.

A placeholder value that can be resolved to a device-specific, appropriate value at run time. It enables configuring device-specific pre-provisioned parameters on a group of devices with a single instant-triggered or event-triggered policy.
A unique identifier for a CDMA cell phone. A CDMA cell phone generally does not use a SIM card to identify and authenticate subscribers to the network like a GSM carrier does.
A job that automatically gets queued for a device whenever a specific event is raised related to that device. In CDP, an event-triggered job is known as a policy.
Policy options that provide the ability to set service tags to given values after a policy has run successfully or unsuccessfully on a specific device.

glossentry.glossterm: Extensible Authentication Protocol-Authentication and Key Agreement (EAP-AKA)

glossdef.para: An authentication framework for providing the transport and usage of keying material and parameters using the AKA mechanism. AKA is a security protocol used in 3G networks. EAP-AKA is defined in RFC 4187.

An operation that implements protocol-specific RPC (Remote Procedure Call) methods to be run on a device. A function can be run as part of an action in bulk campaigns, or it can be applied to single devices on its own or as part of an action. Functions can be built-in or custom.
A network point that serves as an entrance to another network.

A database containing data regarding subscribers of a mobile operator network. Information stored in an HLR includes the IMSI (International Mobile Subscriber Identity) and the Mobile Station International Subscriber Directory Number (MSISDN) of each subscription.

Master database that keeps a list of features and services associated with a user, and that tracks the location and means of access of users. The HSS provides functions that are required in next generation mobile and fixed-mobile converged networks. These functions include HLR.

glossentry.glossterm: Intelligent Management Platform for All Connected Things (IMPACT)

glossdef.para: A gateway used to access M2M end points where direct connection is not possible either because of protocol variation or because the end point is located in an area network that requires an interim gateway to gain access. It can be located on a remote server or in the area network where the device is located.
An expression language (a language that allows communication with the application logic) designed for easy embedding scripting in applications and frameworks written in Java.
The association of an action with target devices. In CDP, jobs are used to manage devices. A job includes metadata such as timeout values for job execution and device specific parameters.

A job can be a single device job, a bulk job (campaign), or an Event Triggered Job (policy). In case of bulk jobs and event-triggered jobs, it works as a rule that defines a set of conditions (such as selection criteria or device groups) and associated actions. If a device meets these conditions, the specified actions for that rule are run on the device.
A job continues to run against targeted devices unless it expires or reaches a failure threshold or the configured retry count. Jobs run only on devices that are enabled.

Lightweight M2M (LWM2M) is a communication protocol from the Open Mobile Alliance (OMA) for M2M or IoT devices management. It provides a link between devices with an LWM2M agent and LWM2M-enabled servers. The LWM2M protocol allows to remotely perform tasks, run diagnostics, and perform application and device management on IoT embedded devices.

A communication domain supporting automatic FOTA (Firmware Over-The-Air), automatic Software Over-The-Air (SOTA), Lightweight Machine-to-Machine (LWM2M) device management, and gateway connected device and sensor management.
A device is "manageable" from the moment CDP recognizes the make or model (that is, the device entry exists in devices.xml).

Whether a manageable device can be managed depends on other (non-technical) aspects such as is the subscriber bill paid, is the account active or has it been suspended, and so on. (The exact reason why a manageable device cannot be managed is beyond the scope of CDP, for example, a trigger from the OSS or BSS, but it makes sense to let the operator turn the managed flag On or Off on CDP.)

A protocol for transmitting a series of related instant messages in the context of a communications session. The MSRP protocol is defined in RFC 4975. MSRP is used in the RCS context, especially for the instant messaging, file transfer and photo sharing features.
A code consisting of 3 decimal digits that identifies a country. Together with the MNC, it uniquely defines a mobile network operator in a certain country.
A unique number for a mobile device. The MEID URN should be a valid, 14 digit number.

A code consisting of 2 or 3 decimal digits that identifies a mobile network. The code per network is unique per country. Together with the MCC, it uniquely defines a mobile network operator in a certain country.

glossentry.glossterm: Mobile Station International Subscriber Directory Number (MSISDN)

glossdef.para: A unique identification for a subscriber of a cellular network operator. It is the number dialed to connect to the subscriber. It is used for routing calls to the subscriber. The MSISDN can change in time.
A unique code to identify a mobile device, consisting of 10 decimal digits.
Used by integrators to connect CDP to customer systems.
Serves as the residential gateway (RGW) and Nokia SmartHome IoT gateway.
A job that automatically gets queued for a device whenever a specific event is raised related to that device. In CDP, policy is also known as "event-triggered job".

A communication protocol, providing a rich message system, capable of service discovery, implementation of individual communication features and transmission of in-call multimedia. Communication features include chat, group chat, MSRP file sharing, video sharing.

A collection of search parameters that can be used to locate devices. The CDP console provides a set of default search criteria templates. Users can add custom templates from the CDP console. A search criteria template is also known as a criteria template.
A Nokia legacy Mobile Device Manager (MDM) product.

A descriptive name and value pair that you can associate with a device to group devices according to the services that are deployed on them, for example, VOIP=enabled). You can set service tags as exit options on policy success or failure. Service tags can be used for selection criteria and for reporting, for example email.
A protocol for network management and the monitoring of network devices and their functions.
A trigger in the form of an SMS message. The SMS event can trigger a policyPolicy in CDP.
An end user of CDP, who can be a service provider, an affiliate of a service provider, or an enterprise configured to access CDP in a multi-tenant deployment.
The CPE WAN Management Protocol (CWMP) protocol defined by the Broadband Forum. See the Broadband Forum for the TR-069 report that documents the protocol.
An object on an ONT or another gateway device that acts as a proxy for a device. The virtual device is associated with the gateway so that the device can be managed by CDP.

A service that enables subscribers to manage their mailbox messages through a visual interface. Subscribers can use the VVM client on their devices to listen to, delete and compose messages in any order. SMS messages are sent between the VVM service and the client to notify the client about events in the subscriber mailbox.
A technology specification that defines the standards and procedures for delivering voice communication over 4G LTE networks using the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS).

SMP-provided or custom content that provides specific functionality on a Service Portal site. A dashboard widget is configured to request execution of specific interactive workflows and service operations for which results are rendered on the dashboard of a page.
An interactive workflow that is to run on a Service Portal site when a user first accesses the site.
A page on a Service Portal site. The supported layout page types are dashboard, workspace, and custom.
An area on a workspace page that is docked or undocked.

SMP's user interface framework with which to create service portal applications. Each application becomes an individual portal site based on a site definition. Two reference portal sites, Customer Support Portal (CSP) and Self Service Portal (SSP), are provided with SMP.
SMP's mechanism for running pre-defined startup content when a user first accesses a Service Portal site.
A .json file containing site definitions and attributes.

In Workflow Builder, an interactive workflow stencil. The Subscriber Data stencil is used in initialization workflows for Service Portal sites. A .json file containing widget definitions and attributes.

Plugin software that enables SMP to retrieve data from a Node-RED server data source.
The service operation content created in Node-RED editor is called as flow.
The settings.js file is used to configure Node-RED. The Node-RED DSA connection parameters, the logging options and the users for the Node-RED editor are configured in the settings.js.

The smp soap request node is used for invoking SOAP calls. During the execution of the Node-RED flow based service operation from SMP, the msg.payload of the http input node is passed as input to the SOAP Method configured in the smp soap request node.
The smpstorage.js is the storage custom module to store Node-RED data in SMP.
